Quiz Results

Part 27 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 261-270)

Quiz Attempt #119208

Total Questions: 27
Question 1
Which of the statements are true of innovations?(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)a. Innovations are a must to survive in businessb. Discontinuous innovations lead to failuresc. Continuous innovations do not disrupt established usage and behaviour patternsd. Line extensions are discontinuous innovationse. Indiscontinuous innovations, there is a change not only in technology but also in behavioural patterns of usage and consumptionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b, d and e only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, c and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and e only

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Continuous innovation is when a company makes a constant improvement to the products, services, or technologies that they are responsible for. This improvement does not radically change the product, etc.; neither does it radically change the buying habits or usage patterns of that company’s customers. This must be done dynamically and continuously to save time, increase effectiveness, and maintain customer loyalty.

 

The opposite of continuous innovation is discontinuous innovation. Also known as radical innovations or disruptive innovations, this is when a company launches a new product or service that is completely different from a previous product or service, leading to a major change in consumer habits. This major change can either be negative or positive.

Question 2
Which of the following is one of the five main factors given by E. M. Rogers that influence adoption of an innovation?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)
  • A.Accountability
  • B.Trialability
  • C.Flexibility
  • D.Saleability
Correct Answer: Trialability

Diffusion of Innovation (DOI) Theory is developed by E.M. Rogers in 1962. It originated in communication to explain how, over time, an idea or product gains momentum and diffuses (or spreads) through a specific population or social system. The end result of this diffusion is that people, as part of a social system, adopt a new idea, behavior, or product. Adoption means that a person does something differently than what they had previously (i.e., purchase or use a new product, acquire and perform a new behaviour, etc.). The key to adoption is that the person must perceive the idea, behaviour, or product as new or innovative. It is through this that diffusion is possible.

 

The theory suggests that the stages by which a person adopts an innovation, and whereby diffusion is accomplished, include awareness of the need for an innovation, decision to adopt (or reject) the innovation, initial use of the innovation to test it, and continued use of the innovation. There are 5 main factors that influence adoption of an innovation, and each of these factors is at play to a different extent in the 5 adopter categories.

 

1. Relative Advantage - The degree to which an innovation is seen as better than the idea, program, or product it replaces.

2. Compatibility - How consistent the innovation is with the values, experiences, and needs of the potential adopters.

3. Complexity - How difficult the innovation is to understand and/or use.

4. Trialability - The extent to which the innovation can be tested or experimented with before a commitment to adopt is made.

5. Observability - The extent to which the innovation provides tangible results.

Question 3
"Innovation is the specific instruments of entrepreneurship-the act that endows resources with a new capacity to create wealth". Who said this?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)
  • A.Peter Drucker
  • B.J. A. Schumpeter
  • C.Frank H. Knight
  • D.Frank W. Young
Correct Answer: Peter Drucker

It was said by Peter Drucker.

Peter Drucker's quote captures the essence of innovation and its relationship with entrepreneurship.

 

Let's break it down:

 

"Innovation is the specific instrument of entrepreneurship..."

Here, Drucker emphasizes that innovation is not just a byproduct or an optional add-on to entrepreneurship; rather, it's the very tool, the specific instrument, that entrepreneurs use to create and seize opportunities. In other words, innovation is at the core of what it means to be an entrepreneur. It's the means by which entrepreneurs navigate challenges, identify unmet needs, and bring about change.

 

"...the act that endows resources with a new capacity to create wealth."

Drucker highlights the transformative power of innovation. By introducing new ideas, methods, products, or services, entrepreneurs enable resources—whether they be financial, human, or material—to achieve more than they could before. This "new capacity to create wealth" refers not only to monetary wealth but also to value creation in broader terms, such as social impact, customer satisfaction, or industry advancement.

 

In essence, Drucker is saying that entrepreneurship harnesses innovation to unlock potential and generate value. By constantly seeking new ways to solve problems and meet needs, entrepreneurs drive progress, spur economic growth, and shape the future. Innovation, therefore, is not just a buzzword but the very lifeblood of entrepreneurial activity, propelling societies forward and transforming the world we live in.

Question 4
Match List I with List II(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)List I (Name of Theories)A. Theory of Opportunities and InnovationB. Theory of profitC. Theory of Entrepreneurial SupplyD. Psychoanalytic TheoryList II (Propounder)I. Frank H KnightII. Peter F. DruckerIII. Sigmund FeudIV. Thomas CochranChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
  • D.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III

The correct matching between List I (Name of Theories) and List II (Propounder) is:

A. Theory of Opportunities and Innovation - II. Peter F. Drucker
B. Theory of Profit - I. Frank H Knight
C. Theory of Entrepreneurial Supply - IV. Thomas Cochran
D. Psychoanalytic Theory - III. Sigmund Freud

So, the correct answer is (B) A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III.

Question 5
Which of the following are relevant in technological innovations?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Most innovations are incrementalb. Most innovations involve the commercial utilization of ideasc. Innovations cannot be explained with isoquantsd. Introduction of innovations is not stimulated by strong domestic rivalry and geographic concentrationse. The risk in introducing innovations is usually highChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.b, d and e only
  • B.a, c and e only
  • C.a, b and e only
  • D.a, b and c only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

In the context of technological innovations, several factors are typically relevant.

 

Let's analyze each statement to determine its relevance:

a. Most innovations are incremental: This is true. Many technological innovations involve small, continuous improvements rather than radical changes.

b. Most innovations involve the commercial utilization of ideas: This is true. Innovation often requires taking an idea and turning it into a marketable product or service.

c. Innovations cannot be explained with isoquants: This is false. Isoquants are used in economics to show combinations of inputs that produce the same output, and they can be used to explain the impacts of innovations on production processes.

d. Introduction of innovations is not stimulated by strong domestic rivalry and geographic concentrations: This is false. Strong domestic rivalry and geographic concentrations (clusters) often stimulate innovation due to competitive pressures and knowledge spillovers.

e. The risk in introducing innovations is usually high: This is true. Innovations often involve uncertainty and significant risk, particularly in terms of market acceptance and technical feasibility.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (C), i.e., a, b and e only.

Question 6
Diffusion of Innovation Theory is associated with: (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.Peter Drucker
  • B.Schumpeter
  • C.Everett Rogers
  • D.Fredrick Taylor
Correct Answer: Everett Rogers

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Diffusion of Innovation (DOI) Theory is developed by E.M. Rogers in 1962. It is one of the oldest social science theories. It originated in communication to explain how, over time, an idea or product gains momentum and diffuses (or spreads) through a specific population or social system. The end result of this diffusion is that people, as part of a social system, adopt a new idea, behaviour, or product.

Question 7
Innovative small firms are more likely to be in existence in which of the following sectors?I. Knowledge-based servicesII. BiotechnologyIII. Information technologyIV. AutomobilesV. CementChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.IV, V only
  • B.III, IV, V only
  • C.I, III only
  • D.II, V only
Correct Answer: I, III only

Option C is the correct answer.

Question 8
Who has described initiation and implementation as the 2 stages of organizational innovation? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.John Child
  • B.Zaltman et. al
  • C.Manz et. al
  • D.N.R. Anderson
Correct Answer: Zaltman et. al

Zaltman said that Innovation takes place in two processes. “Innovation Adoption” is referred to when innovation takes place at the initiation stage whereas at the implementation stage, it is called “Innovation Diffusion”.  The study of innovation should be distinguished between these two processes and needs either cross-sectional or longitudinal investigation.

Question 9
Which of the following technique stimulates people to greater creativity by meeting with others and participating in organized group experiences? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2014)
  • A.Brain writing
  • B.Gordon method
  • C.Brain storming session
  • D.Big-dream approach
Correct Answer: Brain storming session

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Brainstorming is a technique that stimulates people to greater creativity by meeting with others and participating in organized group experiences. During a brainstorming session, individuals come together to generate a large number of ideas and solutions for a specific problem or challenge. The emphasis is on encouraging free expression of ideas, avoiding criticism, and fostering a collaborative and creative environment.

Question 10
Which one of the following is not a major area of entrepreneurial innovation as suggested by Joseph Schumpeter? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.Product innovation
  • B.Process innovation
  • C.Market innovation
  • D.Structural innovation
Correct Answer: Structural innovation

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Austrian economist Joseph Schumpeter was among the first to lay out a clear concept of entrepreneurship. He distinguished inventions from the entrepreneur’s innovations. Schumpeter pointed out that entrepreneurs innovate not just by figuring out how to use inventions, but also by introducing new means of production, new products, and new forms of organization. These innovations, he argued, take just as much skill and daring as does the process of invention.

 

He placed an emphasis on innovation, such as:

New products

New production methods

New markets

New forms of organization

Question 11
Pichot suggested 3 roles for the intrapreneurin promoting innovation. Indicate the correct answer. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2014)
  • A.Inventor, innovator and sponsor
  • B.Inventor, product champion and sponsor
  • C.Team builder, information source and advocate
  • D.Mould breaker, change agent and sponsor
Correct Answer: Inventor, product champion and sponsor

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Gifford Pinchot III, an American entrepreneur, author and co-founder Pinchot University, is credited with inventing the concept of Intrapreneurship in a paper that he and his wife, Elizabeth Pinchot, wrote in 1978 titled “Intra-Corporate Entrepreneurship”. The Pinchots first book, “Intrapreneuring: Why You Don’t Have to Leave the Corporation to Become an Entrepreneur (1985)” presented an expansion of the Intrapreneurship concept.

 

He suggested 3 roles for Intrapreneur:

(i) Product champion

(ii) Inventor

(iii) Sponsor

Question 12
Match the following: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT SEP 2013)List – I (Innovation)(a) Paradigm innovation(b) Position innovation(c) Product innovation(d) Process innovationList – II (Refers to)(i) Changes in the things which are organization offers.(ii) Changes in the ways in which they are created and delivered.(iii) Changes in the context in which the products/services are introduced.(iv) Changes in the underlying mental models which frame what the organization does.Codes:
  • A.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)

Francis and Bessant (2005) have invented how organizations can map innovations. Framework is called “The 4Ps of innovation space”. In that framework every innovation can be mapped somewhere in the 4 dimension space. Dimensions are process, position, product and paradigm.

 

Product innovation (first P of the 4Ps) is the easiest to understand. It means changes in the things which an organization offers.

 

Process innovation (second P of 4Ps) is also quite easy to understand. It means changes in the organization’s processes. In the other words it means changes in the ways in which organization is created and delivered.

 

Position innovation (third P of 4Ps) to understand needs some thinking and it is not as clear as the first two innovation types. It means changes in the context in which the products/services are introduced.

 

The last P is meaning for Paradigm innovation. It is by far the hardest to understand. Meaning for that is changes in the underlying mental models which frame what the organization does.

Question 13
The book ‘Innovation and Entrepreneurship’ is written by: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.Harold Koontz
  • B.Blake and Mouton
  • C.Peter F. Drucker
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Peter F. Drucker

Peter Drucker's classic book “Innovation and Entrepreneurship”, is the first book to present innovation and entrepreneurship as a purposeful and systematic discipline that explains and analyzes the challenges and opportunities of America’s new entrepreneurial economy. Superbly practical, Innovation and Entrepreneurship explains what established businesses, public service institutions, and new ventures need to know and do to succeed in today's economy.

Question 14
Which one of the following idea generation methods focusses on developing new ideas when the individuals are unaware of the problem? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.Gordon method
  • B.Checklist method
  • C.Creative problem solving
  • D.Brain-storming
Correct Answer: Gordon method

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Gordon Method – Gordon method is a method of developing new ideas when the individuals are unaware of the problem. In this method the entrepreneur starts by mentioning a general concept associated with the problem. The group responds with expressing a number of ideas.

Question 15
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:Entrepreneurial innovation and experimentation constantly destroy the old and introduce new equilibria, making possible higher standards of living.Reason “R”:Markets do not passively tend towards equilibrium until profit margins are wiped out.Select thecorrect answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.
  • B.“A”is corrects but“R”is incorrect.
  • C.Both“A” and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of“A”.
  • D.Both“A”and“R”are correct, but“R”is not the right explanation of“A”.
Correct Answer: “A”is corrects but“R”is incorrect.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Joseph Alois Schumpeter (1883 - 1950) was an economist and one of the 20th century's greatest intellectuals. He is best known for his 1942 book “Capitalism, Socialism, and Democracy,” as well as the theory of dynamic economic growth known as “creative destruction.”

 

This was a penetrating and unique insight about how economies grow. Schumpeter explained economic progress is not gradual and peaceful but rather disjointed and sometimes unpleasant. Whenever an entrepreneur disrupts an existing industry, it is likely that existing workers, businesses or even entire sectors can be temporarily thrown into loss. These cycles are tolerated, he explained, because it allows resources to be freed up for other, more productive uses.

 

Schumpeter’s arguments sharply deviated from the dominant tradition in many other respects. First, he highlighted the fact that markets do not passively tend toward equilibrium until profit margins are wiped out. Instead, entrepreneurial innovation and experimentation constantly destroy the old and introduce new equilibria, making possible higher standards of living.

 

In many respects, Schumpeter saw capitalism as a method of evolution within the social and economic hierarchy. The entrepreneur becomes the revolutionary, upsetting the established order to create dynamic change. Much of Schumpeter’s analysis of entrepreneurism was developed in his 1911 “Theory of Economic Development."

Question 16
Consider the following statements.Statement I:All ideas are opportunities. (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)Statement II:An opportunity is an idea that has the qualities of being attractive, durable and timely.Which of the following options is correct?
  • A.Both the statements are correct
  • B.Both the statements are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct while statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect while statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect while statement II is correct

An Idea is a thought, an impression, or a notion.

1) An idea may or may not meet the criteria of an opportunity.

2) many entrepreneurial ventures fail not because the entrepreneurs that launched them didn’t work hard, but rather because there was no real opportunity to begin with.

3) the idea should fill a need and meets the criteria for an opportunity.

 

Therefore, Statement (I) is incorrect. Not all ideas are opportunities.

 

An opportunity has 4 essential qualities. It is (1) attractive, (2) durable, (3) timely, and (4) anchored in a product, service, or business that creates or adds value for its buyer or end user.

 

Therefore, Statement (II) is correct.

Question 17
Which of the following is NOT a source of opportunity identification? (UGC NET Management DEC 2019)
  • A.Employees and ex-employees
  • B.Dealers and Distributors
  • C.Policy Documents
  • D.Friends and relatives
Correct Answer: Policy Documents

Opportunities refer to favourable external factors that could give an organization a competitive advantage. For example, if a country cuts tariffs, a car manufacturer can export its cars into a new market, increasing sales and market share. Such opportunities can arise in any form and we can identify these opportunities using various sources.

Question 18
Deferment, Autonomy of object, use of the common place, involvement/detachment and use of metaphor are description of which of the following technique? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Brainstorming
  • B.Synectics
  • C.Forced Relationship
  • D.Attribute listing
Correct Answer: Synectics

The correct answer is option B - Synectics.

 

Synectics is a creative problem-solving technique that involves thinking analogically, making connections between seemingly unrelated or different elements. The characteristics mentioned in the question - deferment, autonomy of object, use of the common place, involvement/detachment, and use of metaphor - are associated with the Synectics technique.

 

Deferment: Delaying judgment or decision-making to allow creative ideas to emerge.

 

Autonomy of object: Encouraging independent and unique thinking about different elements.

 

Use of the common place: Connecting ideas by finding common elements or places.

 

Involvement/detachment: Balancing emotional involvement and detachment for effective problem-solving.

 

Use of metaphor: Applying metaphorical thinking to draw parallels and generate creative solutions.

 

These characteristics are integral to the Synectics technique, making option (B) the correct answer.

Question 19
Brain storming is a group creativity exercise designed to come up with _______. (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.number of solutions to a single problem
  • B.two solutions to a single problem
  • C.three solutions to two problems
  • D.many solutions to many problems
Correct Answer: number of solutions to a single problem

The correct answer is option A.

 

Brainstorming is a group creativity technique used to generate a large number of ideas or solutions to problems. The main objective of brainstorming is to encourage free-thinking and open discussion within a group, leading to a diverse set of ideas. The emphasis is on quantity rather than quality in the initial stage, allowing for a broad exploration of possibilities. Afterward, the group can evaluate and refine the ideas generated during the brainstorming session.

Question 20
“We must forget to learn and learn forgetting” is ascribed to: (UGC NET Management Jun 2011)
  • A.Tom Peters
  • B.Peter F. Drucker
  • C.Abraham S. Maslow
  • D.Garry Hamel
Correct Answer: Tom Peters

The phrase “We must forget to learn and learn forgetting” is attributed to Tom Peters, a prominent management thinker. This statement reflects an idea that encourages organizations to adopt a mindset that is open to change and willing to challenge deeply ingrained beliefs.

 

In essence, what Tom Peters is emphasizing here is the importance of unlearning or letting go of old habits, traditional thinking, and outdated approaches in order to make room for new learning and innovation. It suggests that organizations should not only focus on acquiring new knowledge and skills but also actively shed obsolete practices and mental models that might hinder progress.

 

In a rapidly changing business environment, the ability to unlearn and adapt is crucial for staying competitive. Sometimes, organizations can become trapped in the comfort of their established routines and past successes, which can lead to complacency. Peters' statement reminds us that true learning involves a dynamic process of continuous improvement, which includes both acquiring new knowledge and letting go of old, less effective ways of doing things.

Question 21
Match List I with List II: (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)List I – ConceptsA. Entrepreneurship and InnovationB. Gaps in Value ChainsC. Think TankD. Machine LearningList II – Institution/Schemes(i) Atal Tinkering Lab(ii) Pradhan Mantri Matsya Sampada Yojana(iii) Atal Innovation Mission(iv) NITI AayogChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A-(ii), B-(iv), C-(i), D-(iii)
  • B.A-(i), B-(iv), C-(iii), D-(ii)
  • C.A-(iv), B-(iii), C-(i), D-(ii)
  • D.A-(iii), B-(ii), C-(iv), D-(i)
Correct Answer: A-(iii), B-(ii), C-(iv), D-(i)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Entrepreneurship and innovation are the objectives of Atal Innovation Mission.

 

Pradhan Mantri Matsya Sampada Yojana aims to fulfil gaps in value chains.

 

NITI Aayog is a government premier think-tank.

 

Machine Learning relates to Atal Tinkering Lab.

Question 22
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)Statement I:Patents are defined as monopoly rights which one granted by the government, for full disclosure of invention for a limited period of time that is for 20 years.Statement II:The purpose of granting patents is to encourage inventions by promoting their protection and utilization so as to contribute to the development of Industries.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

Both Statement l and Statement II are correct.

 

Statement I defines patents accurately as government-granted rights for a limited period to encourage disclosure of inventions, usually lasting for 20 years. Statement II accurately states the purpose of granting patents, which is to promote protection and utilization of inventions to foster industrial development. Therefore, the most suitable choice based on the accuracy of both statements is option (A), indicating that both statements I and II are correct.

Question 23
4 core themes of innovation are (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.recognizingthe opportunity, finding the resources, developing the venture and creating value.
  • B.finding the resources, developing the venture, recognizing the opportunity and creating value.
  • C.developingthe venture, creating value, recognising the opportunity and finding the resources.
  • D.creating the value, recognising the opportunity, developing the venture and finding the resources.
Correct Answer: recognizingthe opportunity, finding the resources, developing the venture and creating value.

Innovation involves a process that typically includes the following core themes:

 

1. Recognizing the opportunity: Identifying new possibilities or needs in the market that can be addressed through innovation.

 

2. Finding the resources: Identifying and securing the necessary resources, such as financial, human, and technological resources, to support the innovation process.

 

3. Developing the venture: Implementing and developing the innovation, which may involve designing, testing, and refining the product, service, or process.

 

4. Creating value: Ensuring that the innovation adds value, either by solving a problem, meeting a need, or providing a new and improved solution.

Question 24
“Innovation and entrepreneurship” is a book written by: (UGC NET Management Dec 2009)
  • A.Philip Kotler
  • B.C. K. Prahlad
  • C.Pradeep Khandwala
  • D.Peter F. Drucker
Correct Answer: Peter F. Drucker

The book is written by Peter F. Drucker.

Question 25
Out of the following, the examples of radical innovations are: (UGC NET Management JUN 2021)1. Personal Computers2. Frozen Yogurt3. Disposable diapers4. Overnight mail delivery5. Microwave popcornChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.2, 4 and 5 only
  • B.1, 2 and 3 only
  • C.1, 3 and 5 only
  • D.1, 3 and 4 only
Correct Answer: 1, 3 and 4 only

Radical innovation is an invention that destroys or supplants an existing business model. Unlike architectural or incremental innovation, radical innovation blows up the existing system or process and replaces it with something entirely new.

 

Statement 1, 3 and 4 are therefore the examples of radical innovation.

Question 26
Sequence the innovation adoption process that consists of 5 stages which potential consumers pass through while attempting to arrive at a decision to try or not to try an innovative product. (UGC NET Management JUN 2021)1. Consumer tries the innovation.2. Consumer undertakes a “mental trial” of the innovation.3. Consumer decides to use the innovation repeatedly.4. Consumer becomes interested in the innovative product.5. Consumer gets aware about the existence of the innovation.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.3, 1, 2, 5, 4
  • B.4, 2, 1, 3, 5
  • C.2, 4, 1, 5, 3
  • D.5, 4, 2, 1, 3
Correct Answer: 5, 4, 2, 1, 3

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Consumers go through 5 stages in the process of adopting a new product:

1. Awareness: The consumer becomes aware of the new product but lacks information about it.

2. Interest: The consumer seeks information about the new product.

3. Evaluation: The consumer considers whether trying the new product makes sense.

4. Trial: The consumer tries the new product on a small scale to improve his or her estimate of its

value.

5. Adoption: The consumer decides to make full and regular use of the new product.

Question 27
Disruptive Innovations in business are those that: (UGC NET Management JUN 2020)
  • A.createnew market by offering value products.
  • B.involve often, new technology or a new business model to offer value to the market.
  • C.displace established market leading firms, Products and alliances.
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: All the above

All these options justify the meaning of Disruptive Innovations in business.

 

“Disruption” describes a process whereby a smaller company with fewer resources is able to successfully challenge established incumbent businesses. Specifically, as incumbents focus on improving their products and services for their most demanding (and usually most profitable) customers, they exceed the needs of some segments and ignore the needs of others.

 

Entrants that prove disruptive begin by successfully targeting those overlooked segments, gaining a foothold by delivering more-suitable functionality – frequently at a lower price. Incumbents, chasing higher profitability in more-demanding segments, tend not to respond vigorously. Entrants then move upmarket, delivering the performance that incumbents’ mainstream customers require, while preserving the advantages that drove their early success.

 

When mainstream customers start adopting the entrants’ offerings in volume, disruption has occurred.

Quiz Attempt #119209

Total Questions: 20
Question 1
Arrange the Project Life Cycle phase in proper sequence from starting to end.(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. Definition phaseB. Conception phaseC. Implementation phaseD. Planning and organizing phaseE. Project clean-up phaseChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B, D, E, C
  • B.B, A, D, C, E
  • C.B, A, C, D, E
  • D.E, A, C, D, B
Correct Answer: B, A, D, C, E

The correct answer is (B) B, A, D, C, E. The Project Life Cycle consists of different phases that guide the project from its inception to its closure. Here’s the proper sequence of the phases:

 

Conception Phase (B):

This is the initial phase where the project idea is conceived, and the feasibility of the project is assessed. The goal is to identify if the project is worth pursuing.

 

Definition Phase (A):

In this phase, the project’s scope, objectives, and deliverables are clearly defined. It includes setting the project goals and developing the project charter.

 

Planning and Organizing Phase (D):

This phase involves creating detailed plans for executing the project, including defining tasks, timelines, resources, and budgets. It's crucial for organizing the project's work.

 

Implementation Phase (C):

In this phase, the plans are put into action. The project is carried out according to the project plan, and tasks are executed.

 

Project Clean-up Phase (E):

The final phase involves closing the project, finalizing all deliverables, and cleaning up the project. This may include post-project reviews, documentation, and releasing resources.

Question 2
What is the primary objective of a feasibility study?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)
  • A.To persuade investors to fund a project
  • B.To assess the historical background of a business
  • C.To uncover strength and weakness of a business idea
  • D.To outline the technical development process
Correct Answer: To uncover strength and weakness of a business idea

The correct answer is (C) To uncover the strengths and weaknesses of a business idea

The primary objective of a feasibility study is to evaluate the viability of a business idea by analyzing its strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats. This helps in determining whether the proposed project or business idea is likely to succeed and what potential challenges may arise.

Question 3
The correct sequence in a business plan can be: (UGC NET Management JUN 2020)a. Executive summaryb. Details about entrepreneurc. Marketing and economic detailsd. Financial detailse. Human resource detailsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a-b-c-d-e
  • B.b-c-e-d-a
  • C.b-c-a-e-d
  • D.a-b-e-d-c
Correct Answer: b-c-e-d-a

The correct sequence is:

b. Details about entrepreneur

c. Marketing and economic details

e. Human resource details

d. Financial details

a. Executive summary

Sometimes, the Executive Summary may also be the first step.

Question 4
Feasibility analysis is the process of determining if a business idea is viable. It consists of 4 areas of feasibility analysis. Identify the correct combination. (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.Product/service feasibility; Industry/target market feasibility; Organizational feasibility; Human resource feasibility
  • B.Industry/target market feasibility; Organisational feasibility; Human resource feasibility; Leadership feasibility
  • C.Financial feasibility; Product/service feasibility; Industry/target market feasibility; Organizational feasibility
  • D.Industry/target market feasibility; Organizational feasibility; Financial feasibility; Leadership feasibility
Correct Answer: Financial feasibility; Product/service feasibility; Industry/target market feasibility; Organizational feasibility

Feasibility analysis is the process of determining if a business idea is viable. It is the preliminary evaluation of a business idea, conducted for the purpose of determining whether the idea is worth pursuing.

 

4 major areas considered while evaluating a business idea are:

1. Product/Service feasibility

2. Industry/Target market feasibility

3. Organizational feasibility

4. Financial feasibility

Question 5
The steps involved in development of a project are given below. Arrange them in proper sequence. (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)A. Selection of business idea for a detailed analysis from the competing ideas.B. Project installation and initiation.C. Feasibility analysis.D. Identification of investment opportunity.E. Arrangements for financing.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.D, A, C, E, B
  • B.A, C, E, D, B
  • C.B, C, A, E, D
  • D.C, D, E, B, A
Correct Answer: D, A, C, E, B

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Steps involved in the Project Development in proper sequence are as follows.

1. Identification of investment opportunity

2. Selection of business idea for a detailed analysis from the competing ideas

3. Feasibility analysis

4. Arrangements for financing

5. Project installation and initiation

Question 6
The first and foremost important feature for a project to be successful is: (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.It should have a legal support
  • B.It should have adequate financing
  • C.It should have a market
  • D.It should benefit society
Correct Answer: It should have a market

The first and foremost important feature for a project to be successful is that it should have a market.

Question 7
A sound business opportunity is the result of appropriate interaction between: (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.needs of the society
  • B.capabilities of an entrepreneur
  • C.resources available in the environment
  • D.all of the above
Correct Answer: all of the above

A sound business opportunity is the result of appropriate interaction between needs of the society, capabilities of an entrepreneur and resources available in the environment. The explanation is given below.

 

(a) Need of the society (people) – Every need is a ‘non-existent’ need till it is converted into a ‘felt need’ in the society. A superb business idea will remain dormant if people do not feel its need. In case, such need is already realized by people, the job of entrepreneur becomes simpler as his job now is to fulfill the gap between market demand and supply.

 

(b) Capability of entrepreneurs – Different entrepreneurs possesses varied capabilities due to differences in family background, experience, exposure and personality traits. An entrepreneur, thus, may be more suitable business while less capable for others. Thus, the existing capabilities to entrepreneurs must be carefully matched with the required and desirable capabilities to pursue a given business opportunity.

 

(c) Resources available in the environment – Resources are the inputs required to convert ideas into business opportunity. These include finance, raw material, labour, technology, infrastructural facilities and skills. A list of resources required has to be prepared to find out those, which are existing in the environment, and to identify resources, which have to be procured.

Question 8
A formal document of what the entrepreneur intends to do to sell enough of the firm’s product or service to make a satisfactory profit is called: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.Long range plan
  • B.Strategic plan
  • C.Business plan
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Business plan

Option C is the correct answer.

 

A business plan is a written document that describes in detail how a business, usually a new one, is going to achieve its goals. A business plan lays out a written plan from a marketing, financial and operational viewpoint. Sometimes, a business plan is prepared for an established business that is moving in a new direction.

Question 9
Which one of the following is NOT a part of the industry analysis for a business plan? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.Analysis of competitors
  • B.Market segmentation
  • C.Distribution of the products/services
  • D.Industry and market forecasts
Correct Answer: Distribution of the products/services

Option C is not the part of industry analysis.

 

The industry analysis that you performed before sitting down to write your business plan can be incorporated into it to provide data on the industry and markets in which your company conducts business. Drawing upon the data you collected by using the various industry analysis resources mentioned earlier allows you to identify the risks and opportunities confronting the company as it prepares to enter the marketplace with its products or services. This information permits you to develop strategies to take full advantage of the opportunities presented to business while minimizing or avoiding the identified risks.

Question 10
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Business opportunity is an attractive project which motivates the entrepreneur to accept the project for making investment decision.Reason ‘R’:A business possibility may take the shape of business opportunity only when it improves social endowments. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.A is correct, but R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect, but R is correct.
  • C.Both A and R are correct, but R is not the right explanation of A.
  • D.Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A.
Correct Answer: A is correct, but R is incorrect.

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Assertion (A) correctly defines a business opportunity as an attractive project that motivates an entrepreneur to make an investment decision. This aligns with the typical understanding of a business opportunity.

 

A business possibility may take the shape of business opportunity even if it does not improve social endowments and purely for commercial gains. Hence, Reason (R) is incorrect.

Question 11
Business propositions are to be selected by making an analysis that, how much the local resources will be depleted in the commencement and the course of Business. This is known as: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2012)
  • A.Sensitivity Analysis
  • B.Common Property Resource use
  • C.Environmental Impact Assessment
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Environmental Impact Assessment

Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is a tool designed to identify and predict the impact of a project on the bio-geophysical environment and on man's health and well-being, to interpret and communicate information about the impact, to analyze site and process alternatives and provide solutions to sift out, or abate/mitigate the negative consequences on man and the environment.

Question 12
Match the following:List-I(a) Action Planning(b) Accountability(c) Working the Plan(d) Reviewing the ProgressList-II(i) New Actions are taken and old habits are broken.(ii) It is the periodic review of what has already been executed.(iii) It is the art of delegation to implement a business plan.(iv) Making decisions relating to the order in which the Business plan is implemented.Codes
  • A.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(iv), d-(i)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(i), b-(iv), c-(iii), d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)

Option B is the correct answer.

 

(a) Action planning - Making decisions relating to the order in which the Business Plan is implemented.

(b) Accountability - It is the art of delegation to implement a business plan.

(c) Working the Plan - New Actions are taken and old habits are broken.

(d) Reviewing the Progress - It is the periodic review of what has already been executed.

Question 13
5 steps of small business development shall occur in the order of: (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.Resource Maturity – Existence – Success – Survival – Take-off
  • B.Success – Existence – Survival – Take-off – Resource Maturity
  • C.Existence – Survival – Success – Take-off – Resource Maturity
  • D.Existence – Success – Survival –Resource Maturity – Take-off
Correct Answer: Existence – Survival – Success – Take-off – Resource Maturity

The correct answer is option (C) - Existence – Survival – Success – Take-off – Resource Maturity.

 

The stages of small business development, often associated with the life cycle of small businesses, typically occur in the following order:

 

1. Existence: The initial stage where the business is established, and efforts are focused on survival and gaining a foothold in the market.

 

2. Survival: The stage where the business seeks to overcome challenges and ensure its continued existence. Survival is a critical phase for many small businesses.

 

3. Success: As the business stabilizes and grows, it enters the success stage, where it achieves profitability and success in the marketplace.

 

4. Take-off: This stage involves significant growth and expansion, as the business takes off and captures a larger market share.

 

5. Resource Maturity: The final stage where the business focuses on managing resources efficiently and effectively, optimizing operations for long-term sustainability.

Question 14
Match the following: (UGC NET Management SEP 2013)List – I (Subject)a. Entrepreneurshipb. Marketingc. Inventory Managementd. HR PlanningList – II (Technique)1. Innovation2. Promotion Mix3. Reorder Level4. AppraisalsSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-1, b-3, c-2, d-4
  • B.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
  • C.a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1
  • D.a-4, b-2, c-3, d-1
Correct Answer: a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4

The correct match for the given pairs of Subject and Technique is:

 

a. Entrepreneurship - 1. Innovation

b. Marketing - 2. Promotion Mix

c. Inventory Management - 3. Reorder Level

d. HR Planning - 4. Appraisals

 

Therefore, correct answer is option D.

Question 15
Match the items given in List – I and List – II: (UGC NET Management DEC 2013)List – Ii. Sales Promotionii. Form of Businessiii. Budgetingiv. Exploring Market OpportunityList – IIa. Market Researchb. Financial Planc. Ownershipd. Marketing PlanCodes:
  • A.i ii iii iv
  • B.iv iii i ii
  • C.iv iii ii i
  • D.i ii iv iii
Correct Answer: iv iii ii i

a) Market Research - Market research is the process of assessing the viability of a new good or service through research conducted directly with the consumer. This practice allows a company to discover the target market and record opinions and other input from consumers regarding interest in the product. Market research may be conducted by the company itself or by a third-party company that specializes in the market research field. It can be done through surveys, product testing and focus groups.

 

b) Financial Plan - A financial plan is a comprehensive evaluation of an investor's current and future financial state by using currently known variables to predict future cash flows, asset values and withdrawal plans. Most individuals work in conjunction with a financial planner and use current net worth, tax liabilities, asset allocation, and future retirement and estate plans in developing financial plans. These metrics are used along with estimates of asset growth to determine if a person's financial goals can be met in the future, or what steps need to be taken to ensure that they are.

 

c) Ownership - Forms of business ownership vary by jurisdiction, but several common entities exist such as:

Sole proprietorship

Partnership

Corporation Cooperative

Limited liability companies (LLC)

Franchises

A company limited by guarantee

A company limited by shares

A company limited by guarantee with a share capital

 

d) Marketing Plan - A marketing plan is a business's operational document for outreach and advertising to generate leads and reach its target market. A marketing plan pulls together all the campaigns that will be undertaken over a period with additional information on how they will be measured and monitored.

Question 16
Match the items of List-I with the items of List-II regarding evaluation of project application and suggest the correct code. (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)List – Ia. Managerial Appraisalb. Economic Appraisalc. Financial Appraisald. Technical AppraisalList – IIi. Analysis of working results.ii. Disposal of factory effluents.iii. Analysis about traits of an entrepreneur.iv. Analysis on employment potential.Select the correct answer using the codesgiven below.Codes
  • A.a-i b-ii c-iv d-iii
  • B.a-ii b-i c-iii d-iv
  • C.a-iii b-iv c-i d-ii
  • D.a-iv b-iii c-ii d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii b-iv c-i d-ii

Correct match is given below.

 

Managerial Appraisal (a) involves the analysis of traits of an entrepreneur (iii).

Economic Appraisal (b) involves the analysis on employment potential (iv).

Financial Appraisal (c) involves the analysis of working results (i).

Technical Appraisal (d) involves the disposal of factory effluents (ii).

Question 17
Match the items of List – I with those of List – II. (UGC NET Management JUL 2016)List I (Projects)(a) Magnitude Oriented(b) Non-quantifiable(c) Causation Oriented(d) Factor Intensity OrientedList II (Classification)(i) Classify projects on the basis of capital intensive and/or labour-intensive projects.(ii) Classify projects on the basis of availability of demand for goods and services, raw materials, skills and/or other inputs.(iii) Level of investment is generallyused as a deciding criterion for project classification.(iv) Projects with social endowments like health, education, social welfare etc.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i

The correct match is given below.

 

(a) Magnitude oriented → (iii) Level of investment is generally used as a deciding criterion for project classification.

(b) Non-quantifiable → (iv) Projects with social endowments like health, education, social welfare, etc.

(c) Causation Oriented → (ii) Classify projects on the basis of availability of demand for goods and services, raw materials, skills, and/or other inputs.

(d) Factor Intensity Oriented → (i) Classify projects on the basis of capital intensive and/or labour-intensive projects.

Question 18
Match the items of List-I with the items of List-II and select the correct answer.List – I(i) Political and Legal Environment(ii) Demographic Environment(iii) Economic Environment(iv) Geographical and Ecological EnvironmentList – II(a) Important for industries directly depending on imports or exports.(b) Close relationship with the economic system and economic policy.(c) Related to natural resources.(d) Occupational and spatial mobilitiesof population having implications for business.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.(i)-(b), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(a)
  • B.(i)-(b), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(a), (iv)-(c)
  • C.(i)-(a), (ii)-(b), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(d)
  • D.(i)-(a), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(b), (iv)-(c)
Correct Answer: (i)-(a), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(b), (iv)-(c)

Political and Legal Environment- Important for industries directly depending on imports or exports as government policies decide how to trade between different countries.

 

Demographic Environment- Occupational and spatial mobilities of population having implications for business as demographic is related to gender, age, race and population of a particular country.

 

Economic Environment- Economic environment is related to economic policies of a particular country and helps in establishing close relationship with the economic system and economic policy.

 

Geographical and Ecological Environment- Geographical and Ecological Environment is related to natural resources which exist in a particular country.

Question 19
Which of the following are considered interlocking elements of a versatile business model? (UGC NET Management DEC 2022)a. Regulatory support and promoter experience.b. Customer value proposition.c. Financial resources and cost sheets.d. Key resources and processes.e. Profit formula.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.b, d and e only
Correct Answer: b, d and e only

The interlocking elements of a versatile business model are typically considered to be the key components that work together to create a successful and sustainable business model. Based on the given options, the most appropriate answer would be option D – b, d and e only.

Question 20
Sequence the following steps in the preparation of a versatile and seasoned business plan. (UGC NET Management DEC 2022)a. Industry and market analysis.b. Operations, marketing plan and financing.c. Company and management team profiling.d. Risk and contingency analysis.e. Executive summary.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b, d, c, e
  • B.c, b, a, d, e
  • C.e, c, a, b, d
  • D.d, a, c, b, e
Correct Answer: e, c, a, b, d

The correct sequence of steps in the preparation of a versatile and seasoned business plan is option C – e, c, a, b, d.

 

First, an executive summary should be prepared, which briefly summarizes the key components of the business plan. Then, it is essential to provide a company and management team profile, including a description of the business, mission statement, and relevant background information about the management team. An industry and market analysis follows to provide insight into the target market, industry trends, and competition. The operations, marketing plan, and financing step should then be taken to describe the day-to-day operations, marketing and sales strategies, and financial projections. Finally, a risk and contingency analysis step follows to identify potential risks and develop contingency plans.

Quiz Attempt #119210

Total Questions: 39
Question 1
Which of the following enterprises is NOT eligible for Udyog Aadhar registration with Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises, Government of India?(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)
  • A.Micro enterprise in manufacturing sector with an investment in plant and machinery of Rs 20 Lacs
  • B.Small enterprise in manufacturing sector with an investment in plant and machinery of Rs 3.5 crores
  • C.Small enterprise in services sector with an investment in equipment of Rs 1.50 crores
  • D.Medium enterprise in manufacturing sector with an investment in plant and machinery of Rs 75 crores
Correct Answer: Medium enterprise in manufacturing sector with an investment in plant and machinery of Rs 75 crores

Option D is the correct answer.

 

As notified by the Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises in June 2020, the classification criteria for micro, small, and medium enterprises are as follows:

(i) A micro enterprise is defined by an investment in Plant and Machinery or Equipment not exceeding 1 crore rupees and a turnover not exceeding 5 crores rupees.

(ii) A small enterprise is characterized by an investment in Plant and Machinery or Equipment not exceeding 10 crore rupees and a turnover not exceeding 50 crore rupees.

(iii) A medium enterprise is identified by an investment in Plant and Machinery or Equipment not exceeding 50 crore rupees and a turnover not exceeding 250 crore rupees.

Question 2
Industrial Policy of which year contained for the very first time a special thrust on measures for promoting and strengthening small tiny and village enterprises? (UGC NET Management Jun 2011)
  • A.1956
  • B.1991
  • C.1948
  • D.1977
Correct Answer: 1977

The correct answer is option (D) - 1977.

 

The 1977 policy gave the highest priority to the small scale and tiny industries. It also announced to establish a separate cell in the Industrial Development Bank of India (now IDBI) to cater to the need of the small industries. It emphasized more attention to marketing, standardization, quality control, etc

Question 3
Which of the following are construed for government intervention to support entrepreneurship and small firms? (UGC NET Management DEC 2022)a. Stimulate demand and new venture creation in the emerging sectors.b. Decentralised asset ownership and people participation.c. Help firms to adopt new technology to avoid market failure.d. Supporting women participation in business and high-tech firms.e. Export promotion and currency stabilisation.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.b, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and d only

The answer is option C i.e., a, c and d only.

 

Stimulating demand and new venture creation in emerging sectors, helping firms adopt new technology to avoid market failure, and supporting women participation in business and high-tech firms are all measures that governments can take to support entrepreneurship and small firms.

 

Decentralized asset ownership and people participation, as well as export promotion and currency stabilization, are not directly related to government intervention to support entrepreneurship and small firms.

Question 4
Which is NOT a socio-economic rationale for promoting SSI in India? (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.Export Promotion
  • B.Employment Generation
  • C.Offering competition to large scale industry
  • D.Labour intensive
Correct Answer: Offering competition to large scale industry

The correct answer is option (C) - Offering competition to large scale industry.

 

The promotion of Small-Scale Industries (SSI) in India is typically driven by various socio-economic rationales. Let's briefly discuss the options:

 

(A) Export Promotion: Encouraging SSI can contribute to export promotion by developing small enterprises that manufacture goods for international markets.

 

(B) Employment Generation: One of the primary socio-economic rationales for promoting SSI is to generate employment opportunities, especially in regions where large-scale industries might be limited.

 

(C) Offering competition to large scale industry: This is NOT a socio-economic rationale. Instead, it implies a competitive relationship between small and large-scale industries. The focus of promoting SSI is usually on complementing, rather than competing with, large-scale industries.

 

(D) Labour Intensive: Promoting labor intensive industries, often found in small-scale enterprises, can be a socio-economic rationale as it contributes to employment and skill development.

Question 5
To gain sustainable competitive advantage in low-cost manufacturing, Indian businesses are expected to: (UGC NET Management JUN 2021)1. Reduce production cost, sacrifice profits and advertise more2. Support MSMEs, to strengthen the supply chain3. Adopt product differentiation and focus more on innovations4. Bridge trust deficit and gain support from the public, workers and policy markersChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.1 and 2 only
  • B.2 and 3 only
  • C.1, 2 and 3 only
  • D.2, 3 and 4 only
Correct Answer: 1, 2 and 3 only

The correct answer is indeed option (C) - 1, 2, and 3 only.

 

(1) Reduce production cost, sacrifice profits, and advertise more (Option 1): This is a strategy for gaining a competitive advantage in low-cost manufacturing. By reducing production costs, companies can offer competitive prices, and advertising can help create awareness and attract customers.

 

(2) Support MSMEs, to strengthen the supply chain (Option 2): Supporting Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) can enhance the overall efficiency and resilience of the supply chain. This is crucial for sustaining competitive advantage, especially in manufacturing where a robust supply chain is essential.

 

(3) Adopt product differentiation and focus more on innovations (Option 3): While low-cost manufacturing is important, sustainable competitive advantage may also come from product differentiation and innovation. This allows businesses to offer unique products or features that set them apart from competitors.

Question 6
Marketing Support/Assistance to MSMEs for Bar code allows: (UGC NET Management JUN 2020)
  • A.Reimbursement of 80% of the onetime registration fees and 80% of the annual recurring fees for first three year paid by MSMEs to GST India for bar coding.
  • B.Reimbursement of 75% of the onetime registration fees only paid by MSMES to GS1 India for bar-coding.
  • C.Reimbursement of 75% of the recurring fees for first 3 years paid by MSMEs to GS1 India for bar-coding.
  • D.Reimbursement of 75% of the onetime registration fees and 75% of the annual recurring fees for the first three year paid by MSMEsto GS1 India for bar coding.
Correct Answer: Reimbursement of 75% of the onetime registration fees and 75% of the annual recurring fees for the first three year paid by MSMEsto GS1 India for bar coding.

Office of the Development Commissioner (MSME) under Ministry of Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises, Government of India is the implementing agency for Marketing Support/Assistance to MSMEs (Bar Code) scheme.

 

Financial Assistance provided under the Scheme are given below.

Under Small Scale Industries – Market Development Assistance Scheme, the financial assistance is provided towards 75% reimbursement of the only one-time registration fee paid by MSEs.

Considering the difficulty of MSEs to meet the liability of the payment of annual recurring fee, 75% annual recurring fee for first three years is reimbursed to MSEs under the Marketing Assistance/Support to MSMEs (Bar Code).

Reimbursement under the scheme is 75% of the fee paid by MSEs. Any other charges like service taxes are not reimbursable under this scheme.

The 75% reimbursement of the one-time registration fee paid by MSEs to Global Standard 1 is provided to those MSEs who have got registration from GS1 India for use of Bar-Codes on or after January 2002.

Besides, 75% reimbursement of annual recurring fee paid by MSEs to Global Standard 1 (GS1) India is provided to only those MSEs who have paid the fee for the period from 1st June 2007 and thereafter.

Question 7
The MSMED Act to cover Micro, Small and Medium Industries in India was introduced in (UGC NET Management JUN 2020)
  • A.June 2006
  • B.June 2005
  • C.June 2007
  • D.August 2008
Correct Answer: June 2006

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The Micro; Small and Medium Enterprises Development (MSMED) Act was notified in June 2006 to address policy issues affecting MSMEs as well as the coverage and investment ceiling of the sector. The Act seeks to facilitate the development of these enterprises as also enhance their competitiveness.

Question 8
International Cooperation scheme under marketing promotion scheme to MSME entrepreneurs are available for what kind of activities? (UGC NET Management JUN 2020)a. Participation in international exhibitions and trade fairs.b. Giving advertisement in international trade journals.c. Participation in buyer seller meets in foreign country.d. For meeting overseas agents and negotiating business.e. For availing overseas grants and aids.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a and c only
  • B.a, b and c only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.a and d only
Correct Answer: a, c and d only

The correct answer is option C - (a), (c), and (d).

 

Under the International Cooperation scheme of the marketing promotion scheme for MSME entrepreneurs, the following activities are typically supported:

a. Participation in international exhibitions and trade fairs.

c. Participation in buyer-seller meets in a foreign country.

d. For meeting overseas agents and negotiating business.

 

These activities are designed to promote international business opportunities for MSMEs by facilitating their participation in events, meetings, and negotiations that can enhance their global presence and business networks.

Question 9
As per RBI guidelines (2008), an MSME is considered to have reached the stage of incipient sickness if the following events are triggered: (UGC NET Management DEC 2019)(a) When there are cost overruns because of delay in commencement of commercial production by more than 6 months.(b) The enterprise incurs losses for 2 years or cash loss for one year.(c) The capacity utilisation is less than 50 percent of the projectedlevel in terms of sales.(d) There is an erosion in the net worth due to accumulated cash losses to the extent of 50 % of net worth during the previous accounting year.Which one of the following is correct?Codes
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • C.(b) and (c) only
  • D.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c) only

An MSME may be treated to have reached the stage of incipient sickness/ potential sickness, if any of the following events are triggered:

(i) There is delay in commencement of commercial production by more than 6 months for reasons beyond the control of promoters and entailing cost overrun.

(ii) The company incurs losses for 2 years or cash loss for one year, beyond the accepted timeframe on account of change in economic and fiscal policies affecting the working of MSEs or otherwise.

(iii) The capacity utilization is less than 50% of the projected level in terms of quantity or the sales are less than 50% of the projected level in terms of value during a year.

Question 10
The scheme, which has been launched by the MSME Ministry to access the capabilities and credit worthiness of the Micro and Small Enterprises (MSEs), is called: (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.Performance and credit rating scheme.
  • B.Zero defect zero effect certification.
  • C.Performance and economic rating scheme.
  • D.Technology upgradation scheme.
Correct Answer: Performance and credit rating scheme.

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises is implementing a Plan Scheme titled “Performance and Credit Rating Scheme” with the objective to provide a trusted third party opinion on the capabilities and creditworthiness of the MSEs and to create awareness amongst them about the strengths and weakness of their existing operations.

 

Ratings under the scheme is being carried out through empanelled rating agencies i.e. CRISIL, CARE, ONICRA, SMERA, ICRA, Brickwork Ratings and India Ratings. Under this Scheme, rating fee payable by the micro & small enterprises is subsidized for the first year only and that is subject to maximum of 75% of the fee or Rs. 40000/-, whichever is less.

Question 11
The cooperative bank came into existence with the enactment of the Co-operative Credit Societies Act, 1912. Which among the following does not come under the structure of co-operative bank? (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.State Co-operative Bank
  • B.Land Development Bank
  • C.Regional Rural Bank
  • D.Primary Agricultural Credit Societies
Correct Answer: Regional Rural Bank

Option C is the correct answer.

Question 12
Which of the following were 2 major criteria for the first official definition of small-scale industry coined in the year 1950? (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.The size of gross investment in fixed assets and the strength of the work force
  • B.The size of gross investment in fixed assets and the annual turnover
  • C.The strength of the workforce and the annual turnover
  • D.The annual turnover and the annual profit
Correct Answer: The size of gross investment in fixed assets and the strength of the work force

Small scale industries were first defined in 1950. At that time, in addition to a limit on investment in fixed assets, there was also an employment stipulation. The employment condition was deleted in 1960. In 1966, the limit on investment in fixed assets was changed to a limit on investment in plant and machinery (original value) only.

Question 13
Which national institute has set up/established Centre for Research in Entrepreneurship Education and Development (CREED) with the objective to broaden the frontier of entrepreneurship research?
  • A.Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad
  • B.Entrepreneurship Development Institute of India
  • C.Delhi University
  • D.Institute of Rural Management, Anand
Correct Answer: Entrepreneurship Development Institute of India

Option B is the correct answer.

 

EDII set up the Centre for Research in Entrepreneurship Education and Development (CREED) on its campus, in the year 1997 emphasizing on research. The goal of CREED is to facilitate expansion of the boundaries of knowledge and give an identifiable thrust to the Entrepreneurship Development Movement. The focus areas of CREED include Entrepreneurship Education, Innovations in Training Techniques, Voluntary Sector: Issues and Interventions, Gender and Enterprise Development, Micro Finance and a Micro Enterprise Development and Emerging Profile of Entrepreneurship.

Question 14
Match the items of List – I with List – II: (UGC NET Management JUL 2016)List – Ia. A promotion assistance for development of Khadi.b. A scheme of fund for regeneration of traditional industries.c. Interest subsidy eligibility for all institutions registered under KVIC.List – IIi. SFURTIii. ISECiii. MDASelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-iii, b-i, c-ii
  • B.a-iii, b-ii, c-i
  • C.a-i, b-iii, c-ii
  • D.a-i, b-ii, c-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-ii

Option A is the correct answer.

 

SFURTI - Scheme of Fund for Regeneration of Traditional Industries

The objective of the Scheme of Fund for Regeneration of Traditional Industries (SFURTI) scheme is to organize traditional industries and artisans into clusters to make them competitive and provide support for their long term sustainability, sustained employment, to enhance marketability of products of such clusters. It was launched in 2005-06 by the Ministry of MSME. The Nodal Agencies include KVIC, Coir Board, IIE Guwahati, NIMSME Hyderabad, NIESBUD Noida, all MSME DIs and all DICs of State Governments.

 

ISEC - Interest Subsidy Eligibility Certificate

The Interest Subsidy Eligibility Certificate (ISEC) Scheme is an important mechanism of funding Khadi programme undertaken by khadi institutions. It was introduced to mobilise funds from banking institutions for filling the gap between the actual fund requirements and availability of funds from budgetary sources. Under the ISEC Scheme, credit at a concessional rate of interest of 4% per annum for working capital, is made available as per the requirement of the institutions. The difference between the actual lending rate and 4% is paid by the Central Government through KVIC to the lending banks.

 

MDA - MSME Market Development Assistance

As part of a comprehensive policy package for MSMEs, MSME-MDA scheme has been announced with a view to increasing the participation of unternat6iona & domestic fair and adoption of bar coding.

 

MDA is offered in 3 forms as mentioned below:

1) Participation in international exhibitions/ fairs for registered small & micro manufacturing enterprises with DI/DIC;

2) Financial assistance for using Global Standards (GS1) in bar-coding; and,

3) Recognise importance of barcoding and avail financial assistance through Office of the Development Commissioner Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (DC - MSME).

Question 15
Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 is related to:
  • A.Industrial Policy
  • B.Investment Limit
  • C.Business Opportunities
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: Investment Limit

The MSMEs are classified in terms of investment made in plant and machineries if they are operating in the manufacturing sector and investment in equipment for service sector companies.

Though the primary responsibility of promotion and development of MSMEs is of the State Governments, the center has passed an Act in 2006 to empower the sector and also has formed a Ministry (Ministry of MSMEs). It was the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development (MSMED) Act which was notified in 2006 that defined the three tier of micro, small and medium enterprises and set investment limits.

 

Under the MSME Act, 2006, Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises were earlier classified as under:

 

Enterprises

Investment in Plant & Machinery (Manufacturing)

Investment in Equipment

(Services)

Micro

Up to Rs. 25 lakhs

Up to Rs. 10 lakhs

Small

Above Rs. 25 lakhs and up to Rs. 5 crore

Above Rs. 10 lakhs and up to Rs. 2 crore

Medium

Above Rs. 5 Crore and up to Rs. 10 crore

Above Rs. 2 Crore and up to Rs. 5 crore

In May 2020, the definition of MSMEs was revised, as one of the initiatives under ‘AtmaNirbhar Bharat Abhiyan’, considering COVID-19 situation. There was a long-pending demand for revisions as low threshold in MSME definition, which had created a fear among MSMEs of graduating out of the benefits given to the sector and, hence, killing the urge to grow.

 

There were 2 major changes, which were done in May 2020, in the definition (see next table):

1. Introduction of additional criteria of turnover.

2. Distinction between manufacturing and service sector eliminated.

 

Enterprises

Manufacturing and Services

Micro

Investment less than Rs. 1 crore & Turnover less than Rs. 5 crore

Small

Investment less than Rs. 10 crore & Turnover less than Rs. 50 crore

Medium

Investment less than Rs. 50 crore & Turnover less than Rs. 250 crore

 

The new criteria is expected to bring about many benefits that will aid MSMEs to grow in size. It has also been decided that the turnover with respect to exports will not be counted in the limits of turnover for any category of MSME units whether micro, small or medium. This is yet another step towards ‘Ease of Doing Business’. This will help in attracting investments and creating more jobs in the MSME sector. The change in criteria of classifying the MSMEs is set to offer major relief to the exporters.

Question 16
Which of the following organizations is meant for promoting small-scale industries at district level? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2012)
  • A.SIDBI
  • B.DIC
  • C.SFCs
  • D.NABARD
Correct Answer: DIC

The ‘District Industries Centre’ (DICs) programme was started by the central government in 1978 with the objective of providing a focal point for promoting small, tiny, cottage and village industries in a particular area and to make available to them all necessary services and facilities at one place.

 

The District Industries Centre is the institution at the District level, which provides all the services and support facilities to the entrepreneur for setting up Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises. This included identification of suitable schemes, preparation of feasibility reports, arrangements for credit facilities, machinery and equipments, provision of raw materials and development of industrial clusters etc.

Question 17
The measure taken by Government to promote small scale industry is/are: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2012)
  • A.Provision of training facilities
  • B.Provision of marketing facilities
  • C.Arrangement of credit and raw materials
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: All the above

All of the statements are the measures taken by the Government to promote small scale industry.

Question 18
Small and medium enterprises are: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2012)
  • A.Labour intensive
  • B.Capital intensive
  • C.Market leader
  • D.Industry price determiner
Correct Answer: Labour intensive

India has supported its small sector as it has believed that these enterprises use labor-intensive methods of production, thereby generating faster employment.

Question 19
SFURTI (Scheme of fund for regeneration of traditional industries) is implemented by: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.Union Ministry of Traditional Industries
  • B.National Agricultural cooperative Marketing Federation
  • C.Federation of Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry
  • D.Union Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises
Correct Answer: Union Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises

SFURTI is Scheme of Fund for Regeneration of Traditional Industries. The Ministry of Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) had launched the Scheme (SFURTI) in the year 2005 with a view to promote cluster development. The following agencies shall be designated as the Nodal Agencies for the Scheme: (i) Khadi and Village Industries Commission (ii) Coir Board. Each Nodal Agency (NA) identifies the Implementing Agencies (IAs).

Question 20
The small-scale sector is the __________ largest employer of human resources in the country. (UGC NET Management DEC 2014)
  • A.Single
  • B.Second
  • C.Third
  • D.Fourth
Correct Answer: Second

The small-scale industry sector output contributes almost 40% of the gross Industrial value-added 45% of the total exports from India (direct as well as indirect exports) and is the second largest employer of human resources after agriculture. The development of Small Scale Sector has therefore been assigned an important role in India's national plans.

Question 21
Timely and adequate assistance and rehabilitation efforts to MSEs should begin on a proactive basis when early signs of sickness are detected. This stage is termed as: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2018)
  • A.Supporting Stage
  • B.Handholding Stage
  • C.Sustaining Stage
  • D.Recovery Stage
Correct Answer: Handholding Stage

Timely and adequate assistance to MSEs and rehabilitation effort should begin on a proactive basis when early signs of sickness are detected. This stage would be termed as ‘handholding stage’ as defined below.

 

This will ensure intervention by banks immediately after detecting early symptoms of sickness so that sickness can be arrested at an early stage. An account may be treated to have reached the ‘handholding stage’; if any of the following events are triggered:

(a) There is delay in commencement of commercial production by more than 6 months for reasons beyond the control of the promoters;

(b) The company incurs losses for 2 years or cash loss for 1 year, beyond the accepted timeframe;

(c) The capacity utilization is less than 50% of the projected level in terms of quantity or the sales are less than 50% of the projected level in terms of value during a year.

Question 22
As per the revised norms of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development (MSMED) Act 2006, the criteria of investment limit in plant and machinery for MSME falls under which one of the following category?
  • A.Micro Rs 1 Crore, Small Rs 5 crore, Medium Rs 50 crore
  • B.Micro Rs 20 lakh, Small Rs 2.5 crore, Medium Rs 5 crore
  • C.Micro Rs1 Crore, Small Rs 6 crore, Medium Rs 8 crore
  • D.Micro Rs 25 lakh, Small Rs 10 crore, Medium Rs 15 crore
Correct Answer: Micro Rs 1 Crore, Small Rs 5 crore, Medium Rs 50 crore

The MSMEs are classified in terms of investment made in plant and machineries if they are operating in the manufacturing sector and investment in equipment for service sector companies.

Though the primary responsibility of promotion and development of MSMEs is of the State Governments, the center has passed an Act in 2006 to empower the sector and also has formed a Ministry (Ministry of MSMEs). It was the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development (MSMED) Act which was notified in 2006 that defined the three tier of micro, small and medium enterprises and set investment limits.

 

Under the MSME Act, 2006, Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises were earlier classified as under:

 

Enterprises

Investment in Plant & Machinery (Manufacturing)

Investment in Equipment

(Services)

Micro

Up to Rs. 25 lakhs

Up to Rs. 10 lakhs

Small

Above Rs. 25 lakhs and up to Rs. 5 crore

Above Rs. 10 lakhs and up to Rs. 2 crore

Medium

Above Rs. 5 Crore and up to Rs. 10 crore

Above Rs. 2 Crore and up to Rs. 5 crore

 

In May 2020, the definition of MSMEs was revised, as one of the initiatives under ‘AtmaNirbhar Bharat Abhiyan’, considering COVID-19 situation. There was a long-pending demand for revisions as low threshold in MSME definition, which had created a fear among MSMEs of graduating out of the benefits given to the sector and, hence, killing the urge to grow.

 

There were 2 major changes, which were done in May 2020, in the definition (see next table):

1. Introduction of additional criteria of turnover.

2. Distinction between manufacturing and service sector eliminated.

 

Enterprises

Manufacturing and Services

Micro

Investment less than Rs. 1 crore & Turnover less than Rs. 5 crore

Small

Investment less than Rs. 10 crore & Turnover less than Rs. 50 crore

Medium

Investment less than Rs. 50 crore & Turnover less than Rs. 250 crore

 

The new criteria is expected to bring about many benefits that will aid MSMEs to grow in size. It has also been decided that the turnover with respect to exports will not be counted in the limits of turnover for any category of MSME units whether micro, small or medium. This is yet another step towards ‘Ease of Doing Business’. This will help in attracting investments and creating more jobs in the MSME sector. The change in criteria of classifying the MSMEs is set to offer major relief to the exporters.

Question 23
Under technology and quality upgradationsupport to help manufacturing MSMEs buy energy efficient technologies for production, what percentage of the actual expenditure is provided as financial support by the Government of India? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JAN 2017)
  • A.75%
  • B.60%
  • C.50%
  • D.25%
Correct Answer: 75%

Scheme for Technology and Quality Upgradation Support to Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises

The scheme is one of the ten components of the National Manufacturing Competitiveness Programme (NMCP).It focuses the two important aspects, namely, enhancing competitiveness of the MSME sector through Energy Efficiency and Product Quality Certification.

 

Components of Grant: Towards organizing the awareness programmes, the Government of India will provide financial support to the extent of 75% of the actual expenditure, subject to maximum Rs. 75,000/- per programme (Average cost of one programme is expected to be Rs. 80,000).
