The primary consideration is whether the act is driven by a genuine concern for public interest and supported by credible evidence.

Question 16
Consider the following.Assertion “A”:Corporate Governance is an important instrument of investor protection. (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)Reason “R”:Strong Corporate Governance is indispensable to resilient and vibrant capital markets.Which one of the following options is correct?
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct but R is not the right explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A

The correct answer is option (A) - Both A and R are correct, and R is the right explanation of A.

 

Assertion "A" states that Corporate Governance is an important instrument of investor protection. This is correct because Corporate Governance involves the systems and processes used by companies to ensure that they operate in a transparent, fair, and responsible manner, which is essential for protecting the interests of investors.

 

Reason "R" states that strong Corporate Governance is indispensable to resilient and vibrant capital markets. This is also correct because a well-governed corporate environment inspires investor confidence, promotes market integrity, and contributes to the efficient functioning of capital markets.

Question 17
Given below are 2 statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:The Stakeholder Model can be used as a tool for managers, who are asked to handle the stakeholders’ relations as a guide to achieve ultimate goals.Reason “R”:Corporation is an economic institution which has a social service as well as a profit-making function while shareholder control is similar to Adam Smith’s ‘invisible hand’ argument.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.“A” is correct, but “R” is incorrect.
  • B.Both “A” and “R” are correct, but “R” is not the right explanation of “A”.
  • C.Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is the right explanation of “A”
  • D.Both “A” and “R” are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is the right explanation of “A”

The correct answer is option (C) - Both "A" and "R" are correct, and "R" is the right explanation of "A."

 

The stakeholder model emphasizes that a corporation is not only an economic entity but also has social responsibilities. Managers, guided by the stakeholder model, are expected to consider and manage relationships with various stakeholders, including customers, employees, suppliers, and the community. This aligns with the idea that a corporation serves not only profit-making goals but also has a social service function.

 

The reason provides additional context, explaining that shareholder control is comparable to Adam Smith's 'invisible hand' argument. The 'invisible hand' argument, proposed by Adam Smith, suggests that individuals pursuing their own self-interest unintentionally contribute to the overall economic well-being of society. In the context of the assertion, it implies that shareholder control, focusing solely on profit-making, may not address the broader social responsibilities that corporations have, as highlighted by the stakeholder model.

Question 18
Match the items of List I with the items of List II and choose the correct answer from the code given below. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)List I(a) Cadbury Committee(b) Clause 49 of listing agreement(c) Minimum number of specified board meetings a year(d) Whistle blowingList II(i) SEBI regulation(ii) Code of best practices(iii) Ethics(iv) Companies Act, 2013Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • C.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • D.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)

Cadbury Committee came out with the report on Corporate Governance in UK (1992).

 

The first formal regulatory framework for listed companies specifically for corporate governance was established by the SEBI in February 2000, following the recommendations of Kumarmangalam Birla Committee Report. It was enshrined as Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement. Thereafter SEBI had set up another committee in 2003 under the chairmanship of Mr. N. R. Narayana Murthy, to review Clause 49, and suggest measures to improve corporate governance standards. Some of the major recommendations of the committee primarily related to audit committees, audit reports, independent directors, related party transactions, risk management, directorships and director compensation, codes of conduct and financial disclosures.

 

As per provisions of the Companies Act 2013, Every company shall hold the first meeting of the Board of Directors within 30 days of the date of its incorporation and thereafter hold a minimum number of 4 meetings of its Board of Directors every year in such a manner that not more than 120 days shall intervene between two consecutive meetings of the Board.

 

A Whistle-blower is a person who exposes any kind of information or activity that is deemed illegal, unethical, or not correct within an organization that is either private or public.

Question 19
Which one of the following is NOT a norm of Corporate Governance? (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)
  • A.Woman Independent Director
  • B.Clause 49 of listing agreement.
  • C.Disclosure norms of earning per share.
  • D.Audit committee
Correct Answer: Disclosure norms of earning per share.

Disclosure norms of earning per share is not a norm of Corporate Governance.

 

The Companies Act of 2013 mandated a certain class of companies to have at least one-woman director on board. The regulator, in compliance with the Act, made this compulsory from October 2014. Many companies inducted a woman member from their promoter families to meet the requirement. However, the mandate to have at least one woman on board still helped improve gender diversity in boardrooms, demonstrated by the increase in female directors. 

 

The audit committee plays a major role in corporate governance regarding the organisation’s direction, control, and accountability. As a representative of the board of directors and main part of the corporate governance mechanism, the audit committee is involved in the organisation’s both internal and external audits, internal control, accounting and financial reporting, regulatory compliance, and risk management.

 

Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement to the Indian stock exchange that came into effect from 31 December 2005. It has been formulated for the improvement of corporate governance in all listed companies.

Question 20
Whistle-Blowers are: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2012)
  • A.to be removed from the jobs.
  • B.to be promoted.
  • C.to be rewarded for the organizational enrichment.
  • D.to be protected since they intend to bring out truth
Correct Answer: to be protected since they intend to bring out truth

Whistle-blowers are individuals who expose or report wrongdoing, unethical behavior, or illegal activities within an organization. It is crucial to protect whistle-blowers because they play a significant role in bringing to light information that is in the public interest and can help prevent or address issues within the organization.

 

Option (D) reflects the ethical perspective that whistle-blowers should be protected for their courage in revealing the truth, and this protection can encourage others to come forward with important information without fear of reprisals.

 

The Companies Act, 2013 provides whistle-blowing mechanism and requires every listed company and other classes of companies to establish a Vigil mechanism for directors and employees to report genuine concern.

Question 21
Which of the following Committees were formed to introduce corporate governance practices in the banking sector?
  • A.Ganguly Committee
  • B.Kumar Mangalam Birla Committee
  • C.J.J. Irani Committee
  • D.Sachar Committee
Correct Answer: Ganguly Committee

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The first formal regulatory framework for listed companies specifically for corporate governance was established by the SEBI in February 2000, following the recommendations of Kumar Mangalam Birla Committee Report. It was enshrined as Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement.

 

To introduce corporate governance practices in the banking sector, a working group of directors of Banks and Financial Institutions was set up. The group named Ganguly Committee submitted its report in 2002.

In 2004, Government of India constituted an expert committee under the chairmanship of Dr. J.J Irani the then Director of Tata Sons, to review and make recommendations on Company Law.

Question 22
Which among the following corporate governance theories make pessimistic assumptions about the self-servicing motives of company executives? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2014)
  • A.Agency theory
  • B.Stakeholder theory
  • C.Stewardship theory
  • D.Resource Dependence theory
Correct Answer: Agency theory

The correct answer is option A - Agency theory.

 

Agency theory is a corporate governance theory that often makes pessimistic assumptions about the self-serving motives of company executives. It suggests that there may be a divergence of interests between the principals (shareholders) and agents (company executives or managers). According to agency theory, managers may act in their own self-interest rather than in the best interest of the shareholders, leading to the need for mechanisms and structures to align the interests of managers with those of the shareholders.

Question 23
Who has defined following concept of Corporate Governance?“Corporate Governance is defined as holding the balance between economic and social goals and between individual common goals. The governance framework is there to encourage the efficient use of resources and equally to require accountability for the stewardship of those resources”. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)
  • A.K. Keasay
  • B.Cadbury committee
  • C.J.J. Irani Committee
  • D.Ronald R. Sims
Correct Answer: Cadbury committee

Cadbury Committee On Corporate Governance, 1992: The stated objective of the Cadbury Committee was ‘to help raise the standards of corporate governance and the level of confidence in financial reporting and auditing by setting out clearly what it sees as the respective responsibilities of those involved and what it believes is expected of them’. The Committee investigated the accountability of the Board of Directors to shareholders and to the society. It submitted its report and associated ‘Code of Best Practices’ in December 1992 wherein it spelt out the methods of governance needed to achieve a balance between the essential powers of the board of directors and its proper accountability.

 

Sir Adrian Cadbury in ‘Global Corporate Governance Forum’, World Bank, 2000 stated that, “Corporate Governance is concerned with holding the balance between economic and social goals and between individual and communal goals. The corporate governance framework is there to encourage the efficient use of resources and equally to require accountability for the stewardship of those resources. The aim is to align as nearly as possible the interests of individuals, corporations and society”.

Question 24
The enforcement mechanisms followed in respect of implementation of Corporate Governance practices are indicated below. Choose any one of the mechanism which is NOT included in corporate governance practice. (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)
  • A.Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement
  • B.Directors responsibility statement, appointment of independent directors, audit committee and internal check
  • C.Corporate governance compliance certificate, audit committee report, appointment of woman director
  • D.Formulation of mission statement, appointment of a whistleblower, contents of red herring prospectus
Correct Answer: Formulation of mission statement, appointment of a whistleblower, contents of red herring prospectus

Formulation of mission statement is not related to Corporate Governance.

Question 25
CII Committee on Corporate Governance with SEBI as the Custodian of investors constituted on 7thMay 1999 is known by which one of the following?
  • A.Dr. J.J. Irani Committee
  • B.Kumar MangalamBirla Committee
  • C.Narayan Murthy Committee
  • D.Working group on the Companies Act
Correct Answer: Kumar MangalamBirla Committee

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The CII was the first to come up with a version of an audit committee. The SEBI, as the custodian of investors’ interest constituted an 18-memeber Committee, chaired by industrialist Kumar Mangalam Birla, on Corporate Governance, mainly with a view to protecting the investors’ interests. The Committee made 25 recommendations, 19 of them “mandatory”, that is, these were enforceable. The listed companies were obliged to comply with these because of the contractual obligation arising out of the listing agreement with stock exchanges.

Question 26
Which one of them was NOT a Corporate Fraud?
  • A.Satyam Case
  • B.Abdul Karim Telgi case
  • C.Saradha Chit Fund
  • D.Ketan Parikh
Correct Answer: Abdul Karim Telgi case

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Abdul Karim Telgi case is not a corporate fraud. It was a case of fake Stamp Paper.

 

The Satyam Computer Services scandal was a corporate scandal affecting India-based Company Satyam Computer Services in 2009, in which chairman Ramalinga Raju confessed that the company's accounts had been falsified.

 

The Saradha Group financial scandal was a major financial scam and alleged political scandal caused by the collapse of a Ponzi scheme run by Saradha Group, a consortium of over 200 private companies that was believed to be running collective investment schemes popularly but incorrectly referred to as chit funds in Eastern India.

 

The Ketan Parekh scam was the second most important scam that rocked the Bombay Stock Exchange after the Harshad Mehta scam. Ketan Parekh is a former stock broker from Mumbai, India, who was convicted in 2008, for involvement in the Indian stock market manipulation scam that occurred from late 1998 to 2001.

 

Harshad Mehta was an Indian stockbroker, well known for his wealth and for having been charged with numerous financial crimes that took place in the Securities Scam of 1992. It was alleged that Mehta engaged in a massive stock manipulation scheme financed by worthless bank receipts, which his firm brokered in “ready forward” transactions between banks.

Question 27
The practice of willingly hiding relevant information by being secretive and deceitful known as _________, which occur when organization punishes individual who is open and honest and rewards the one who has unethical behavior.(UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2014)
  • A.Window Dressing
  • B.Counter Norms
  • C.Stone-walling
  • D.Whistle Blowing
Correct Answer: Stone-walling

The correct answer is option (C) - Stone-walling.

 

The practice of willingly hiding relevant information by being secretive and deceitful is known as "Stone-walling." In this context, it refers to an organizational behavior where relevant information is intentionally withheld or concealed, and there is a lack of transparency. Stone-walling can occur when an organization punishes individuals who are open and honest while rewarding those who engage in unethical behavior.

 

The other options are:

 

(A) Window Dressing: This refers to presenting a favorable image or appearance, often by manipulating information or financial reports to make the organization look better than it actually is.

 

(B) Counter Norms: This term is not commonly associated with the described practice. It does not fit the context of hiding information or rewarding unethical behavior.

 

(D) Whistle-Blowing: This is the act of reporting unethical or illegal activities within an organization to external authorities. It is the opposite of stone-walling as it involves exposing information rather than hiding it.

Question 28
The term ‘Corporate Governance’ comes closest to:
  • A.Corporate Management
  • B.Corporate Administration
  • C.Corporate Planning
  • D.Corporate System
Correct Answer: Corporate System

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Corporate Governance is the system of rules, practices and processes by which a firm is directed and controlled. Corporate Governance essentially involves balancing the interests of a company’s many stakeholders, such as shareholders, management, customers, suppliers, financiers, government and the community. Since Corporate Governance also provides the framework for attaining a company’s objectives, it encompasses practically every sphere of management, from action plans and internal controls to performance measurement and corporate disclosure.

Question 29
Anglo-American Model of Corporate Governance sets top most priority to:
  • A.Business growth
  • B.Customers
  • C.Employees
  • D.Shareholders
Correct Answer: Shareholders

The correct answer is option D - Shareholders

 

The Anglo-American Model of Corporate Governance places topmost priority on shareholders. In this model, the primary goal of a corporation is to maximize shareholder value. The interests of shareholders are given paramount importance, and decisions and actions are typically directed towards enhancing the financial returns for shareholders.

Question 30
A good governance in corporate sector depends upon: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2013)
  • A.Strong political will
  • B.Transparency and accountability
  • C.Trade Union practices
  • D.Social and political responses
Correct Answer: Transparency and accountability

The correct answer is option B - Transparency and accountability.

 

Good governance in the corporate sector depends upon several factors, but among the options provided:

 

(A) Strong political will: While political will can influence the regulatory environment, corporate governance is more directly associated with the internal practices and policies of corporations.

 

(B) Transparency and accountability: This is a key factor in good corporate governance. Transparency involves openness and clarity in financial and operational disclosures, and accountability ensures that decision-makers are responsible for their actions and decisions.

 

(C) Trade Union practices: While trade unions can play a role in representing the interests of employees, they are not the sole determinant of good corporate governance.

 

(D) Social and political responses: These are external factors that can influence the business environment but may not directly determine the quality of corporate governance within a company.

Question 31
Which among the following is NOT correct with regards to Clause 49 of SEBI Act?
  • A.It came into effect from 31stDecember 2005.
  • B.Clause 49 is related to the Listing Agreement to the Indian Stock Exchange.
  • C.It desires 50 percent independent Directors.
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

Option D is the correct answer. All the options are correct.

 

As a major step towards codifying the Corporate Governance norms, SEBI enshrined the Clause 49 in the Equity Listing Agreement in year 2000, which now serves as a standard of Corporate Governance in India. With Clause 49 was born the requirement that “half the Directors on a listed company’s board must be Independent Directors”. In the same clause, the SEBI had put forward the responsibilities of the Audit Committee, which was to have a majority Independent Directors.

 

Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement is applicable to companies which wish to get themselves listed in the stock exchanges. This clause had both mandatory and non-mandatory provisions.

 

After the enactment of the new Companies Act, 2013, the SEBI amended Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement, in year 2014 to bring it into conformity with the new Act.

 

Note that Clause 49 is now subsumed under SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations 2015.

Question 32
Which of the following powers of Directors cannot be exercised without the consent of shareholders in General Meeting?
  • A.Power to make calls on shareholders
  • B.Power to borrow monies
  • C.Power to buy back its shares
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Section 179 of the Companies Act, 2013 provides the relevant provisions related to powers of Board. These are given below.

 

The Board of Directors of a company shall exercise the following powers on behalf of the company by means of resolutions passed at meetings of the Board, namely:

 

(a) to make calls on shareholders in respect of money unpaid on their shares;

(b) to authorize buy-back of securities under section 68;

(c) to issue securities, including debentures, whether in or outside India;

(d) to borrow monies;

(e) to invest the funds of the company;

(f) to grant loans or give guarantee or provide security in respect of loans;

(g) to approve financial statement and the Board’s report;

(h) to diversify the business of the company;

(i) to approve amalgamation, merger or reconstruction;

(j) to take over a company or acquire a controlling or substantial stake in another company;

(k) any other matter which may be prescribed.

Question 33
The professional having high ranking and trained to uphold the highest standard and effective operations, compliance and administration as corporate governance, is known as: (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.Directors of Company
  • B.Chairman of Company
  • C.Company Secretary
  • D.Shareholders
Correct Answer: Company Secretary

Option C is the correct answer.

 

A Company Secretary is the senior position in any public or private organization, placed at the top most level of the organization’s hierarchy i.e. at Management level. The Company Secretary is responsible for regulating and efficiently managing the financial, legal and statutory requirements. Along with that he has to comply with the corporate governance that includes the welfare of all the stakeholders of the company viz. shareholders, employees, customers, suppliers, financiers, government and the society.

 

A Director of company is a person from a group of managers who leads or supervises a particular area of a company. Companies that use this term often have many directors spread throughout different business functions or roles (e.g. director of human resources).

 

A Chairman of company is an executive elected by a company’s board of directors that is responsible for presiding over board or committee meetings. The Chairman ensures that meetings run smoothly and remain orderly, and works at achieving a consensus in board decisions. The position is different than that of the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and can be either a Non-Executive (part-time) or Executive (full-time) position.

 

A shareholder, commonly referred to as a stockholder, is any person, company, or institution that owns at least one share of a company’s stock. Because shareholders are a company's owners, they reap the benefits of the company's successes in the form of increased stock valuation. If the company does poorly and the price of its stock declines, however, shareholders can lose money.

Question 34
Governance is the system of values, policies and institutions by which a society manages its economic, political and social affairs through interactions within and among the state, civil society and private sector is defined by: (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.World Bank
  • B.UNDP
  • C.European Commission
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: UNDP

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The UNDP by means of its ‘Strategy Note on Governance for Human Development 2004’ defines ‘governance’ as the system of values, policies and institutions by which a society manages its economic, political and social affairs through interactions within and among the state, civil society and private sector.

Question 35
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Corporate behavior towards stakeholders is an important concept in practice and a central part of Corporate Governance.Reason ‘R’:It has to be ethical, legal and responsible behaviour for organization, stakeholders and society. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.Both assertion and reason are true.
  • B.Both assertion and reason are false.
  • C.Assertion is false, but reason is true.
  • D.Assertion is true, but reason is not a correct explanation of assertion.
Correct Answer: Both assertion and reason are true.

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Corporate behaviour is important for company success both financially and concerning the relationship between corporate and business interests (stakeholders). We cannot define corporate behaviour without an ethical and CSR base in order to refer to that behavioral aspect.

 

Corporate behaviour involves legal rules, ethical codes of conduct and social responsibility principles. In other words corporate behaviour is based on all of these components and involves law, ethics and CSR. It is important to recognize also that this behaviour must be ethical but must also be seen to be ethical - perceptions are very important.

 

Hence, both Assertion and Reason are true and Reason (R) is the correct explanation of Assertion (A).

Question 36
Which one of the following is NOT a principle of Corporate Governance? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.Transparency
  • B.Accountability
  • C.Feasibility
  • D.Responsibility
Correct Answer: Feasibility

The correct answer is option C – Feasibility.

 

Corporate Governance principles typically revolve around ensuring ethical, responsible, and transparent management of a company. Brief explanation of each option is given below.

 

(A) Transparency: This principle emphasizes openness, disclosure, and clear communication of information to stakeholders, ensuring that they are well-informed about the company's activities.

 

(B) Accountability: This principle holds individuals and entities responsible for their actions and decisions. It ensures that there are mechanisms in place to track and evaluate the performance of those in positions of authority.

 

(C) Feasibility: This term is not typically considered a core principle of Corporate Governance. Feasibility relates more to the practicality or viability of a project or idea, and while it is important in business decision-making, it is not a direct governance principle.

 

(D) Responsibility: This principle emphasizes the ethical and responsible conduct of the company toward its stakeholders and the broader society.

Question 37
The financial institutions have a major say in which of the following Corporate Governance Model? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2014)
  • A.Japanese Model
  • B.Anglo-American Model
  • C.German Model
  • D.Indian Model
Correct Answer: Japanese Model

Corporate Governance systems vary around the world. This because in some cases, corporate governance focuses on link between a shareholder and company, some on formal board structures and board practices and yet others on social responsibilities of corporations. Following are some of the models of corporate governance:

 

Japanese Model: This model is also called as the business network model, usually shareholders are banks/ financial institutions, shareholders, corporate with cross-shareholding. There is supervisory board which is made up of board of directors and a president, who are jointly appointed by shareholder and banks/financial institutions. This is rejection of the Japanese ‘keiretsu’- a form of cultural relationship among family controlled corporate and groups of complex interlocking business relationship, where cross shareholding is common most of the directors are heads of different divisions of the company. Outside director or independent directors are rarely found of the board.

Question 38
The Board of Directors can appoint: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT SEP 2013)(i) Additional Director(ii) Causal Director(iii) Alternative Director(iv) Nominee DirectorSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (ii) and (iii)
  • B.(ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • C.(iii), (iv) and (i)
  • D.(iv), (i) and (ii)
Correct Answer: (iii), (iv) and (i)

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Section 161 of the Companies Act, 2013 deals with the Appointment of Additional Director, Alternate Director and Nominee Director.

 

1) Additional Director: The articles of a company may confer on its Board of Directors the power to appoint any person, other than a person who fails to get appointed as a director in a general meeting, as an additional director at any time. An additional director shall hold office up to the date of the next AGM or the last date on which the AGM should have been held, whichever is earlier.

 

2) Alternate Director: The Board of Directors of a company may, if so authorized by its articles or by a resolution passed by the company in general meeting, appoint a person, not being a person holding any alternate directorship for any other director in the company, to act as an alternate director for a director during his absence for a period of not less than 3 months from. A person shall not be appointed as an alternate director for an independent director unless he is qualified to be appointed as an independent director under the provisions of this Act. An alternate director shall not hold office for a period longer than that permissible to the director in whose place he has been appointed and shall vacate the office if and when the director in whose place he has been appointed returns to India. If the term of office of the original director is determined before he so returns to India, any provision for the automatic re-appointment of retiring directors in default of another appointment shall apply to the original, and not to the alternate director.

 

3) Nominee Director: Subject to the articles of a company, the Board may appoint any person as a director nominated by any institution in pursuance of the provisions of any law for the time being in force or of any agreement or by the Central Government or the State Government by virtue of its shareholding in a Government company.

Question 39
Which of the following duties is NOT a general duty of Directors of a Company?
  • A.Duty of good faith
  • B.Duty of care
  • C.Duty to attend Board Meeting
  • D.Duty not to delegate
Correct Answer: Duty to attend Board Meeting

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Section 166 of the Companies Act, 2013 addresses the responsibilities of directors in a company:

In compliance with the Companies Act, a director must align their actions with the company's articles.

Directors are obligated to act in good faith to advance the company's objectives, benefiting its members collectively, and ensuring the best interests of the company, its employees, shareholders, the community, and environmental protection.

Directors are required to exercise their duties with due care, skill, and diligence, demonstrating independent judgment.

Directors should avoid situations where their direct or indirect interests may conflict with those of the company.

Directors must refrain from seeking undue personal gain or advantage for themselves, their relatives, partners, or associates. Any director found guilty of such actions is liable to repay the equivalent amount to the company.

Directors are not permitted to transfer their office, and any such attempt is considered void.

Violation of these provisions results in penalties, with fines ranging from 1 lakh rupees to 5 lakh rupees for directors found in contravention of Section 166.

Question 40
Consider the following.Statement (I):For the improvement in the corporate governance, the Department of Company Affairs (DCA) proposed a code of behavior for the public sector companies in the year 1998.Statement (II):After the enactment of the new Companies Act, 2013, the SEBI amended Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement, mandating, that the Board of Directors of listed entities shall have an optimum combination of executive and non-executive directors with at least 1 woman director.Code:
  • A.Statement (I) is correct but (II) is incorrect.
  • B.Statement (II) is correct but (I) is incorrect.
  • C.Both the Statements (I) and (II) are correct.
  • D.Both the Statements (I) and (II) are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Statement (II) is correct but (I) is incorrect.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

For the improvement in the corporate governance, the Department of Company Affairs (DCA) proposed the following changes in 2000 (not in 1998), among others:

a) A code of behaviour for the public sector companies

b) Proper disclosures

c) Greater role of non-executive, independent directors

d) More transparency in accounting and reporting

 

After the enactment of the new Companies Act, 2013, the SEBI through an official circular has amended Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement, mandating, that the Board of Directors of listed entities shall have an optimum combination of executive and non-executive directors with at least one woman director.

 

As per Clause 49, for a company with an Executive Chairman, at least 50 % of the board should comprise independent directors. In the case of a company with a non-executive Chairman, at least one-third of the board should be independent directors.

Question 41
Which one among the following is not correct about J. J. Irani Committee’s recommendations on Company Law (2005)? (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.2/5th of the board of a listed company should comprise of independent directors.
  • B.Introduce the concept of One Person Company (OPC).
  • C.Allow corporations to self-regulate their affairs.
  • D.Disclose proper and accurate compilation of financial information of a corporation.
Correct Answer: 2/5th of the board of a listed company should comprise of independent directors.

Option A is the correct answer.

 

With regards to independent directors, the J.J. Irani Committee on Companies Law 2005 recommended that:

 

The Committee is of the view that given the responsibility of the Board to balance various interests, the presence of Independent directors on the Board of a Company would improve corporate governance. This is particularly important for public companies or companies with a significant public interest. While directors representing specific interests would be confined to the perspective dictated by such interests, independent directors would be able to bring an element of objectivity lo Board process in the general interests of the company and thereby to the benefit of minority interests and smaller shareholders.

 

Independence, therefore, is not to be viewed merely as independence from Promoter Interests but from the point of view of vulnerable stakeholders who cannot otherwise get their voice heard. Law should, therefore, recognize the principle of independent directors and spell out their role, qualifications and liability. However requirement of presence of Independent directors may vary depending on the size and type of company. There cannot be a single prescription to suit all companies. Therefore number of Independent directors may be prescribed through rules for different categories of companies. However a definition of independent director should be incorporated in the Company law.

Question 42
Disclosure of Corporate Governance practice and its compliance has been stipulated in which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JAN 2017)
  • A.Directors’ Responsibility Statement under Section 134 of the Companies Act 2013
  • B.Auditor’s Report
  • C.C.A.G. Report
  • D.Report of the SEBI and MCA 21
Correct Answer: Directors’ Responsibility Statement under Section 134 of the Companies Act 2013

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Financial statements are prepared from companies books of accounts. The management of a company is responsible for the safekeeping of the company’s books and papers, including books of accounts. In the case of a company, the management is the Board of Directors, and therefore the directors are responsible for the safekeeping of the company’s books and papers. The Director Responsibility Statement is a brief overview of the directors’ responsibilities for the preparation of the company’s financial statements. This also includes disclosure of Corporate Governance practice and its compliance as well as Corporate Social Responsibility policy of the company.

Question 43
Kumar MangalamBirla Committee Report, Ramesh Chandra Committee Report, Cadbury Committee Report primarily focus on which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JAN 2017)
  • A.ethical issues in business practice and marketing practice
  • B.health programme of the employees in an organization
  • C.issues relating to corporate governance practice
  • D.gender issues in management and equality for all
Correct Answer: issues relating to corporate governance practice

Option C is the correct answer.

Question 44
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Bad corporate governance can cast doubt on a company’s reliability.Reasoning ‘R’:Companies that do not cooperate sufficiently with auditors can publish non-compliant financial results. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT NOV 2017)Codes
  • A.Both Assertion and Reasoning are correct and Reasoning is the right explanation of Assertion.
  • B.Both Assertion and Reasoning are correct but Reasoning is not the right explanation of Assertion.
  • C.Assertion is correct but Reasoning is incorrect.
  • D.Reasoning is correct but Assertion is incorrect
Correct Answer: Both Assertion and Reasoning are correct but Reasoning is not the right explanation of Assertion.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Assertion (A): Bad corporate governance can cast doubt on a company’s reliability.

This statement is correct. Corporate governance refers to the system of rules, practices, and processes by which a company is directed and controlled. Good corporate governance is essential for building trust among stakeholders, including investors, employees, and the general public. Bad corporate governance, on the other hand, can lead to a lack of transparency, accountability, and ethical behavior, casting doubt on the reliability of the company.

 

Reasoning (R): Companies that do not cooperate sufficiently with auditors can publish non-compliant financial results.

This statement is also correct. Auditors play a crucial role in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of a company's financial statements. If a company does not cooperate sufficiently with auditors, it may raise concerns about the integrity of the financial reporting process. Non-compliant financial results may be published if there is a lack of transparency and cooperation during the audit process.

 

However, the Reasoning is not the right explanation of the Assertion. The Assertion is a broader statement about bad corporate governance casting doubt on a company's reliability, while the Reasoning specifically focuses on the cooperation with auditors leading to non-compliant financial results. While the Reasoning is a valid point related to corporate governance, it does not fully explain the broader implications of bad corporate governance on a company's reliability. Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

Question 45
Corporate Governance mechanism should ensure that corporate executive make strategic decisions that serve the entire group of:
  • A.Environmentalists
  • B.Government officials
  • C.Suppliers
  • D.Shareholders
Correct Answer: Shareholders

One of the key responsibilities of corporate governance is to ensure that corporate executives make strategic decisions that serve the best interests of the shareholders. Shareholders are the owners of the company, and their interests include receiving a return on their investment, ensuring the long-term success of the company, and having their rights protected.

 

While it's important for a company to consider the interests of various stakeholders, including environmentalists, government officials, suppliers, and others, the primary focus of corporate governance is to align the interests of executives with those of shareholders. This is because shareholders have a financial stake in the company and are considered the ultimate owners.

 

Therefore, the corporate governance mechanism should ensure that strategic decisions are made in a manner that maximizes shareholder value and protects their interests. The correct answer is (D) Shareholders.

Question 46
Match the items of two lists, indicating the correct code:List – Ia. Transparencyb. Equityc. Sustainabilityd. AccountabilityList – IIi. All stakeholder groups have the opportunity to maintain or improve their well-being.ii. The State of being answerable for decisions and activities to all stakeholders.iii. Information freely available and directly accessible to interested parties.iv. The effect which action taken in the present has upon the options available in the future.Codes:
  • A.a-iii, b-I, c-iv, d-ii
  • B.a-I, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-ii, b-iii, c-I, d-iv
  • D.a-iii, b-I, c-ii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-I, c-iv, d-ii

a. Transparency - Information freely available and directly accessible to interested parties.

 

b. Equity - All stakeholder groups have the opportunity to maintain or improve their well-being.

 

c. Sustainability - The effect which action taken in the present has upon the options available in the future.

 

d. Accountability - The State of being answerable for decisions and activities to all stakeholders.

Question 47
Which one among the following is NOT a true statement? (UGC NET Management JUL 2018)
  • A.Accountability and transparency is not visible in less developed countries.
  • B.A disciplined and controlled corporate governance can considerably reduce financial turmoil.
  • C.A good corporate citizenship is a sort of national pride.
  • D.A good corporate governance can considerably reduce corporate frauds
Correct Answer: Accountability and transparency is not visible in less developed countries.

The correct answer is option (A) - Accountability and transparency are not visible in less developed countries.

 

Statement (A) is not a true statement. Accountability and transparency are principles that can and should be promoted in all countries, regardless of their level of development. While challenges may exist in certain regions or countries, it is not accurate to broadly state that accountability and transparency are not visible in less developed countries. Efforts are made globally to improve governance practices and promote transparency in all economies.

Question 48
Which of the following committees is related to the investor protection? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.Bhagwati Committee
  • B.N. K. Mitra Committee
  • C.J. R. Verma Committee
  • D.L. C. Gupta Committee
Correct Answer: N. K. Mitra Committee

N. K. Mitra Committee: The committee chaired by Dr. N. K. Mitra submitted its report on investor protection in April 2001.

 

Bhagwati Committee: set up in mid-1998 to recommend changes to the SEBI Takeover Regulations.

 

J. R. Verma Committee: a three-member Committee headed by Justice J.S. Verma, former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, was constituted to recommend amendments to the Criminal Law so as to provide for quicker trial and enhanced punishment for criminals accused of committing sexual assault against women.  The Committee submitted its report in January 2013.

 

L. C. Gupta Committee: SEBI appointed the L.C. Gupta Committee in November 1996 to develop appropriate regulatory framework for derivative trading and to recommend suggestive byelaws for Regulation and Control of Trading and Settlement of Derivative Contracts. the Committee was also to focus on financial derivatives and in particular equity derivatives.

Question 49
Match the items of List – I with those Lists – II and select correct answer:List – I(1) Narasimham Committee(2) Shetty Committee(3) Ghosh Committee(4) Janakiraman CommitteeList – II(a) Lending under consortium arrangement(b) Frauds and Malpractices in banks(c) Securities operations of banks and financial institutions(d) Financial system in IndiaCodes:
  • A.a-(3), b-(4), c-(2), d-(1)
  • B.a-(2), b-(3), c-(4), d-(1)
  • C.a-(4), b-(2), c-(3), d-(1)
  • D.a-(3), b-(4), c-(1), d-(2)
Correct Answer: a-(2), b-(3), c-(4), d-(1)

The Narasimham Committee was established under former RBI Governor M. Narasimham in August 1991 to look into all aspects of the financial system in India. The report of this committee had comprehensive recommendations for financial sector reforms including the banking sector and capital markets.

 

Jagannath Venkanna Shetty was an Indian Banker. He was Chairman and Managing Director of Canara Bank, Chairman of Indian Banks' Association from January 1993 - August 1994. He also headed the J. V. Shetty Banking Committee of India which decided on the crucial issue of consortium lending by Indian Banks.

 

RBI set up a high level committee on frauds and malpractices in banks under the chairmanship of Shri A. Ghosh, the then Dy. Governor, to enquire into various aspects of frauds and malpractices in banks with a view to make recommendation to reduce such incidence. The committee submitted its report in June, 1992.

 

The Janakiraman Committee, set up in the wake of the securities market irregularities of 1992 reported that there existed a thriving market for repos and virtually all wholesale participants of the money market and not only banks, used repo transactions widely despite there being an explicit prohibition on them.

Question 50
Corporate Governance is about: (UGC NET Management Jun 2011)
  • A.Crafting the strategy
  • B.Compliance with regulatory regime
  • C.Satisfying the stakeholders
  • D.Governing the company in the interest of government in power
Correct Answer: Satisfying the stakeholders

The correct answer is option (C) - Satisfying the stakeholders.

 

Corporate Governance is a framework of principles, policies, and processes by which a company is directed and controlled. The primary objective of corporate governance is to ensure that the company operates in an ethical and transparent manner that serves the interests of its stakeholders. Stakeholders include shareholders, employees, customers, suppliers, creditors, and the wider community.

Quiz Attempt #119215

Total Questions: 39
Question 1
What is the minimum prescribed net profit threshold for Companies to be required to undertake Corporate Social Responsibility activities under clause 135 of the Companies Act, 2013?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)
  • A.1% of net profit
  • B.2% of net profit
  • C.3% of net profit
  • D.5% of net profit
Correct Answer: 2% of net profit

As per provisions of Companies Act 2013, it is mandatory for the companies covered under section 135 to comply with the CSR provisions in India. Companies are required to spend a minimum of 2% of their net profit over the preceding three years as CSR.

Question 2
The method of collecting money for Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) by raising prices or following many other unethical ways is often described as: (UGC NET Management DEC 2013)
  • A.Reverse effect
  • B.Reverse Robinhood effect
  • C.Boomerang
  • D.Roosevelt effect
Correct Answer: Reverse Robinhood effect

The correct answer is (B) Reverse Robinhood effect. The term "Reverse Robinhood effect" is used to describe the unethical practice of collecting money for Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiatives, such as by raising prices or adopting other questionable means. It refers to a situation where, unlike the traditional Robinhood principle of taking from the rich to give to the poor, the company engages in actions that are counterproductive and may harm its reputation or relationships with stakeholders.

Question 3
At which stage of ethical consciousness, there is a shift in focus from ‘business’ to ‘ethics’? (UGC NET Management DEC 2014)
  • A.Corporate social responsibility
  • B.Long-term profit maximisation
  • C.Stakeholders concept
  • D.Short term profit maximisation
Correct Answer: Corporate social responsibility

The correct answer is (A) Corporate social responsibility.

 

In the context of ethical consciousness, the shift from 'business' to 'ethics' is most prominent at the stage of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR). Corporate social responsibility involves businesses integrating ethical and social considerations into their decision-making processes. It reflects a broader awareness and commitment to addressing societal and environmental concerns beyond immediate profit motives.

Question 4
Match the items of List – I with List – II and identify the code of correct matching: (UGC NET Management JAN 2017)List – I (CSR Models)a. Ethical Modelb. Statist Modelc. Liberal Modeld. Stakeholder ModelList – II (Emphasis)i. Corporate responsibilities limited to private owners.ii. Voluntary commitment by companies to public welfare.iii. State ownership and legal requirements determine corporate responsibilities.iv. Companies respond to the need of customers, communities,etcSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
  • D.a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv

The correct matching of items is option (A) - a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv.

 

a. Ethical Model - ii. Voluntary commitment by companies to public welfare.

 

The Ethical Model emphasizes companies voluntarily committing to public welfare beyond the legal requirements.

 

b. Statist Model - iii. State ownership and legal requirements determine corporate responsibilities.

 

The Statist Model suggests that corporate responsibilities are determined by state ownership and legal requirements.

 

c. Liberal Model - i. Corporate responsibilities limited to private owners.

 

The Liberal Model involves corporate responsibilities limited to private owners.

 

d. Stakeholder Model - iv. Companies respond to the need of customers, communities, etc.

 

The Stakeholder Model emphasizes that companies respond to the needs of various stakeholders, including customers and communities.

Question 5
“We must maintain in good order the property, we are privileged to use, protecting the environment and natural resources” is known as: (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)
  • A.Protecting business environment
  • B.Social responsibility of business
  • C.Maintaining good property
  • D.Protect natural resources
Correct Answer: Social responsibility of business

The correct answer is option (B) - Social responsibility of business.

 

The statement "We must maintain in good order the property, we are privileged to use, protecting the environment and natural resources" reflects the idea of the social responsibility of business. Social responsibility encompasses the ethical considerations and obligations that businesses have towards the broader society, including environmental protection and sustainable use of resources.

 

Option (A) "Protecting business environment" is not as comprehensive as the broader concept of social responsibility, which extends beyond the business environment to include the overall societal and environmental impact.

 

Option (C) "Maintaining good property" is too narrow and doesn't capture the broader ethical and environmental considerations implied in the statement.

 

Option (D) "Protect natural resources" is related to the concept, but it doesn't encompass the full scope of social responsibility, which also involves maintaining the property in good order and considering the broader environment.

Question 6
“Make use of paper bags instead of plastic bags.”It is related to: (UGC NET Management Dec 2011)
  • A.Environmental Ethics
  • B.Green Marketing
  • C.Socially Responsible Marketing
  • D.Social Marketing
Correct Answer: Socially Responsible Marketing

The correct answer is option (C) - Socially Responsible Marketing.

 

The statement "Make use of paper bags instead of plastic bags" is related to Socially Responsible Marketing. Socially Responsible Marketing involves promoting products or services in a way that considers and contributes to societal well-being. In this case, the message encourages the use of a more environmentally friendly option (paper bags) over a less environmentally friendly one (plastic bags).

Question 7
Which one of the following is NOT the social responsibility of business? (UGC NET Management Jun 2010)
  • A.Adopting village for development.
  • B.Providing drinking water and medical facilities in remote villages.
  • C.Construction of Temples.
  • D.Opening in-house R & D department.
Correct Answer: Construction of Temples.

The correct answer is option (C) - Construction of Temples.

 

Social responsibility of business typically involves activities that contribute to the well-being of society at large. Options (A), (B), and (D) all reflect activities that align with social responsibility.

Question 8
Which of the following is NOT the social responsibility of the business? (UGC NET Management Dec 2010)
  • A.Promotion of Markets
  • B.Promotion of Green Environment
  • C.Promotion of Education
  • D.Promotion of Public Health
Correct Answer: Promotion of Markets

The correct answer is option (A) Promotion of Markets.

 

The social responsibility of a business typically involves activities that contribute to the overall well-being of society beyond its economic objectives.

 

(A) Promotion of Markets: While businesses contribute to markets through their economic activities, promoting markets specifically may not be considered a social responsibility in the traditional sense. Social responsibility often involves activities directly related to societal welfare.

Question 9
On which of following principles is Andrew Carnegie’s view on Corporate Social Responsibility, as reflected in his books, “The Gospel of Wealth” based? (UGC NET Management DEC 2019)
  • A.Peter Principle
  • B.ScalerPrinciple
  • C.Charity Principle
  • D.Steward Principle
Correct Answer: Charity Principle

In 1899, Andrew Carnegie, founder of the conglomerate US Steel corporation published a book called “The Gospel of Wealth”, which set forth the classic statement of Corporate Social Responsibility. Carnegie’s view was based on the charity principle.

 

The charity principle required the more fortunate members of society to assist its less fortunate members, including the unemployed, the handicapped, the sick, and the elderly. These unfortunates could be aided either directly or indirectly, through such institutions as churches, settlement houses, and (from the 1920s onwards) the Community Chest Movement.

Question 10
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:Archie Carroll’s Model speaks of an organisations 4 most basic forms of responsibility in order of priority.Reason “R”:Economic, legal, ethical, philanthropic responsibilities and their compliance increases brand value and furthers the profit.Codes:
  • A.Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.
  • B.Both“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of“A”
  • C.Both“A”and“R”are correct, but“R”is not the right explanation of“A”.
  • D.“A”is correct, but“R”is incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of“A”

Option B is the correct answer.

 

In his 1991 article "The Pyramid of Corporate Social Responsibility," Dr. Archie B. Carroll, a business management author and professor, identifies 4 areas that make up a corporate social responsibility pyramid: legal, economic, ethical and philanthropic. This pyramid has become widely used and is meant to explain the main areas that a business's duties to its stakeholders fall under.

 

Legal: Corporations must ensure that their business practices are legal. Obeying regulations helps protect consumers, who rely on a business to be truthful about the products it sells, and investors, who stand to lose profits if a company is penalized or shut down because of illegal practices.

 

Economic: According to the 2011 book "Business Ethics," a company's economic responsibilities include being profitable in order to provide a return on investment to owners and shareholders, to create jobs in their communities and to contribute useful products and services to society. Part of being economically responsible means streamlining processes to find the most efficient ways to run your business and innovating your product offerings and marketing to increase revenue.

 

Ethical: Beyond abiding by the letter of the law, an organization's ethical responsibilities include managing waste, recycling and consumption. These areas are sometimes regulated by city, state or federal governments, but often a company can go further than what the law requests and institute policies that help sustain the environment for future generations. Other ethical responsibilities come in the form of advertising, as in not stretching the truth to a customer just to get them to make a purchase, and treatment of employees. A company can provide more than minimum wage and minimum safety precautions for employees; it can provide excellent benefits, insurance and invest resources in building a clean and safe workplace where employees will be happy to come each day.

 

Philanthropic: The authors of the 2011 "Business Ethics" also suggest that part of the philanthropic responsibility corporations face is to promote the welfare of humans and to spread goodwill. An example of this is The Xerox Foundation's "Xerox Employee Matching Gifts Program" in which Xerox matches its employees' contributions to higher education institutions up to $1,000. Similarly, the PepsiCo Foundation has committed over $2 million to World Food Program USA, which helps fight hunger in "vulnerable communities around the globe."

Question 11
Consider the following.Statement I:If the workers develop an attitude of non-cooperation with Management, a repressive economic system may be needed to set right this industrial disorder.Statement II:By fulfilling social responsibility towards shareholders, employees, consumers, government and community, a business achieves economic growth and increases public image.Codes: (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • B.Both the statements I and II are correct.
  • C.Statement II is correct but I is incorrect.
  • D.Both the statements are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct.

Both the statements I and II are correct.

 

Statement I suggest that if workers develop an attitude of non-cooperation with management, a repressive economic system may be needed to restore order in the industrial relations. This statement is correct in the context of industrial relations. When there is a breakdown in cooperation and trust between workers and management, it can lead to industrial unrest and disrupt productivity. In such situations, measures to maintain discipline and restore order may be necessary, which could include disciplinary actions or other forms of repressive measures.

 

Statement II states that by fulfilling social responsibility towards shareholders, employees, consumers, government, and the community, a business can achieve economic growth and enhance its public image. This statement is also correct. In modern business practices, there is an increasing recognition of the importance of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR). When businesses fulfill their social responsibilities by considering the interests and welfare of various stakeholders, it can contribute to their long-term success. By considering the needs of shareholders, employees, consumers, government, and the wider community, businesses can build trust, enhance their reputation, and ultimately achieve economic growth.

Question 12
Which of the following statements about CSR provision in the new Companies Bill passed in parliament is NOT true? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2014)
  • A.It is compulsory for a company to spend on CSR if its net worth is at least Rs 500 crore.
  • B.There is provision for minimum turnover of Rs 800 crore.
  • C.The net profit of at least Rs5 crore in a year is a condition for compulsory spending on CSR.
  • D.The companies have to spend 2% of its average profits of three years on corporate social responsibility.
Correct Answer: There is provision for minimum turnover of Rs 800 crore.

The Ministry of Corporate Affairs has notified Section 135 and Schedule VII of the Companies Act 2013 as well as the provisions of the Companies (Corporate Social Responsibility Policy) Rules, 2014 to come into effect from April 1, 2014.

 

With effect from April 1, 2014, every company, private limited or public limited, which either has a net worth of Rs 500 crore or a turnover of Rs 1,000 crore or net profit of Rs 5 crore, needs to spend at least 2% of its average net profit for the immediately preceding 3 financial years on corporate social responsibility activities. The CSR activities should not be undertaken in the normal course of business and must be with respect to any of the activities mentioned in Schedule VII of the 2013 Act. Contribution to any political party is not considered to be a CSR activity and only activities in India would be considered for computing CSR expenditure.

Question 13
Gandhianconcept of social responsibility is denoted by which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)
  • A.Social commitment concept
  • B.Trusteeship concept
  • C.Sustainable development concept
  • D.Welfare concept
Correct Answer: Trusteeship concept

The Gandhian Principle of Trusteeship is closely related to the “Social Responsibility of Business”. According to the Gandhian Concept of Trusteeship “All business firms must work like a trust.” All assets of the firm must be held by a ‘trust’ and must be used for the welfare of the social .The firm must keep only a small part of its profits for the honorable livelihood of its owners .The remaining part of the profit must be distributed equitably to all sections of society.

Question 14
As per Indian Companies Act, 2013, a qualified Indian Company is required to contribute at least 2% of its net average profit towards Corporate Social Responsibility. In which of the following situations the company is required to follow the provisions? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)
  • A.Company’s net worth is Rs 100 crores or more.
  • B.Company’s net worth is Rs 500 crores or more.
  • C.Company’s net worth is Rs 1,000 crores or more.
  • D.Company’s net worth is Rs 2,000 crores or more.
Correct Answer: Company’s net worth is Rs 500 crores or more.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

With effect from April 1, 2014, every company, private limited or public limited, which either has a:

net worth of Rs 500 crore or more; or

a turnover of Rs 1,000 crore or more; or

net profit of Rs 5 crore or more,

 

needs to spend at least 2% of its average net profit for the immediately preceding 3 Financial Years on corporate social responsibility activities. The CSR activities should not be undertaken in the normal course of business and must be with respect to any of the activities mentioned in Schedule VII of the 2013 Act. Contribution to any political party is not considered to be a CSR activity and only activities in India would be considered for computing CSR expenditure.

Question 15
CSR is important because: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.It influences all aspects of Company’s operation.
  • B.It gives company's mission and strategy.
  • C.It increases the general affluence and societal expectation.
  • D.All of the Above
Correct Answer: All of the Above

Option D is the correct answer.

 

CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility) is important for several reasons, and all the options listed are valid:

 

(A) It influences all aspects of Company’s operation: CSR is not limited to one aspect of a company's operation. It encompasses a wide range of practices and initiatives that consider the social, environmental, and ethical impacts of business activities.

 

(B) It gives the company's mission and strategy: CSR is often integrated into a company's mission and strategy. Companies define their commitment to social responsibility as part of their overall business objectives.

 

(C) It increases the general affluence and societal expectation: CSR contributes to the general affluence of society by addressing social and environmental issues. It also raises societal expectations for businesses to operate responsibly and ethically.

Question 16
Which of the following is a principle of CSR?
  • A.Protecting Environment
  • B.Avoiding price discrimination
  • C.Adopting the labour policies
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Correct answer is option D – All of the Above.

 

CSR stands for Corporate Social Responsibility, and it refers to a company's commitment to operating in an economically, socially, and environmentally sustainable manner. The options provided align with different aspects of CSR:

 

(A) Protecting Environment: This is a key principle of CSR, as companies are increasingly expected to minimize their environmental impact, promote sustainability, and engage in environmentally friendly practices.

 

(B) Avoiding price discrimination: Price discrimination is not directly related to CSR. CSR typically focuses on ethical, social, and environmental responsibilities, while price discrimination is more related to pricing strategies.

 

(C) Adopting labor policies: Ensuring fair labor practices, providing safe working conditions, and respecting human rights are important components of CSR. This aligns with the principle of adopting responsible labor policies.

Question 17
Which of the following is related to initiatives taken by an organization to reduce carbon footprints?
  • A.Corporate policy towards sustainability
  • B.Corporate governance of an organization
  • C.Social responsibility of an organization
  • D.Corporate values of an organization
Correct Answer: Social responsibility of an organization

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is option A - Corporate policy towards sustainability.

 

Initiatives taken by an organization to reduce carbon footprints are typically related to its corporate policy towards sustainability. Corporate sustainability involves integrating environmental, social, and economic considerations into business operations to ensure that the organization operates in a responsible and sustainable manner.

 

Corporate policy towards sustainability: This choice directly addresses the efforts and strategies adopted by an organization to minimize its environmental impact, including actions to reduce carbon footprints.

Question 18
The 4 types of social responsibility include: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2014)
  • A.Legal, Philanthropic, Economic and Ethical
  • B.Ethical, Moral, Social and Economic
  • C.Philanthropic, Justice, Economic and Ethical
  • D.Legal, Moral, Ethical and Economic
Correct Answer: Legal, Philanthropic, Economic and Ethical

Option A is the correct answer.

 

In his 1991 article "The Pyramid of Corporate Social Responsibility," Dr. Archie B. Carroll, a business management author and professor, identifies four areas that make up a corporate social responsibility pyramid: legal, economic, ethical and philanthropic. This pyramid has become widely used and is meant to explain the main areas that a business's duties to its stakeholders fall under:

 

1. Legal: Corporations must ensure that their business practices are legal. Obeying regulations helps protect consumers, who rely on a business to be truthful about the products it sells, and investors, who stand to lose profits if a company is penalized or shut down because of illegal practices.

 

2. Economic: According to the 2011 book “Business Ethics,” a company’s economic responsibilities include being profitable in order to provide a return on investment to owners and shareholders, to create jobs in their communities and to contribute useful products and services to society. Part of being economically responsible means streamlining processes to find the most efficient ways to run your business and innovating your product offerings and marketing to increase revenue.

 

3. Ethical: Beyond abiding by the letter of the law, an organization’s ethical responsibilities include managing waste, recycling and consumption. These areas are sometimes regulated by city, state or federal governments, but often a company can go further than what the law requests and institute policies that help sustain the environment for future generations. Other ethical responsibilities come in the form of advertising, as in not stretching the truth to a customer just to get them to make a purchase, and treatment of employees. A company can provide more than minimum wage and minimum safety precautions for employees; it can provide excellent benefits, insurance and invest resources in building a clean and safe workplace where employees will be happy to come each day.

 

4. Philanthropic: The authors of the 2011 “Business Ethics” also suggest that part of the philanthropic responsibility corporations face is to promote the welfare of humans and to spread goodwill. An example of this is The Xerox Foundation's "Xerox Employee Matching Gifts Program" in which Xerox matches its employees' contributions to higher education institutions up to $1,000. Similarly, the PepsiCo Foundation has committed over $2 million to World Food Program USA, which helps fight hunger in "vulnerable communities around the globe."

Question 19
The principles to be followed for corporate social responsibility are: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT SEP 2013)
  • A.Involvement of stakeholders.
  • B.Maintaining transparency in reporting.
  • C.Independent verification of policies and outcome.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is Option D - All of the above.

 

The principles to be followed for corporate social responsibility (CSR) encompass various aspects, and all the options provided are generally considered important:

 

(A) Involvement of stakeholders: CSR involves considering the interests and concerns of all stakeholders, including employees, customers, communities, and others. Engaging stakeholders helps in understanding their needs and expectations.

 

(B) Maintaining transparency in reporting: Transparency is a key principle in CSR. Companies are expected to openly communicate their CSR activities, goals, and outcomes to build trust and accountability with stakeholders.

 

(C) Independent verification of policies and outcome: Having independent verification or third-party assessments of CSR policies and outcomes can add credibility to a company's CSR efforts. It provides an objective evaluation and assurance that the company is meeting its stated goals.

Question 20
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is looked as the organized network of making long economic and social relationship of the corporate with the society. But a business of which type, as mentioned below, cannot afford for it, at thefirst instance? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.Large Business
  • B.Medium Business
  • C.Small Business
  • D.A Business Start-up
Correct Answer: A Business Start-up

A business start-up cannot afford to invest in CSR activities at the first instance because, during the early period of a business, the companies are struggling to secure finances to run their day-to-day activities and trying to reach break-even. At this point, a start-up is not in a state to spend money on CSR activities.

Question 21
Who among the following has not given a model on Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)? (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.Walker
  • B.Friedman
  • C.Ackerman
  • D.Carroll
Correct Answer: Walker

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Ackerman Model emphasizes on the internal policy goals and their relation to the CSR. According to this Model, the 4 stages involved in CSR include:

1. Managers of company getting to know the most common social problem and then express a willingness to take a particular project which will solve some social problems.

2. Intensive study of the problem by hiring experts & getting their suggestions to make it operational.

3. Managers take up the project actively and work hard.

4. Evaluating the project by addressing the issues.

 

Carroll’s Pyramid Model of CSR

It was Carroll who had stated that individual responsibilities and obligations in different fields are finally summarized into the totality of CSR The pyramid model, which is based on such totality of CSR, comprises four very different aspects, i.e., legal, economic, ethical, and philanthropic.

 

Liberal Model

This approach was encapsulated by the American economist Milton Friedman, who in 1958 challenged the very notion of corporate responsibility with the idea that companies are solely responsible to their owners (Friedman, 1971). As argued in this model, it is sufficient for a business to obey the law and generate wealth, which through taxation and private charitable choices can be directed to social ends. This ultimately fulfils the social responsibility of an organization towards the community and the nation.

Question 22
What among the following is meant to assess the performance of a business in the field of social responsibility? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)
  • A.Social accounting
  • B.Social responsibility accounting
  • C.Social audit
  • D.Social accounting index
Correct Answer: Social audit

A Social Audit is a way of measuring, understanding, reporting and ultimately improving an organization’s social and ethical performance.

Question 23
Some of the driving forces behind the evolution of corporate social responsibility are: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)(a) Concerns and expectations from citizens, public authorities, and investors.(b) Decisions made by individuals and institutions influenced by the criteria of foreign trade.(c) Concerns about the impact of economic activities on the production houses.(d) Increased transparency of business activities because of the development in information technology.Codes
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(a) and (c)
  • C.(a) and (d)
  • D.(b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a) and (d)

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The correct option is option C - (a) and (d).

 

(a) Concerns and expectations from citizens, public authorities, and investors are driving forces behind the evolution of corporate social responsibility. This is because stakeholders, including citizens, government authorities, and investors, increasingly expect businesses to consider and address social and environmental concerns.

 

(d) Increased transparency of business activities because of the development in information technology is also a driving force behind corporate social responsibility. As information technology advances, businesses are under greater scrutiny, and there is an increased demand for transparency in their activities, leading to a focus on social responsibility.

Question 24
As per the Companies Act, 2013 a qualified Indian company is required to contribute at least 2% of its average net profit towards corporate social responsibilities activities. In which of the following situations the company is required to follow the provisions?
  • A.Turnover of the company is Rs 100 crore or more
  • B.Turnover of the company is Rs500 crore or more
  • C.Turnover of the company is Rs 1,000 crore or more
  • D.Turnover of the company is Rs 2,000 crore or more
Correct Answer: Turnover of the company is Rs 1,000 crore or more

The Companies Act 2013 (Companies Act) has introduced several new provisions regarding Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR). Section 135 of the Companies Act provides the threshold limit for applicability of the CSR to a Company i.e.

(a) net worth of the company to be Rs 500 crore or more;

(b) turnover of the company to be Rs 1000 crore or more;

(c) net profit of the company to be Rs 5 crore or more.

 

Further as per the CSR Rules, the provisions of CSR are not only applicable to Indian companies, but also applicable to branch and project offices of a foreign company in India.

 

Every qualifying company requires spending of at least 2% of its average net profit for the immediately preceding 3 financial years on CSR activities. Further, the qualifying company will be required to constitute a committee (CSR Committee) of the Board of Directors (Board) consisting of 3 or more directors. The CSR Committee shall formulate and recommend to the Board, a policy which shall indicate the activities to be undertaken (CSR Policy); recommend the amount of expenditure to be incurred on the activities referred and monitor the CSR Policy of the company. The Board shall take into account the recommendations made by the CSR Committee and approve the CSR Policy of the company.

Question 25
3 levels of corporate social responsibility of business are denoted by which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)
  • A.natural environment, market economy, voluntary action
  • B.ethical values, work culture, participation
  • C.market force, mandated action, voluntary actions
  • D.healthy competition, good corporate business, voluntary action
Correct Answer: market force, mandated action, voluntary actions

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is option C - market force, mandated action, voluntary actions.

 

The 3 levels of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) of business are often denoted by the following:

 

1. Market Force: This refers to CSR activities that are driven by market dynamics and the demand from customers, stakeholders, and the broader market. Companies may engage in socially responsible practices to meet the expectations of consumers and gain a competitive advantage.

 

2. Mandated Action: This level involves CSR activities that are required or mandated by laws and regulations. Governments may enforce certain social and environmental responsibilities on businesses to ensure compliance with legal standards and ethical norms.

 

3. Voluntary Actions: These are CSR initiatives that companies undertake voluntarily, going beyond legal requirements and market demands. Businesses may engage in philanthropy, sustainability efforts, and other socially responsible activities because they believe it is the right thing to do or because it aligns with their values and corporate mission.

Question 26
Which among the following is NOT associated with social responsibility of business enterprise? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)
  • A.Caux Round Table
  • B.Transparency International
  • C.Global reporting initiative
  • D.Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
Correct Answer: Transparency International

Option B is the correct answer. Transparency International India is not associated with social responsibility of business enterprise.

 

The Transparency International India (TII) is a leading non-political, independent, non-governmental anti-corruption organization of India. TII has extensive expertise and understanding of issues of corruption in India.
