The Caux Round Table is an international organization of senior business executives aiming to promote ethical business practice. It was founded in 1986 by Frits Philips, president of Philips.

 

The Global Reporting Initiative is an international independent standards organization that helps businesses, governments and other organizations understand and communicate their impacts on issues such as climate change, human rights and corruption. It was founded in 1997.

 

The mission of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) is to promote policies that will improve the economic and social well-being of people around the world.

Question 27
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Social audit has been defined as a commitment to systematic assessment of and reporting in some meaningful, definable domain of the company's activities that have social impacts.Reasons ‘R’:The Companies Act 2013 has accorded statutory recognition of thesocial responsibility of a corporate entity and gives option to provide a percentage of profit for the purpose as per discretion of the board. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2015)
  • A.Both Assertion and Reasoning are correct, and Reasoning is the right explanation of Assertion.
  • B.Both Assertion and Reasoning are correct, but Reasoning is not the right explanation of Assertion.
  • C.Assertion is correct but Reasoning is not correct.
  • D.Reasoning is correct but Assertion is not correct.
Correct Answer: Assertion is correct but Reasoning is not correct.

Option C is the correct answer.

 

As per Boweni, Social Audit has been defined as “A commitment to systematic assessment of and reporting on some meaningful, definable domain of a company’s activities that have a social impact”.

 

As per Companies Act, 2013, every company, private limited or public limited, which either has a net worth of Rs 500 crores or a turnover of Rs 1,000 crores or net profit of Rs 5 crores, needs to spend at least 2% of its average net profit for the immediately preceding three financial years on corporate social responsibility activities.

Question 28
Social responsibility of business while appropriating natural resources by a corporate entity has been recommended in which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JAN 2017)
  • A.Montreal Protocol of 1987
  • B.Millennium Development Goals 2008
  • C.Sustainable Development Goals 2015 in Global Sustainability Report
  • D.UNDP Human Development Report
Correct Answer: Sustainable Development Goals 2015 in Global Sustainability Report

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were launched at the UN Sustainable Development Summit in New York in September 2015. The SDGs embrace a universal approach to the sustainable development agenda. They explicitly call on business to use creativity and innovation to address development challenges and recognize the need for governments to encourage sustainability reporting.

Question 29
‘The continuing commitment by business to behave ethically and contribute to economic development while improving the quality of life of the workforce and their families as well as of the local community and society at large.’This may be attributed rightly to which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JAN 2017)
  • A.ethical responsibility of business
  • B.corporate social responsibility
  • C.commitment towards employee welfare
  • D.compliance with the provisions of the Plantation Workers Act
Correct Answer: corporate social responsibility

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The World Business Council for Sustainable Development in its publication Making Good Business Sense by Lord Holme and Richard Watts, used the following definition “Corporate Social Responsibility is the continuing commitment by business to behave ethically and contribute to economic development while improving the quality of life of the workforce and their families as well as of the local community and society at large”.

Question 30
Which one among the following is NOT a part of Corporate Social Initiatives? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT NOV 2017)
  • A.Socially-responsible business practices
  • B.Corporate social marketing
  • C.Cause-related marketing
  • D.Corporate ambience building
Correct Answer: Corporate ambience building

The correct answer is option D - Corporate ambience building.

 

Corporate Social Initiatives typically involve activities and programs that contribute to social and environmental well-being. Let's briefly explain each option:

 

(A) Socially-responsible business practices: This involves integrating ethical and socially responsible considerations into business operations. It includes practices such as sustainable sourcing, fair labor practices, and environmentally-friendly operations.

 

(B) Corporate social marketing: This refers to using marketing techniques to promote behavior that has a positive impact on society. For example, campaigns encouraging health awareness or environmental conservation.

 

(C) Cause-related marketing: Involves the association of a company's products or services with a specific social cause, often through marketing campaigns. The company may donate a portion of sales to the cause.

 

(D) Corporate ambience building: This is not typically considered a part of Corporate Social Initiatives. "Corporate ambience building" is a term that might be related to creating a positive work environment within a company, but it doesn't directly align with the typical understanding of corporate social responsibility or initiatives directed at external societal or environmental issues.

Question 31
Which among the following are also called Corporate Social Responsibility? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT NOV 2017)(a) Corporate Conscience(b) Corporate Citizenship(c) Responsible BusinessCodes
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(a), (b) and (c)
  • C.(a) and (c)
  • D.(b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c)

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is also called corporate conscience, corporate citizenship, social performance, or sustainable responsible business/ Responsible Business.

 

CSR is a form of corporate self-regulation integrated into a business model. CSR policy functions as a built-in, self-regulating mechanism whereby a business monitors and ensures its active compliance with the spirit of the law, ethical standards, and international norms.

Question 32
Consider the following.Statement I:The Classical Economical Model (CSR) –It is believed that an invisible hand promoted public welfare.Statement II:The Socio-Economic Model (CSR) – Business is seen as on sub-system among many in a highly interdependent society. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)Select the correct answer using thecodes given below.Codes
  • A.I is correct but II is incorrect.
  • B.II is correct but I is incorrect.
  • C.Both I and II are correct.
  • D.Both I and II are incorrect
Correct Answer: Both I and II are correct.

The correct answer is option C - Both I and II are correct.

 

Statement I: The Classical Economic Model (CSR) – It is believed that an invisible hand promoted public welfare.

 

This statement refers to the classical economic perspective, often associated with economists like Adam Smith. The "invisible hand" is a metaphor for the self-regulating nature of a free market economy, where individuals pursuing their own self-interest unintentionally contribute to the overall well-being of society. This concept is consistent with the classical economic model.

 

Statement II: The Socio-Economic Model (CSR) – Business is seen as one sub-system among many in a highly interdependent society.

 

This statement reflects the socio-economic perspective on Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR). In this view, businesses are considered as part of a larger social system, and their responsibilities extend beyond economic considerations to include social and environmental impacts. This perspective acknowledges the interdependence between businesses and society.

Question 33
Match the items of List – I with List– II with regard to models of Corporate Social Responsibility. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)List – I (Proponent)(a) Mahatma Gandhi(b) Jawaharlal Nehru(c) Milton Friedmen(d) Edward FreemanList – II (Emphasis and Models)(i) Voluntary commitment by companies to public welfare. (Ethical Model)(ii) State ownership and legal requirements determine corporate responsibilities. (Statist Model)(iii) Corporate responsibilities limited private owners. (Liberal Model)(iv) Companies respond to the needs of stakeholders. (Stakeholder Model)Codes:
  • A.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(iv), d-(i)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii)
  • D.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)

Ethical Model

This model was developed under the influence of Mahatma Gandhi and, hence, finds its seat in the early 20th century. The pressure on Indian industrialists to demonstrate their commitment to social development increased during the independence movement, when Mahatma Gandhi developed the notion of trusteeship, whereby the owners of property would voluntarily manage their wealth on behalf of the people

 

Static Model

This model is based on the state-owned Public Sector Units (PSUs). It is based on the socialist and Nehruvian mixed economy format that India had adopted for its economy. Propounded by Jawaharlal Nehru, this model calls for state ownership and legal requirements of CSR. The PSUs provide housing and schools to workers.

 

Liberal Model

This is the liberal approach where the belief is that the free market would take care of corporate responsibility. It is drawn from Milton Friedman’s view, which states that a company’s responsibility lies mainly in improving the economic bottom-line and increasing the shareholder. It is sufficient for the corporate to obey the law and generate wealth, which can be directed towards social ends through fiscal policy and charitable choices.

 

Stakeholder Model

The stakeholder model is often associated with R. Edward Freeman, whose seminal analysis of the stakeholder approach to strategic management in 1984 brought stake holding into the mainstream of management literature (Freeman, 1984). The rise of globalization has brought with it a growing consensus that with increasing economic rights, the range of social obligations of businesses is also growing. This, therefore, gave rise to the stakeholder model of corporate responsibility.

Question 34
The “Polluters must pay”principle is commonly accepted practice that those who produce pollution should bear the cost of managing it to prevent damage to human health or the environment. This principle was adopted in: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2018)
  • A.1996 Manila Declaration
  • B.2002 Kyoto Declaration
  • C.1992 Rio Declaration
  • D.2007 Paris Declaration
Correct Answer: 1992 Rio Declaration

The polluter pays principle is deeply rooted in legal systems but it came to be explicitly discussed in relation to environmental harms by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development in the 1970s and 80s.

 

Finally, in 1992, it was adopted by the international community in Principle 16 of the Rio Declaration.

 

Principle 16 of the Rio Declaration states, “Polluters should, in principle, bear the cost of pollution”

In India, the Polluter Pays principle made an important impact in the famous MC Mehta Oleum Gas Leak case. In this judgment, the Supreme Court laid down the rule of absolute liability which essentially states that a person would be wholly responsible for any mishap caused by their “hazardous or inherently dangerous” enterprise, which in this case was a chlorine plant. The apex court noted that the polluter’s liability would depend on their ability to pay – thus using the principle to both clean up the environmental damage and to punish the polluter.

Question 35
Match the following: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT SEP 2013)List – I(a) Work ethics(b) Values(c) Environmental responsibility of a business(d) Corporate Social ResponsibilityList – II(i) includes taking care of issues like air and water pollution, toxic waste disposal etc.(ii) is an organization’s obligation to benefit society in ways that transcend the prime business objectives of maximizing profit.(iii) is a characteristic attitude of a group towards what constitutes the morality of work.(iv) determine the overall personality of an individual and the organization that he is working for.Select the correct answer using the codes givenbelow.Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(ii), d-(i)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(ii)

Option C is the correct answer.

 

a) Work ethics – The belief that work has a moral benefit and an inherent ability to strengthen character. Work ethics involve such characteristics as honesty and accountability. Essentially, work ethics break down to what one does or would do in a particular situation.

b) Values – Important and lasting beliefs or ideals shared by the members of a culture about what is good or bad and desirable or undesirable. Values have major influence on a person’s behavior and attitude and serve as broad guidelines in all situations. Some common business values are fairness, innovation and community involvement.

c) Environmental responsibility of a business – Under the Environmental Responsibility of the Corporates, it is expected to operate in a manner that protects the environment. In other words, environmental CSR aims to reduce any damaging effects on the environment from your business' processes. Activities may focus on- energy use, water use, waste management, recycling, emissions, eco-friendly office and business travel policies. Some of these are significant from both environmental and financial point of view.

d) Corporate Social Responsibility – It is an organization’s obligation to benefit society in ways that transcend the prime business objectives of maximizing profit. CSR, also called corporate sustainability, sustainable business, corporate conscience, corporate citizenship, conscious capitalism, or responsible business.

Question 36
Consider the following. (UGC NET Management SEP 2013)Assertion ‘A’:The poor compliance to environmental regulations is attributed to tax enforcement despite regulatory framework.Reasoning ‘R’:The Government is not capable of enforcing full compliance.
  • A.A is correct and R is the right explanation of A.
  • B.A and R both are correct, but R is not the right explanation of A.
  • C.A is correct, but R is not correct.
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are incorrect.

Correct answer is option D. Both the assertion and reasoning are incorrect.

 

The Assertion (A) incorrectly links poor compliance to environmental regulations with tax enforcement. Environmental regulations and tax enforcement are typically separate areas of regulation, and compliance issues in one area do not necessarily correlate with non-compliance in the other.

 

The Reasoning (R) states that the government is not capable of enforcing full compliance. This is a broad and sweeping statement that may not be universally true. The capability of the government to enforce compliance can vary, and it is not accurate to make a blanket statement that the government is incapable of enforcing full compliance.

Question 37
Environmental issues can be managed by (UGC NET Management DEC 2012)
  • A.Investing in environment friendly process or products.
  • B.Managing environmental regulations.
  • C.Investing in environmental performance improvement.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is option (D) - All of the above.

 

All the provided options are valid ways to manage environmental issues:

 

(A) Investing in environment-friendly processes or products: This involves incorporating technologies, processes, or products that have a lower environmental impact, reducing the overall ecological footprint.

 

(B) Managing environmental regulations: Adhering to and managing compliance with environmental regulations is essential for organizations to ensure they meet legal requirements and contribute to environmental sustainability.

 

(C) Investing in environmental performance improvement: This involves actively working to enhance the overall environmental performance of the organization, which may include initiatives such as energy efficiency, waste reduction, and pollution prevention.

Question 38
The Gaia hypothesis was propounded in 1999 by: (UGC NET Management JUN 2015)
  • A.James Lovelock.
  • B.Friedman.
  • C.Lord Keynes.
  • D.Jean - Jacques Rousseau
Correct Answer: James Lovelock.

The Gaia hypothesis was propounded by James Lovelock.

 

The Gaia hypothesis, also known as the Gaia theory, was formulated by James Lovelock, a British independent scientist, in the late 1960s and formally presented in his book “Gaia: A New Look at Life on Earth,” published in 1979. The hypothesis suggests that the Earth functions as a self-regulating, complex system that maintains conditions suitable for life. Lovelock named his theory after Gaia, the ancient Greek goddess of the Earth. The Gaia hypothesis has had a significant influence on ecological and environmental thinking.

Question 39
Consider the following.Assertion (A):When a Corporation acts ethically and socially responsible in its business decisions and strategic planning, then the corporation will be more sustainable.Reason (R):Socially responsible corporate behaviour is increasingly seen as essential to long-term survival of companies. (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation
  • B.Both (A) and (R) are true but (R) is not the correct explanation
  • C.(A) is true, but (R) is false
  • D.(A) is false, but (R) is true
Correct Answer: Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation

The correct answer is option (A) - Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation.

 

Assertion (A) is true. Ethical and socially responsible behaviour can contribute to the long-term success and sustainability of a corporation. It helps in building trust with stakeholders, improving the company's reputation, and avoiding legal and reputational risks.

 

Reason (R) is also true and provides the correct explanation for the assertion. There is a growing recognition in business and academia that social responsibility is not just a moral obligation but also a strategic necessity for the sustainable survival of companies. Stakeholders, including customers, investors, and the community, are placing increasing importance on ethical and socially responsible business practices.

Quiz Attempt #119216

Total Questions: 40
Question 1
Given below are two statements:(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)Statement I:To exist and be successful in a competitive world a businesshas tobe ethical.Statement II:An ethical organisation can be recognizedon the basis ofits corporate excellence and not on its relations with the stakeholders.In light ofthe above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II arc incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectbut Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectbut Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I iscorrectbut Statement II is incorrect

The correct answer is option C i.e., "Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.

 

Statement I correctly asserts that ethics are important for a business to exist and succeed in a competitive world. Ethical practices can enhance a company's reputation, build trust among customers and stakeholders, and contribute to long-term sustainability.

 

Statement II, however, is incorrect. An ethical organization can be recognized not only through corporate excellence but also through its relationships with stakeholders. An ethical organization can be recognized on the basis of its corporate excellence and its relation to the stakeholders it follows: corporate governance, a set of rules that govern the administration and management of companies. Its goalposts are transparency, integrity, full disclosure of financial and non-financial information, and protection of stakeholders' interests. These tenets are as much ethical practice as they are part of corporate governance. It is for these reasons that value-based management and practice of ethics have become imperatives in corporate governance now, and in the foreseeable future. If values are the bedrock of any corporate culture, ethics are the foundation of authentic business relationships.

Question 2
Which one of the following is not the view of ethics among the following of views?(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)
  • A.Utilitarian view of ethics
  • B.Rights view of ethics
  • C.Theory of justice view of ethics
  • D.Non-integrative social view
Correct Answer: Non-integrative social view

The non-integrative social view is not one of the commonly recognized views of ethics. The other options – utilitarian view, rights view, and theory of justice view – are established ethical perspectives that provide frameworks for evaluating and making ethical decisions.

Question 3
Which one of the following normative ethical theories has “Net benefit from the decision” as consideration in ethical decision making?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Ethics of duty
  • B.Theory of justice
  • C.Stockholder ethics
  • D.Utilitarianism
Correct Answer: Utilitarianism

The correct answer is option D - Utilitarianism.

 

Utilitarianism is a normative ethical theory that emphasizes the greatest overall net benefit or utility as the basis for making ethical decisions. In utilitarianism, ethical action is the one that maximizes happiness, pleasure, or well-being for the greatest number of people while minimizing harm. Therefore, considering the "Net benefit from the decision" is a central consideration in ethical decision-making according to utilitarianism.

Question 4
The utilitarian view of ethics is one of the fewperspectiveon business ethics and it includes(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)A. Respecting and protectingindividualsliberties and privilegesB. Imposing and enforcing rules fairly and impartiallyC. Ethical decision made solely on the business basis of their outcomes or consequencesD. Encourages efficiency and productivity and is consistent with goal of profit maximizationE. Ethical decisions be learned on existing norms in industries and communities
  • A.A, E only
  • B.C, D only
  • C.B, C only
  • D.D, E only
Correct Answer: C, D only

The most appropriate answer is (B) C, D only

 

Option C reflects the utilitarian view of ethics, which emphasizes ethical decisions based on their outcomes or consequences.

Option D aligns with the utilitarian perspective by emphasizing efficiency, productivity, and profit maximization as ethical goals.

Question 5
The sequential stages of moral development in business organisations are characterised by:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)
  • A.Conceptualised disposition, consistency and harmony, principled oriented
  • B.Consistency and harmony, conceptualised disposition, principled oriented
  • C.Principled oriented, conventional and preconventional
  • D.Preconventional, conventional, principled oriented
Correct Answer: Preconventional, conventional, principled oriented

Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development offer a sequential progression through different levels of ethical understanding.

 

At the initial stage, known as the preconventional level, morality is perceived as externally controlled, with individuals adhering to rules to avoid punishment or gain rewards. This level comprises two stages: the punishment/obedience orientation, where behavior is influenced by fear of consequences, and the instrumental purpose orientation, where behavior is driven by personal gain.

 

Moving to the conventional level, individuals prioritize conformity to social rules, seeking approval from others and striving to maintain social order. This level includes the good boy/nice girl orientation, where behavior is guided by the desire for social approval, and the law and order orientation, where individuals adhere to societal laws to uphold social harmony.

 

Finally, at the postconventional or principled level, moral reasoning transcends societal norms, focusing instead on abstract principles and universal values. Here, individuals consider individual rights and ethical principles that apply universally, even if they conflict with societal rules. This level encompasses the social contract orientation, where individual rights take precedence, and the universal ethical principle orientation, where decisions are guided by self-chosen ethical principles rooted in conscience and applicable to all situations.

Question 6
“Work Diversity” by nature, does not go against Ethics. But an executive assistant while getting transferred from “stores” to “despatch” section created turmoil in the office. He is: (UGC NET Management JUN 2012)
  • A.Most ethical in his deal
  • B.Fully against work ethics
  • C.He is workaholic
  • D.A Rigid employer, hard nut to crack
Correct Answer: Fully against work ethics

The correct answer is option (B) - Fully against work ethics.

 

The situation described involves an executive assistant creating turmoil in the office while getting transferred from the "stores" to the "despatch" section. This disruption suggests that the executive assistant's behaviour is not aligned with work ethics. Work ethics typically involve principles of honesty, integrity, professionalism, and cooperation.

 

In this context, causing turmoil during a transfer could be considered unprofessional and disruptive, going against the principles of work ethics. Option (B) "Fully against work ethics" reflects this understanding of the situation.

Question 7
Ethical Management is: (UGC NET Management JUN 2012)
  • A.A Compromise
  • B.A Compulsion
  • C.A Judgement
  • D.(A) and (B)
Correct Answer: A Judgement

The correct answer is option (C) - A Judgement.

 

Ethical Management involves making judgments about what is right and wrong in business practices. It requires leaders and managers to consider moral principles and values when making decisions that affect the organization and its stakeholders. Ethical management goes beyond mere compliance with laws and regulations; it involves making choices that align with ethical standards and contribute to the well-being of individuals and society.

Question 8
Corporate business ethics is ________ norms and pattern that spring from organizational view of good and bad, right and wrong. (UGC NET Management DEC 2013)
  • A.Social
  • B.Behavioural
  • C.Institutional
  • D.Individual
Correct Answer: Behavioural

Option B is the correct answer.

Question 9
Consider the following. (UGC NET Management AUG 2016)Statement I:Corporate values seen to ensure a consistency of conduct across the entire organisation.Statement II:Business ethics can provide the general guidelines within which management can operate.Select the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.I and II both are incorrect
  • B.I and II both are correct
  • C.I is correct II is incorrect
  • D.I is incorrect II is correct
Correct Answer: I and II both are correct

The correct answer is option (B) - I and II both are correct.

 

Statement I: Corporate values seen to ensure a consistency of conduct across the entire organization.

This statement is correct. Corporate values are principles or beliefs that guide the behavior of individuals within an organization. When corporate values are well-defined and upheld, they contribute to a consistency of conduct across the entire organization.

 

Statement II: Business ethics can provide the general guidelines within which management can operate.

This statement is also correct. Business ethics provides a framework of principles and guidelines that guide ethical decision-making and behaviour within an organization. It sets the standards for how individuals and entities should conduct themselves in the business environment.

Question 10
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:According to David Fritzsche, business ethics is the process of evaluating decisions, either pre or post, with respect to the moral standards of society.s culture. (UGC NET Management DEC 2015)Reason ‘R’:Managers need not evaluate the moral dimensions of a decision before making it, because they are to carry out the order of the higher authority to maximise commercial gain for the entity.Codes
  • A.Both A and R are correct.
  • B.A is correct and R is the right explanation of A.
  • C.A is correct but R is not the right explanation of A.
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect.
Correct Answer: A is correct but R is not the right explanation of A.

The correct answer is option (C) - A is correct but R is not the right explanation of A.

 

Assertion ‘A’ states that business ethics is the process of evaluating decisions, either pre or post, with respect to the moral standards of society's culture. This statement is generally true. Business ethics involves considering the moral implications of decisions and actions within the context of societal standards.

 

Reason ‘R’ states that managers need not evaluate the moral dimensions of a decision before making it, as they are to carry out the order of the higher authority to maximize commercial gain for the entity. This statement is not a valid explanation for Assertion 'A.' The reason provided does not support or explain why business ethics involves evaluating decisions based on moral standards. In fact, it seems to contradict the idea of considering moral standards in decision-making by suggesting that managers should prioritize commercial gain without ethical evaluation.

Question 11
The study of moral principles or values that determine whether actions are right or wrong and outcomes are good or bad refers to following: (UGC NET Management Dec 2011)
  • A.Quality
  • B.Ethics
  • C.Opinions
  • D.Controls
Correct Answer: Ethics

The correct answer is option (B) - Ethics.

 

The study of moral principles or values that determine whether actions are right or wrong and outcomes are good or bad is referred to as "Ethics." Ethics is a branch of philosophy that deals with questions about what is morally right or wrong.

 

Option (A) "Quality" is not directly related to the study of moral principles; it typically refers to the standard or degree of something.

 

Option (C) "Opinions" are subjective expressions of beliefs and may not necessarily involve the systematic study of moral principles.

 

Option (D) "Controls" generally pertains to mechanisms or measures used to manage or regulate something and is not directly related to the study of moral principles.

Question 12
Match List – I with List – II: (UGC NET Management Dec 2011)List – I (Terms relating to ethics)I. Ethical ClimateII. Ethical RelativismIII. Ethical UniversalismIV. Ethical ConvergenceList – II (Conceptual description of terms relating to ethics)1. Each society’s view of ethics must be considered legitimate and ethical.2. There are basic moral principles that transcend cultural and political boundaries3. People pick-up subtle hints and clues that tell them what behaviour is approved and what is forbidden.4. There are growing pressures on international business to follow the same rules in managing ethical behaviour and social responsibilitySelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.I-3, II- 1, III- 2, IV- 4
  • B.I-1, II-3, III- 2, IV- 4
  • C.I- 1, II-4, III-3, IV- 2
  • D.I-4, II- 1, III-2, IV-3
Correct Answer: I-3, II- 1, III- 2, IV- 4

Option A is the correct answer.

 

I. Ethical Climate - 3. People pick-up subtle hints and clues that tell them what behaviour is approved and what is forbidden.

 

II. Ethical Relativism - 1. Each society’s view of ethics must be considered legitimate and ethical.

 

III. Ethical Universalism - 2. There are basic moral principles that transcend cultural and political boundaries.

 

IV. Ethical Convergence - 4. There are growing pressures on international business to follow the same rules in managing ethical behaviour and social responsibility.

Question 13
Which of the following is NOT related to business ethics? (UGC NET Management Dec 2010)
  • A.Social responsibility of business
  • B.Environmental ethics
  • C.Ecological consciousness
  • D.Profiteering
Correct Answer: Profiteering

The correct answer is option (D) - Profiteering.

 

Business ethics involves principles and values that guide the conduct of individuals and organizations in the business world. Let's look at each option:

 

(A) Social responsibility of business: This is related to business ethics, as it involves businesses acting in ways that benefit society beyond their economic obligations.

 

(B) Environmental ethics: This is related to business ethics, as it involves ethical considerations related to the environment and sustainable practices.

 

(C) Ecological consciousness: This is related to business ethics, as it implies awareness and responsibility towards ecological considerations.

 

(D) Profiteering: This term generally refers to making excessive profits, often in an unethical or exploitative manner. While profit-making is a legitimate goal for businesses, profiteering, especially if it involves unethical practices, can be considered against business ethics.

Question 14
Environmental Ethics refers to: (UGC NET Management Jun 2009)
  • A.Unfair Trade Practices.
  • B.Pollution.
  • C.Product price.
  • D.Quality of the product
Correct Answer: Pollution.

The correct answer is option (B) Pollution.

 

Environmental Ethics refers to the ethical considerations and principles related to the interactions between human activities and the natural environment. It involves the moral responsibility of individuals, organizations, and societies towards the environment. The key focus of Environmental Ethics is on sustainable practices, conservation, and minimizing harm to the ecosystem.

 

Therefore, the most relevant aspect related to Environmental Ethics among the given options is (B) Pollution.

Question 15
Members of organizations are increasingly finding themselves facing situations in which they are required to define right and wrong conduct. It is most aptly called as following: (UGC NET Management Jun 2011)
  • A.Environmental issues of ethics
  • B.Social responsibilities of business
  • C.Corporate governance & ethics
  • D.Ethical Dilemmas of business
Correct Answer: Ethical Dilemmas of business

The correct answer is option (D) – Ethical Dilemmas of business.

 

When members of organizations find themselves facing situations in which they are required to define right and wrong conduct, it is most aptly referred to as "Ethical Dilemmas of business." An ethical dilemma is a situation where individuals must choose between conflicting moral principles, and the right course of action may not be clear.

Question 16
Arrange the following steps of a simple ethics programme: (UGC NET Management Jun 2011)I. Walk the talkII. Size up your company’s current ethicsIII. Train your peopleIV. Solicit feedback from your employeesV. Create a code of conductSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.V, I, IV, II, III
  • B.II, V, IV, III, I
  • C.II, V, III, IV, I
  • D.II, IV, III, II, I
Correct Answer: II, V, III, IV, I

The correct arrangement of the steps of a simple ethics program is option (C) - II, V, III, IV, I.

 

II. Size up your company’s current ethics: Before implementing changes, it's important to assess the current state of ethics within the organization.

 

V. Create a code of conduct: Developing a code of conduct is a foundational step that outlines the ethical standards and expectations for everyone in the organization.

 

III. Train your people: Providing ethical training to employees is crucial to ensure they understand the values and principles expected in the workplace.

 

IV. Solicit feedback from your employees: Gathering feedback from employees helps in understanding their perspectives and concerns, which can inform improvements to the ethics program.

 

I. Walk the talk: This step usually involves leading by example, demonstrating ethical behaviour at all levels of the organization.

Question 17
Which of the following are the sources of ethical problems in organizations? (UGC NET Management DEC 2022)a. Failure of personal character.b. Organisational goals Vs. Social values.c. psychological egoism and rationalism.d. Virtue and common good conflict.e. Conflict of personal values and organizational goals.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.a, b and e only
  • D.b, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

The correct answer is C, which means that failure of personal character, organizational goals vs. social values, and conflict of personal values and organizational goals are the sources of ethical problems in organizations. This implies that the personal values and beliefs of individuals may conflict with the goals and values of the organization they work for, leading to ethical dilemmas. Additionally, there may be a conflict between the goals of the organization and the broader societal values, leading to ethical issues. Failure of personal character, such as unethical behaviour, can also contribute to ethical problems within the organization.

Question 18
The Business Code of Conduct provides guidance to managers and employees: (UGC NET Management Dec 2010)
  • A.when they encounter an ethical dilemma.
  • B.for improving their technical skills.
  • C.for pursuing their business goals.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: when they encounter an ethical dilemma.

The correct answer is option (A) - when they encounter an ethical dilemma.

 

The Business Code of Conduct is a set of guidelines and principles that provides ethical standards and expectations for managers and employees within an organization. Its primary purpose is to guide behaviour in situations where individuals may encounter ethical dilemmas or challenging situations.

 

Option (A) "when they encounter an ethical dilemma" accurately reflects the main purpose of a Business Code of Conduct. It helps individuals navigate complex ethical situations by providing a framework for making ethical decisions.

Question 19
Match the following approaches of moral reasoning with their Propounder(s). (UGC NET Management DEC 2019)List-I (Moral Reasoning)(a) Consequentialism Approach(b) Deontological Approach(c) Natural Law Theory(d) Theological ApproachList-II (Propounder(s))(i) Thomas Hobbes, Ayow Rand(ii) Aristotle(iii) Ronald F. White(iv) W.D. Ross, John RawlsChoose your answer from the following options:
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(iii), (d)-(ii)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(iii), (d)-(ii)

Consequentialism approach, given by Thomas Hobbes and A. Rand, says whether an act is morally right depends only on consequences as opposed to the circumstances or the intrinsic nature of the act or anything that happens before the act.

 

W. D. Ross, John Rawls were an important proponents of the Deontological approach to ethics in the first half of the 20th century. He rejected the utilitarian view that actions are made right simply by the goodness of their consequences, arguing instead that certain kinds of actions are prima facie right or wrong simply because of the kinds of acts they are. For example, we should keep a promise simply because we have made it, or show gratitude toward a benefactor simply because of the service that we have received.

 

Natural Law Theory of Ethics, propounded by Ronald F. White, is ultimately based on the idea that “life is a gift from God” and that “What is natural is good”. Moral rules based on natural law, like the dictates of science, are portrayed as objective and existing independent of personal, social, or cultural beliefs. Natural law theory (or naturalism) is often invoked in support of divine command theory, secular humanism in the Western Enlightenment tradition, and even evolutionary biology.

 

Theological approach, given by Aristotle, has as an essential component or assumption the premise that what gods or God wishes or commands is what we should be or do. If God commands us to love our neighbours, that is what we should do; but if God commands us to kill one or more individuals, then that is what we should do. Theological ethics subscribes to the divine command theory of morality, which holds that the ultimate basis of moral rightness is what God/the gods wishes us to do.

Question 20
Which of the following laydown Universal Ethical principles for Multinationals? (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)(a) The United Nations Declaration of Human Rights(b) The OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises(c) The Caux Roundtable Principles of BusinessSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(b) and (c) only
  • C.(a) and (c) only
  • D.(a), (b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c)

The correct answer is option (D) - (a), (b) and (c).

 

The United Nations Declaration of Human Rights (a): The UN Declaration of Human Rights provides a set of universal ethical principles that emphasize the importance of human rights, dignity, and equality. Multinational enterprises are expected to adhere to these principles in their operations.

 

The OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises (b): The OECD Guidelines provide a framework for responsible business conduct by multinational enterprises. They cover areas such as human rights, labor, environment, and anti-corruption. These guidelines aim to ensure that businesses operate ethically and contribute to sustainable development.

 

The Caux Roundtable Principles of Business (c): The Caux Roundtable Principles provide a set of ethical guidelines for businesses. They focus on principles such as moral capitalism, responsible business leadership, and stakeholder engagement. These principles aim to promote ethical behavior and responsible business practices.

 

Therefore, all three options (a), (b), and (c) lay down universal ethical principles for multinationals. The correct answer is (D) (a), (b) and (c).

Question 21
An act in a way that results in the greatest good for the greatest number is:
  • A.The golden rule
  • B.The utilitarian principle
  • C.The four way test
  • D.Kant’s categorical imperative
Correct Answer: The utilitarian principle

Utilitarianism is a theory of morality, which advocates actions that foster happiness and oppose actions that cause unhappiness. Utilitarianism promotes "the greatest amount of good for the greatest number of people." When used in a socio-political construct, utilitarian ethics aims for the betterment of society as a whole.

Question 22
Consider the following statements:Statement I:The science of ethics is a normative science.Statement II:Normative sciences judge the value of the facts in terms of an idea; concerned with judgements of ‘what ought to be’ but not with factual judgements. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT NOV 2017)
  • A.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.
  • B.Statement II is correct but Statement I is incorrect.
  • C.Both the Statements I and II are incorrect.
  • D.Both the Statements I and II are correct.
Correct Answer: Both the Statements I and II are correct.

Option D is the correct answer. Both statements are correct.

 

Statement I:

This statement is correct. Ethics is considered a normative science because it deals with the study of what ought to be, guiding principles, and moral values. It prescribes norms and standards for human behaviour.

 

Statement II:

This statement is also correct. Normative sciences, including ethics, focus on making value judgments about what ought to be, rather than providing factual descriptions of what is. They are concerned with prescribing norms and standards based on certain ideals or principles.

Question 23
Deontological theory of ethics is concerned with which of the following? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)(a) Duty ethics(b) Obligation ethics(c) Rule based ethics(d) Classical ethicsSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(a) and (c)
  • C.(a) and (d)
  • D.(a), (b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

In moral philosophy, deontological ethics or deontology is the normative ethical theory that the morality of an action should be based on whether that action itself is right or wrong under a series of rules and principles, rather than based on the consequences of the action.

 

(a) Duty ethics: Deontological ethics is often referred to as duty ethics because it emphasizes the moral obligation or duty to perform certain actions. Individuals following this ethical perspective believe in acting in accordance with their duties and moral principles, regardless of the consequences.

 

(b) Obligation ethics: The term "obligation ethics" is not a commonly used term in ethical philosophy. However, it aligns with the deontological perspective because deontology emphasizes moral obligations and duties.

 

(c) Rule-based ethics: Deontological ethics is also described as rule-based ethics because it involves adhering to specific rules and principles. In this ethical framework, certain actions are deemed inherently right or wrong based on established rules, irrespective of the outcomes.

Question 24
Utilitarianism theory of ethics refers to which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT NOV 2017)
  • A.Welfare
  • B.Duty
  • C.Obligation
  • D.Rules
Correct Answer: Welfare

Utilitarianism i.e. ethics of welfare is based on consequential approach and on the concept of welfare. Utility means capacity in action to have good results i.e. usefulness. Accordingly actions are not good or bad in themselves but only in what they are good or bad for utility means happiness and an action would be right if it leads to maximization of happiness or minimization of unhappiness and one can take a decision based on this principle. It has to be a sum total of human happiness which needs to be maximized and not simply our own individual happiness. It is called greatest happiness principal which majority feel happy.

Question 25
Which one of the following of ‘Immanuel Kant’s Principle’, known as categorical imperatives, is a guide to managerial action? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2015)
  • A.The managers should be open to share his corporate secrets, individual traits with external agencies.
  • B.The managers be free and open to share individual knowledge and experience for community's gain.
  • C.A person’s action is ethical only if that person is willing for that same action to be taken by everyone who is in a similar situation.
  • D.A person always treats another human being simply as a means to an end.
Correct Answer: A person’s action is ethical only if that person is willing for that same action to be taken by everyone who is in a similar situation.

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Option C reflects Immanuel Kant's formulation of the categorical imperative, a fundamental principle in his ethical philosophy. Kant's categorical imperative is a universal principle that guides moral decision-making. In the context of managerial action, this principle suggests that an action is ethical only if one is willing for that same action to be taken by everyone in a similar situation.

 

In a managerial context, this means that decisions and actions should be guided by principles that could be applied universally without contradiction. It encourages managers to consider whether the rules and principles they follow are suitable for everyone and do not lead to inconsistencies or conflicts when applied universally.

Question 26
Teleology in ethics supports which one of the following the most? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2015)
  • A.It is duty-based ethics and measures whether an action is right or wrong.
  • B.It measures whether the results of the actions are right or wrong.
  • C.It focuses on purpose of each action and judges the consequences of an action.
  • D.It focuses on neutrality and fidelity of an action.
Correct Answer: It focuses on purpose of each action and judges the consequences of an action.

Consequentialism: An action is morally right if the consequences of that action are more favorable than unfavorable. Consequentialist normative principles require that we first tally both the good and bad consequences of an action. Second, we then determine whether the total good consequences outweigh the total bad consequences. If the good consequences are greater, then the action is morally proper. If the bad consequences are greater, then the action is morally improper. Consequentialist theories are sometimes called teleological theories, from the Greek word telos, or end, since the end result of the action is the sole determining factor of its morality.

Question 27
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Deontology is duty-based ethics. It is an approach to ethics that addresses whether the motives behind certain action are right or wrong.Reason ‘R’:Deontology focuses on whether the results of the actions are rightor wrong. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2015)
  • A.Both A and R are correct
  • B.A is correct and R is the right explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is not right explanation of A
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect
Correct Answer: A is correct but R is not right explanation of A

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Assertion is correct.

Deontology is indeed a duty-based ethical theory that emphasizes the inherent rightness or wrongness of actions based on adherence to moral duties and principles. It focuses on the motives behind actions rather than solely on the consequences.

 

Reason does not provide the correct explanation of Assertion.

The reason provided is not an accurate explanation of deontology. Deontology is distinct from consequentialist ethical theories (such as utilitarianism) that focus on the outcomes or results of actions. Deontology, on the other hand, places primary importance on the inherent nature of actions and whether they align with moral duties, irrespective of the consequences.

Question 28
There is a provision in the Companies Act, 2013 regarding related party transactions to ensure ethical standards in managerial decisions. From the following options identify who is not a related party as per the Companies Act, 2013. (UGCNET MANAGEMENT DEC 2015)
  • A.A person on whose advice, directions or instructions (except given in professional capacity) a director or manager is accustomed to act.
  • B.A private company in which a director or manager is a director or holds along with his relatives less than 2% of its paid up share capital.
  • C.A firm in which a director, manager or his relative is a partner.
  • D.A holding/subsidiary or associatecompany, subsidiary's subsidiary and such person as would be prescribed.
Correct Answer: A private company in which a director or manager is a director or holds along with his relatives less than 2% of its paid up share capital.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

As per companies Act 2013, the Section 2(76) defines “Related Party” with reference to a company:

i) a director or his relative;

ii) a key managerial personnel or his relative;

iii)a firm, in which a director, manager or his relative is a partner;

iv) a private company in which a director or manager is a member or director

v) a public company in which a director or manager is a director or holds along with his relatives, more than 2% of its paid up share capital;

vi) a body corporate whose Board of Directors, Managing Director or manager is accustomed to act in accordance with the advice, directions or instructions of a Director or Manager;

vii) any person whose advice, directions or instructions a director or manager is accustomed to act;

viii) A company which is:

A holding, subsidiary or associate company of such company or;

A subsidiary of a holding company to which it is also a Subsidiary;

Question 29
Ethics deals with ideals, it is regarded as a normative science. Choose any one from the following options which is not a part of ethics as a normative science. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2015)
  • A.It tells what a human conduct ought to be.
  • B.It determines norms, ideals, standards or values.
  • C.It passes judgementsof value stating whether a particular conduct is in conformity with the moral ideal or the ideal of goodness.
  • D.It passes judgements regarding facts and events as they are and state the laws governing them.
Correct Answer: It passes judgements regarding facts and events as they are and state the laws governing them.

Ethics, as a normative science, is concerned with prescribing norms, ideals, standards, or values for human conduct. It involves determining what ought to be, passing judgments of value, and stating whether a particular conduct is in conformity with moral ideals or the ideal of goodness.

 

Options (A), (B), and (C) align with the characteristics of ethics as a normative science. Option (D), on the other hand, is not a part of ethics as a normative science. Passing judgments regarding facts and events as they are and stating the laws governing them is more aligned with descriptive or factual sciences rather than normative sciences like ethics.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option D.

Question 30
In the sphere of ethics in decision making, for determining morally correct action, there are specific stages providing rationale for moral action. Choose any one appropriate option from the following. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2015)
  • A.Actions that avoid punishment, actions that serve one's needs, actions that gain approval from others, actions that abide laws and authority, social contracts and actions supported by universal principles.
  • B.Actions that impose punishment, actions that are not followed by feedback response, actions beyond moral approbation, approved by judicial pronouncement, supported by universal principles.
  • C.Actions that are morally right, legally enforceable, is used on external believes that events are controlled by destiny, fate or luck, not supported by social contracts, supported by universal principles.
  • D.Actions that are morally wrong but supportedby hierarchy and organizational goal of profit maximization, individual judgements about ethicality of the decision is ignored.
Correct Answer: Actions that avoid punishment, actions that serve one's needs, actions that gain approval from others, actions that abide laws and authority, social contracts and actions supported by universal principles.

The correct answer is option A.

 

This question is related to the stages or levels of moral development, associated with the work of Lawrence Kohlberg. Kohlberg proposed a theory of moral development that includes several stages. The provided options reflect these stages.

 

Option A aligns with Kohlberg's stages of moral development as given below:

Actions that avoid punishment: This corresponds to the earliest stage, where individuals are motivated by fear of punishment.

Actions that serve one's needs: This represents a self-centered orientation where one's own needs and interests are the primary focus.

Actions that gain approval from others: This reflects a concern for social approval and conforming to societal norms.

Actions that abide laws and authority: This stage involves a recognition of the importance of laws and authority figures in guiding behavior.

Social contracts and actions supported by universal principles: This is the highest level where individuals recognize the importance of social contracts and universal ethical principles, demonstrating a more abstract and principled understanding of morality.

Question 31
A business should act ethically for which of the following reasons? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JAN 2017)(a) To prevent harm to the general public(b) To meet stake-holder expectations(c) To protect their own employees(d) To maximize profit of the businessCodes:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • B.(b), (c) and (d) only
  • C.(a), (c) and (d) only
  • D.(a) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c) only

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Ethical behavior in business is driven by various considerations. Let's break down the provided options:

 

(a) To prevent harm to the general public: This is a valid reason for a business to act ethically. Businesses have a responsibility to avoid causing harm to the broader community or general public.

 

(b) To meet stakeholder expectations: Meeting stakeholder expectations, including those of customers, employees, and investors, is a fundamental reason for businesses to act ethically. Ethical behavior is often expected and valued by stakeholders.

 

(c) To protect their own employees: Ensuring the well-being and protection of employees is an ethical responsibility of businesses. Ethical conduct includes creating a safe and fair working environment.

 

(d) To maximize profit of the business: While maximizing profit is a goal for businesses, it is not typically considered an ethical reason. Ethical behavior may contribute to long-term success and sustainability, but the primary focus is on values, fairness, and responsibility rather than solely on profit.

Question 32
Match the following with regards to environmental ethical issues: (UGC NET Management JUN 2013)List-Ia. Ozone Depletionb. Environmental Healthc. Loggingd. Genetic EngineeringList-II1. Lead poisoning2. Deforestation3. Food controversies4. CFCCodes:
  • A.a-4, b-2, c-1 , d-3
  • B.a-4, b-1, c-2, d-3
  • C.a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1
  • D.a-4, b-3, c-1, d-2
Correct Answer: a-4, b-1, c-2, d-3

Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) is an ozone depleting substances. Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) are nontoxic, nonflammable chemicals containing atoms of carbon, chlorine, and fluorine. They are used in the manufacture of aerosol sprays, blowing agents for foams and packing materials, as solvents, and as refrigerants.

 

Logging, or cutting down trees in a forest to harvest timber for wood, products or fuel, is a primary driver of deforestation. Logging affects the environment in several ways.

 

Lead is a highly toxic metal and a very strong poison. Lead poisoning is a serious and sometimes fatal condition. It occurs when lead builds up in the body. Lead moves into and throughout ecosystems. Atmospheric lead is deposited in vegetation, ground and water surfaces. The chemical and physical properties of lead and the biogeochemical processes within ecosystems will influence the movement of lead through ecosystems. The metal can affect all components of the environment and can move through the ecosystem until it reaches an equilibrium. Lead accumulates in the environment, but in certain chemical environ­ments it will be transformed in such a way as to increase its solubility (e.g., the formations of lead sulfate in soils), its bioavailability or its toxicity.

 

Genetically modified food controversies are disputes over the use of foods and other goods derived from genetically modified crops instead of conventional crops, and other uses of genetic engineering in food production. The disputes involve consumers, farmers, biotechnology companies, governmental regulators, non-governmental organizations, and scientists. The key areas of controversy related to genetically modified food (GM food or GMO food) are whether such food should be labeled, the role of government regulators, the objectivity of scientific research and publication, the effect of genetically modified crops on health and the environment, the effect on pesticide resistance, the impact of such crops for farmers, and the role of the crops in feeding the world population. In addition, products derived from GMO organisms play a role in the production of ethanol fuels and pharmaceuticals.

Question 33
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Ethical relativism means that there are universal standards of human behaviour.Reasoning ‘R’:Ethical behaviour is primarily personal behaviour conforming to standards of morality. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2014)
  • A.A is correct, and R is the right explanation of A.
  • B.A is incorrect, and R is a correct statement in isolation.
  • C.A and R both are incorrect.
  • D.A is correct, but R is not the right explanation of A.
Correct Answer: A is incorrect, and R is a correct statement in isolation.

Only Assertion is incorrect.

 

Ethical relativism is a philosophical perspective that argues that ethical principles are subjective and vary across cultures or individuals. It denies the existence of universal standards and asserts that moral judgments are culturally or individually determined.

Question 34
Morality of an employee in a business organisation depends upon: (UGC NET Management JUN 2014)
  • A.Individual disposition
  • B.Understanding of business activities
  • C.Understanding of individual in a group
  • D.Family setup of individual employee
Correct Answer: Individual disposition

Disposition means the positive or negative way a person views the world. In contrast, your character is determined by your inner moral values, and your personality reflects what you are like as an individual.

Question 35
Factors contributing to unethical behaviour are:
  • A.Poor leadership
  • B.Poor internal communication
  • C.Lack of management support
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Option D is the correct answer.

 

All the factors listed—poor leadership, poor internal communication, and lack of management support—can contribute to unethical behavior in an organization. Let's briefly explore each factor:

 

Poor leadership: When leaders do not set a positive example, lack integrity, or fail to establish an ethical culture within the organization, it can lead to unethical behavior among employees.

 

Poor internal communication: Ineffective communication within an organization can result in misunderstandings, lack of clarity about ethical standards, and a breakdown in conveying the importance of ethical behavior. This can contribute to unethical actions.

 

Lack of management support: If employees perceive a lack of support from management regarding ethical conduct, they may feel less motivated to adhere to ethical standards. Management's commitment to ethical behavior is crucial for fostering a culture of integrity.

Question 36
Find out the correct combination of statements with regards to business ethics: (UGC NET Jun 2015)a. Business ethics is the behaviour that a business adheres to in its daily dealings.b. The ethics of a particular business can be diverse.c. Business ethics has normative and descriptive dimensions.
  • A.only a and b
  • B.only a and c
  • C.only b and c
  • D.all a, b and c
Correct Answer: all a, b and c

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is option D - a, b, and c.

 

a. "Business ethics is the behaviour that a business adheres to in its daily dealings."

This statement is correct. Business ethics refers to the ethical principles and standards that guide the behaviour of individuals and organizations in the business environment.

 

b. "The ethics of a particular business can be diverse."

This statement is also correct. Business ethics can vary among different businesses due to factors such as industry, cultural context, and organizational values. The diversity in ethical standards is a valid consideration.

 

c. "Business ethics has normative and descriptive dimensions."

This statement is correct. Business ethics has normative dimensions, prescribing what actions are considered right or wrong, and descriptive dimensions, describing the ethical behaviour of individuals and organizations.

Question 37
Which one of the following is NOT correct about business ethics? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.Business ethics reflects the philosophy of business.
  • B.Business ethics is a form of applied ethics.
  • C.Business ethics are governed by the Government Policies.
  • D.Ethics are the standards which govern decisions on daily basis.
Correct Answer: Business ethics are governed by the Government Policies.

The correct answer is option C – Business ethics are governed by the Government Policies.

 

(A) "Business ethics reflects the philosophy of business."

This statement is correct. Business ethics is rooted in the philosophical principles that guide ethical decision-making within the business context. It involves considering moral values, principles, and standards in business practices.

 

(B) "Business ethics is a form of applied ethics."

This statement is correct. Business ethics is a branch of applied ethics, which means it applies ethical principles and theories to real-world business situations. It involves the application of moral values to business activities.

 

(C) "Business ethics are governed by the Government Policies."

This statement is NOT correct. Business ethics is more broadly shaped by societal norms, values, and moral principles. While government policies and regulations may influence ethical practices in business to some extent, business ethics is not solely governed by government policies.

 

(D) "Ethics are the standards which govern decisions on a daily basis."

This statement is correct. Ethics refers to the standards of behaviour or moral principles that guide individuals in making decisions on a daily basis, including within the business context.

Question 38
Which of the following is related to the practical means of determining a moral course of action? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.Meta ethics
  • B.Virtue ethics
  • C.Normative ethics
  • D.Applied ethics
Correct Answer: Normative ethics

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is option C - Normative ethics.

 

Normative ethics is the branch of ethics that is concerned with establishing and prescribing principles for determining what is morally right or wrong. It provides practical means for individuals and societies to evaluate and guide moral decision-making. Normative ethics seeks to answer questions about the norms, standards, and criteria that should be used to judge the morality of actions.

 

Metaethics (Option A) is concerned with the nature of ethics itself, exploring questions about the meaning of ethical language, the nature of moral reasoning, and the metaphysical foundations of ethics.

 

Virtue ethics (Option B) focuses on the development of virtuous character traits and the cultivation of moral virtues as a means of determining ethical behavior.

 

Applied ethics (Option D) involves the application of ethical principles to specific, real-world situations, such as business ethics, medical ethics, or environmental ethics.

 

Therefore, the practical means of determining a moral course of action align with normative ethics, making option (C) the correct answer.

Question 39
Which of the following is an ethical behaviour of a Manager? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Trading stocks on the basis of inside information.
  • B.Padding expense accounts.
  • C.Not divulging trade secrets to competitors.
  • D.Being severely critical of competitors.
Correct Answer: Not divulging trade secrets to competitors.

The ethical behaviour of a manager is best represented by option (C) - Not divulging trade secrets to competitors.

 

Ethical behaviour involves conducting oneself in a manner that is morally right and fair as given below.

 

(A) Trading stocks on the basis of inside information: This is unethical because it involves taking advantage of privileged information that is not available to the general public.

 

(B) Padding expense accounts: This is also unethical as it involves falsifying financial records for personal gain or to deceive stakeholders.

 

(C) Not divulging trade secrets to competitors: This is ethical. Protecting trade secrets is a common practice in business to maintain a competitive advantage. It respects the rights of the company and its stakeholders.

 

(D) Being severely critical of competitors: While expressing opinions about competitors is a common business practice, being excessively critical may cross into unethical behaviour, especially if it involves spreading false information or engaging in unfair business practices.

Question 40
Which of the following are sources of ethics? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)(i) Religion(ii) Legal system(iii) Economic system(iv) Culture(v) Family systemSelect the correct answer from the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (v)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iv)
  • C.(i), (iv), (v)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
Correct Answer: (i), (iv), (v)

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is option C.

 

Ethics draws influences from various sources that shape individuals’ and societies’ moral principles and values.

 

(i) Religion: Many ethical principles are derived from religious teachings and beliefs.

 

(iv) Culture: Cultural values and traditions play a significant role in shaping ethical perspectives within a society.

 

(v) Family system: Family upbringing and values contribute to an individual's ethical outlook and behaviour.

Quiz Attempt #119217

Total Questions: 34
Question 1
Consider the following.Statement I:Ethical decision making is a very tough prospect in this ‘dog-eat-dog’ world. All will have to fall in and play fair.Statement II:In this age of liberalization and globalization, the old dirty games and ethical conduct will no longer be accepted. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)The three basic principles of business ethicsCodes:
  • A.Statement I and II both are incorrect.
  • B.Statement I and II both are correct.
  • C.Statement I correct, II incorrect.
  • D.Statement I incorrect, II correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I and II both are correct.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Statement I suggests that ethical decision-making is challenging in a highly competitive world, but it concludes with the idea that everyone must play fair. However, it doesn't inherently make the statement incorrect. The challenges of ethical decision-making can indeed be influenced by the competitive nature of the business environment.

 

Statement II suggests that with the advent of liberalization and globalization, unethical practices will no longer be accepted. This is a positive statement about the expectation for ethical conduct in the modern business environment.

 

Given that both statements express reasonable perspectives on the challenges and expectations of ethical behavior in the business world, the correct answer is (B) Statement I and II both are correct.

Question 2
Ethical challenges may arise on account of: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2012)
  • A.Failure of personal character, conflict of personal value & organizational goals and conflict of organizational goals and social values
  • B.Hazardous but popular products
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Both A and B

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Ethical challenges can indeed arise from various sources, and both options A and B capture different aspects of these challenges:

 

(A) Failure of personal character, conflict of personal values & organizational goals, and conflict of organizational goals and social values: This option highlights challenges related to personal integrity, conflicts between personal values and organizational goals, and conflicts between organizational goals and societal values. These are common sources of ethical challenges in the workplace.

 

(B) Hazardous but popular products: This option points out a specific scenario where ethical challenges can arise. Selling products that are hazardous but popular may present a dilemma for organizations, as they need to balance profitability with ethical considerations related to consumer safety.

Question 3
The 3 basic principles of business ethics are shown by which one of the following? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)
  • A.Utilitarianism, social commitment and reputation
  • B.Utilitarianism, societal reputation and justice
  • C.Utilitarianism, principle of right and principle of justice.
  • D.Principle of right, principle of justice and social commitment
Correct Answer: Utilitarianism, principle of right and principle of justice.

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is option C - Utilitarianism, principle of right, and principle of justice.

 

The 3 basic principles of business ethics are often associated with different ethical theories and frameworks. Let's break down each component:

 

1. Utilitarianism: This ethical principle suggests that decisions should be made based on maximizing overall happiness or utility. In a business context, this would involve considering the consequences of actions and choosing the one that leads to the greatest overall benefit.

 

2. Principle of Right (Rights-based ethics): This principle is based on the idea that individuals have certain inherent rights that should be respected and protected. In business ethics, this involves recognizing and upholding the rights of employees, customers, and other stakeholders.

 

3. Principle of Justice (Justice-based ethics): This principle emphasizes fairness and equality. In business ethics, it involves treating individuals fairly, ensuring equal opportunities, and addressing issues of fairness in decision-making.

Question 4
Which one of the following denotes good choices of ethical decision making? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)
  • A.(i) take choice seriously (ii) good decisions are both ethical and effective (iii) discernment and discipline
  • B.(i) ethical actions (ii) discernment and discipline (iii) stage of social welfare
  • C.(i) take choice seriously (ii) improve ethical decision (iii) discernment and discipline
  • D.(i) good decision are both ethical and effective (ii) take choice seriously (iii) ethical actions
Correct Answer: (i) take choice seriously (ii) good decisions are both ethical and effective (iii) discernment and discipline

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The correct answer is option A - (i) take choice seriously, (ii) good decisions are both ethical and effective, (iii) discernment and discipline.

 

The question emphasizes the key components of good choices in ethical decision-making. Let's break down each part:

 

(i) Take choice seriously:

This implies that ethical decision-making involves a thoughtful and serious consideration of the choices at hand. It suggests a careful evaluation of the potential consequences and ethical implications of the decision.

 

(ii) Good decisions are both ethical and effective:

This emphasizes the idea that ethical decisions are not only morally sound but also effective in achieving their intended goals. Ethical decision-making should not compromise effectiveness, and effective decisions should align with ethical principles.

 

(iii) Discernment and discipline:

Discernment refers to the ability to perceive and understand the ethical dimensions of a situation. Discipline involves adhering to ethical principles and maintaining integrity in decision-making. Together, discernment and discipline contribute to making ethically sound choices.

Question 5
Indicate the correct code for the following statements about Assertion ‘A’and Reason ‘R’: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2013)Assertion ‘A’:All ethical theories are not equally applicable every time in all types of ethical dilemma resolution.Reason ‘R’:The ethical resolution should be based as far as possible on a cognitive ethical principle with justification.Codes
  • A.A is correct, R is incorrect.
  • B.R is correct, A is incorrect.
  • C.Both the statements A and R are correct.
  • D.Both the statements A and R are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both the statements A and R are correct.

Both Assertion and Reason are correct.

 

Assertion is correct. Different ethical theories provide distinct frameworks for approaching ethical dilemmas. The applicability of a particular ethical theory may vary depending on the nature of the dilemma and the specific context.

 

Reason is also correct. The reason emphasizes the importance of grounding ethical resolutions in cognitive ethical principles, meaning reasoned and well-justified principles. Justification provides a rational basis for ethical decision-making.

Question 6
The evaluation of Business activities and behavior as right or wrong is called: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.Corporate Governance
  • B.Business Ethics
  • C.Social Responsibility
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Business Ethics

Business Ethics refers to the principles, values, and moral standards that guide the behavior and decisions of individuals and organizations within the context of the business environment. It involves considering not only the financial and operational aspects of business, but also the social, environmental, and ethical implications of actions and choices. Business ethics aims to promote responsible and ethical conduct in business activities, taking into account the interests of stakeholders, society, and the environment.

 

Some of the prominent definitions given by various Scholars are given below.

According to Cater Mcnamara, “business Ethics is generally coming to know what is right or wrong in the work place and doing what is right. This is in regard to effects of products/services and in relationship with the stake holders.”

 

According to John Donaldson, “business ethics in short can be defined as the systematic study of ethical matters pertaining to the business, industry or related activities, institutions and beliefs. Business ethics is the systematic handling of values in business and industry.”

 

According to Andrew Crane, "business ethics is the study of business situations, activities, and decisions where issues of right and wrong are addressed."

 

According to Raymond C. Baumhart, "the ethics of business is the ethics of responsibility. The business man must promise that he will not harm knowingly."

Question 7
Which of the following is/are the component(s) of Ethics by field of interest? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUN 2015)
  • A.Descriptive ethics
  • B.Normative ethics
  • C.Meta ethics
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Ethics is often studied and analyzed through various fields of interest, and different components help in understanding and exploring ethical principles. Let's break down the components mentioned:

 

Descriptive Ethics (A): Descriptive ethics involves the study of how people perceive and understand morality. It describes and analyzes existing moral beliefs, practices, and behaviors without making judgments about their correctness.

 

Normative Ethics (B): Normative ethics is concerned with establishing norms or principles that guide ethical behavior. It involves the study of what actions are morally right or wrong and what principles should govern ethical decision-making.

 

Meta Ethics (C): Meta ethics deals with the nature of ethical concepts, the meaning of ethical terms, and the analysis of ethical language. It goes beyond specific moral principles to examine the underlying nature and foundation of ethics.

Question 8
