What is the right sequence of 4 psychological sub-processes in ethical action given by James Rest? (UGC Management JUN 2015)
  • A.Moral sensitivity, moral focus, moral judgment, moral character
  • B.Moral focus, moral character, moral sensitivity, moral judgement
  • C.Moral sensitivity, moral judgement, moral focus, moral character
  • D.Moral character, moral focus, moral judgement, moral sensitivity
Correct Answer: Moral sensitivity, moral judgement, moral focus, moral character

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Moral Development Theory of James Rest

James Rest's (1979, 1983, 1986, 1988) studies center directly on moral development in the context of formal education. The 4 component model suggests various inner psychological processes, which together give way to observable behaviour.

 

1. Moral Sensitivity: The first component of the process starts with a recognition that a moral problem or opportunity exists.

2. Moral Judgment: The second component of the model is moral judgment. It involves the individual making a judgment concerning which course of action is morally right and which course of action is morally wrong.

3. Moral Focus (Moral Intention): The third component of the model is moral focus. This one is also known as moral intention which involves the individual prioritizing choices in response to a given situation.

4. Moral Character: The final component of the model is moral character. This component involves executing and implementing a morally-based course of action. During this stage, individuals carry out their intentions by keeping the goals and outcomes of their chosen course of action in mind.

Question 9
Match the items given in the List - I and List - II and suggest the correct code: (UGC NET Management JUN 2015)List - I(a) Ethics(b) Morality(c) Moral standard(d) Meta Moral StandardList - II(i) Right code of behavior for a group or profession(ii) Prescribes right conduct for everyone(iii) Needs some inclination to follow morality(iv) Practical and pragmaticCodes:
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iv)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(iii)
  • D.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iv), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Ethics – Right code of behavior for a group or profession

Morality – Prescribes right conduct for everyone

Moral Standards – Needs some inclination to follow morality

Meta Moral Standards – Practical and pragmatic

Question 10
A Business Organization deals with product/service and has relationship with stakeholder which is being considered a part of ‘management discipline’ is known as:
  • A.Maximization of Wealth
  • B.Business Ethics
  • C.Relationship Management
  • D.Optimization of Profits
Correct Answer: Business Ethics

Business ethics is the application of general ethical ideas to business behaviour. It is based on the principle of integrity and fairness and concentrates on the benefits to the stakeholders, both internal and external. Stakeholder includes those individuals and groups without which the organization does not have an existence. It includes shareholders, creditors, employees, customers, dealers, vendors, government and the society.

Question 11
The obligation of an organization behave in an ethical way is known as: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT SEP 2013)
  • A.Knowledge about ethics
  • B.Social responsibility of business
  • C.Organizational behavior
  • D.Business without ethics
Correct Answer: Social responsibility of business

Social responsibility is an organization’s obligation to best serve society. The way organizations behave in relationship with their many stakeholders is a good indicator of their underlying ethical characters.

Question 12
Anything dealing with Ethics in Business is: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.Good, bad or both, to the business gains
  • B.Not related to religion
  • C.Not to focus obligation
  • D.Killing all types of Unfair Trade Practices
Correct Answer: Good, bad or both, to the business gains

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Ethics in business involves evaluating actions, decisions, and behaviors within a business context based on moral principles and values. It is not limited to a single perspective but encompasses a broader understanding of what is considered good, bad, or a combination of both in terms of business gains.

 

Option (A) acknowledges the varied nature of ethical considerations in business. Actions and decisions can be evaluated based on their impact on business gains, and ethical behavior may be seen as contributing positively, negatively, or having a mixed impact on the overall success and reputation of a business.

Question 13
Company seeking ethical standard must purport to: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.Good Employee Relation
  • B.Better Production Portfolio
  • C.Economy of Scale
  • D.Public Disclosure and Publishing
Correct Answer: Public Disclosure and Publishing

Option D is the correct answer.

 

When a company seeks ethical standards, it is essential to engage in transparent practices, and public disclosure and publishing play a crucial role in achieving this.

 

Option D, i.e., Public Disclosure and Publishing, aligns with the idea that ethical companies are expected to be transparent in their operations, policies, and practices. Public disclosure involves sharing information with stakeholders and the public, allowing them to assess the company's ethical standards and practices.

Question 14
Ethics are moral principles and values which: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2018)
  • A.Are legally enforceable
  • B.Guide a firm’s behavior
  • C.Provide employees with rules on how to behave
  • D.Govern the actions of an individual
Correct Answer: Govern the actions of an individual

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Ethics are moral principles and values that guide human behavior. Ethics indeed govern the actions of individuals, both at the level of employees within a firm and individuals in society more broadly.

Question 15
Match the items of List- I with those of List- II: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT NOV 2017)List - I(a) Ethics are the principles of conduct governing an individual or profession.(b) Ethics is the discipline dealing with what is good and bad, or right and wrong, or with moral duty and obligation.(c) Ethics are a set of rules that defines right and wrong conduct.(d) Business ethics, in short can be described as the systematic study of moral (ethical) matters pertaining to business, industry or related activities, institutions, or practices and beliefs.List - II(i) John Donaldson(ii) Keith Davis(iii)Shea(iv) R. Wayne MondyCodes:
  • A.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)
  • C.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(ii), d-(i)
  • D.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)

Option B is the correct answer.

 

According to R. Wayne Mondy, “Ethics is the discipline dealing with what is good and bad, or right and wrong, or with moral duty and obligation.”

 

In 1988, Shea defined ethics as the principles of conduct governing an individual or profession.

 

According to John Donaldson (1989), “business ethics in short can be described as a systematic study of moral (ethical) matters pertaining to business, industry or related activities, institutions or practices and beliefs”.

 

According to Keith Davis and associates, ethics are a set of rules that define right and wrong conduct. These rules tell us when our behaviour is acceptable and when it is disapproved and considered to be wrong. Business ethics are the application of general ethical rules to business behaviour.

Question 16
Which one of the following denotes six characteristics of ethical code of conduct for manager? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT AUG 2016)
  • A.Integrity, Impartiality, Responsiveness to public interest, Economic, Honesty, Transparency.
  • B.Integrity, Impartiality, Responsiveness to public interest, Accountability, Honesty, Transparency
  • C.Integrity, Impartiality, Responsiveness to public interest, Civil society, Accountability, Transparency.
  • D.Integrity, Impartiality, Responsiveness to public interest, Accountability, Fairness, Transparency.
Correct Answer: Integrity, Impartiality, Responsiveness to public interest, Accountability, Honesty, Transparency

Option B is the correct answer.

Question 17
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:In a widely reported instance in Wipro Technologies, a very senior executive who had put in long years of service in the company and had contributed significantly to its growth had to be dismissed because he claimed in his travel expenses more than his dues.Reasoning ‘R’:Most companies in advanced countries and some even in developing countries have developed their own Codes of Conduct, which provide some ethical standards for their employees. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JUL 2016)Codes:
  • A.Assertion is correct, but Reasoning is incorrect.
  • B.Both Assertion &Reasoning are correct and Reasoning is the right explanation of Assertion.
  • C.Both Assertion & Reasoning are correct, but Reasoning is not the right explanation of Assertion.
  • D.Both Assertion and Reasoning are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both Assertion &Reasoning are correct and Reasoning is the right explanation of Assertion.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

In the reported instance at Wipro Technologies, a Senior Executive with significant contributions to the company's growth was dismissed for claiming travel expenses exceeding his entitlement. This action illustrates the importance of organizations establishing ethical standards. Many companies, including those in advanced and developing countries, develop Codes of Conduct to provide ethical guidelines for employees. While these codes may not address every ethical dilemma, they assist employees in navigating ethical challenges by prescribing or limiting specific activities. The effectiveness of such codes depends on their communication to employees and the commitment of top management to implementation.

 

In the Wipro case, the severe action against a senior executive emphasizes the company's commitment to ethical behavior. This incident serves as a compelling lesson in ethical management and sends a strong signal about the company's expectations for ethical conduct from its employees. The implementation of ethical standards is crucial, and the Wipro case highlights the company's seriousness in upholding these standards. Therefore, both the assertion and reasoning are correct, and the reasoning appropriately explains the assertion (Option B).

Question 18
The first social audit in India to evaluate role and success of company towards moral responsibility of employees conducted by:
  • A.Birla Group (BALCO)
  • B.Wipro
  • C.Infosys
  • D.TISCO
Correct Answer: TISCO

Option D is the correct answer.

 

In India, Tata Steel (formerly TISCO) was the first company to set up a social audit committee in 1979 for measuring its social performance. The social audit committee was asked to “examine and report whether and the extent to which the Tata Steel has fulfilled the objectives contained in its Articles of Association regarding its social and moral responsibilities to the consumers, employees, shareholders, society and the local community.” The Committee reported that the social performance of the company has been of a high order and, in its magnitude, is perhaps unequalled in India.

Question 19
Match the items in the two lists: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2013)List – I (Part of Social Responsibility)a. Responsibility towards ownersb. Responsibility towards employeesc. Responsibility towards depositorsd. Responsibility towards customersList –II (Features)i. Stockii. Quality productiii. Safety of their investmentiv. Job securityv. InterestSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii), d-(v)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(v), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(v), d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii).b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(v), d-(ii)

Major Responsibility of business towards different sections of society are as:

 

Towards Employees – No Enterprise can succeed without the whole-hearted cooperation of the employees. Responsibility of business towards employees is in the form of training, promotion, proper selection, fair wages, safety, health, worker’s education, job safety, comfortable working conditions, participation management etc.

 

Towards Owners – Business is accountable towards owners as well as managing business profitably, ensuring fair and regular return on capital employed, consolidating financial position of business, guaranteeing capital appreciation so as to enable the owners to withstand any business contingencies.

 

Towards Consumers – Responsibility of business towards consumer extends to:

(i) Product:

Quality goods should be produced and supplied. Distribution system should make goods easily available to avoid artificial scarcities and after sales service should be prompt. Buying capacity and consumer preferences should be taken into consideration while deciding the manufacturing policies. The care must be exercised in supplying the goods of quality which has no adverse effect on the health of consumers.

(ii) Marketing:

To avoid being misled by wrong claims about products through improper advertisements or otherwise, the consumer should be provided full information about the products including their adverse effects, risks and care to be taken while using the products.

 

Towards Government – A number of legislatives are formed from time to time by the government for proper regulation and control of business. Businessmen should comply with all legal requirements, execute government contracts, pay taxes honestly and in time, make services of executives available for government, suggest measures and send proposals to enact new laws for the business. A number of taxes are imposed on business for collecting revenue. Businessmen should pay various taxes in time and help government in collecting funds. They should not resort to tax evasions rather declare their incomes honestly and correctly.

 

Towards Shareholders – Shareholders who are the owners of business should be provided with correct information about company to enable them to give them true and fair position of the company to enable them to decide about further investments. Company should provide a fair return on the investment made by shareholders. If shareholders do not get proper dividend then they will hesitate to invest additional funds in the concern. Shareholders should be kept fully informed about the working of the company for healthy growth of the business. The Companies Act 2013 also requires company to give full disclosure in the published statements.

 

Towards Community – Responsibility of business towards community and society includes spending a part of profits towards civic and educational facilities. Every industrial undertaking should take steps to dispose of Industrial wastes in such a way that ecological balance is maintained and environmental pollution is prevented.

 

Towards Environment – Business should protect the environment which has acquired great importance all over the world. Business can discharge the responsibility of protecting environment through preservation of Natural Resources and Pollution Control.

Question 20
A high ranking organizational official (e.g. General Counsellor or Vice President) who is expected to provide strategies for ensuring ethical conduct throughout the organization is known as: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2013)
  • A.Ethics Manager
  • B.Ethics Officer
  • C.Ethics Controller
  • D.Ethics Counsellor
Correct Answer: Ethics Officer

The correct answer is option B - Ethics Officer.

 

An Ethics Officer is a high-ranking organizational official responsible for providing strategies to ensure ethical conduct throughout the organization. The role involves developing and implementing policies and programs related to ethics, overseeing compliance, and promoting a culture of ethical behavior within the organization.

Question 21
Consider the following.Statement - I:Ethical principles tend to be broader than legal principles.Statement - II:Laws and ethics are closely related. (UGC NET MANAGEMENT JAN 2017)
  • A.Statement - I is correct but Statement - II is incorrect.
  • B.Statement - II is correct but Statement - I is incorrect.
  • C.Both the Statements are correct.
  • D.Both the Statements are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both the Statements are correct.

The correct answer is option C - Both the Statements are correct.

 

Statement I: Ethical principles tend to be broader than legal principles.

This statement is generally correct. Ethical principles encompass a broader range of values, moral considerations, and societal norms than legal principles. While laws are specific regulations established by authorities, ethical principles often reflect broader societal expectations and values that may not be explicitly codified in laws.

 

Statement II: Laws and ethics are closely related.

This statement is also correct. Laws and ethics are interconnected, as laws often reflect ethical standards and societal values. Many laws are created to codify ethical principles and establish a framework for acceptable behavior within a society. However, it's important to note that while there is a relationship between laws and ethics, they are not identical, and ethical considerations may extend beyond legal requirements.

Question 22
Fundamental legal obligations in taking corporate business decisions are formulated on the basis of:
  • A.Judicial Principles
  • B.Moral Principles
  • C.Ethical Principles
  • D.Legislative Principles
Correct Answer: Ethical Principles

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Ethical values, translated into active language establishing standards or rules describing the kind of behavior an ethical person should and should not engage in, are ethical principles. The following list of principles incorporates the characteristics and values that most people associate with ethical behavior.

Question 23
In order to check the growing unethical practices in the field of information technology, the first cyber law passed in India was:
  • A.Information Technology Act
  • B.Anti-hacking Law
  • C.Cyber Law
  • D.E-commerce Law
Correct Answer: Information Technology Act

The correct answer is (A) - Information Technology Act.

 

In order to address growing unethical practices in the field of information technology, the first cyber law passed in India was the Information Technology Act, 2000. This Act was enacted to provide legal recognition to electronic transactions and combat cybercrimes.

Question 24
Lawrence Kohlberg, in his 6 stage model of cognitive development, explains: (UGC NET Management Sep 2013)
  • A.Why people make different decisions in similar ethical situations?
  • B.How people make decisions based on the stage of cognitive moral development?
  • C.Both of the above.
  • D.None of the above.
Correct Answer: How people make decisions based on the stage of cognitive moral development?

Kohlberg’s stages of Moral Development

Kohlberg identified three distinct levels of moral reasoning each with two sub-stages. People can only pass through these levels in the order listed. Each new stage replaces the reasoning typical of the earlier stage. Not everyone achieves all the stages.

 

Level 1 - Pre-conventional morality

At the pre-conventional level (most nine-year-old and younger, some over nine), we don’t have a personal code of morality. Instead, our moral code is shaped by the standards of adults and the consequences of following or breaking their rules. Authority is outside the individual and reasoning is based on the physical consequences of actions.

Stage 1: Obedience and Punishment Orientation: The child/individual is good in order to avoid being punished. If a person is punished, they must have done wrong.

Stage 2: Individualism and Exchange: At this stage, children recognize that there is not just one right view that is handed down by the authorities. Different individuals have different viewpoints.

 

Level 2 - Conventional morality

At the conventional level (most adolescents and adults), we begin to internalize the moral standards of valued adult role models. Authority is internalized but not questioned, and reasoning is based on the norms of the group to which the person belongs.

Stage 3: Good Interpersonal Relationships: The child/individual is good in order to be seen as being a good person by others. Therefore, answers relate to the approval of others.

Stage 4: Maintaining the Social Order: The child/individual becomes aware of the wider rules of society, so judgments concern obeying the rules in order to uphold the law and to avoid guilt.

 

Level 3 - Post-conventional morality

Individual judgment is based on self-chosen principles, and moral reasoning is based on individual rights and justice. According to Kohlberg this level of moral reasoning is as far as most people get. Only 10-15% are capable of the kind of abstract thinking necessary for stage 5 or 6 (post-conventional morality). That is to say, most people take their moral views from those around them and only a minority think through ethical principles for themselves.

Stage 5: Social Contract and Individual Rights: The child/individual becomes aware that while rules/laws might exist for the good of the greatest number, there are times when they will work against the interest of particular individuals. The issues are not always clear-cut. For example, in Heinz’s dilemma, the protection of life is more important than breaking the law against stealing.

Stage 6: Universal Principles: People at this stage have developed their own set of moral guidelines which may or may not fit the law. The principles apply to everyone. E.g., human rights, justice, and equality. The person will be prepared to act to defend these principles even if it means going against the rest of society in the process and having to pay the consequences of disapproval and or imprisonment. Kohlberg doubted few people reached this stage.

Question 25
Trade Union strike supporting a political cause and affecting production activities is a problem related to:
  • A.Socio-economic phenomenon
  • B.Ethical and technical phenomenon
  • C.Ethical and economic phenomenon
  • D.Socio-political phenomenon
Correct Answer: Ethical and economic phenomenon

When a trade union goes on a strike in order to support a political cause, then it poses as an ethical issue. This is so because, the reason trade unions are being formed is to protect the interest of the workers and not seek the interests of politicians. However, since majority of trade unions are affiliated to some or the other political party, they feel obliged to work or go on strike for political interests.

 

Similarly, when trade unions go on a strike, the work stoppage leads to hampering of production activities. When the production is hampered, it directly affects the economy.

 

Thus, when trade unions strike to support a political cause and affects production activities, it is a problem related to ethical and economic phenomenon.

Question 26
According to the Economic Times study, which one of the following is India’s best company to work for in 2021? (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.Blue Dart Express Limited
  • B.DHL Express India Private Limited
  • C.NTPC Limited
  • D.Max Life Insurance Company Limited
Correct Answer: DHL Express India Private Limited

According to the Economic Times study, India’s best company to work for in 2021 was DHL Express India Private Limited.

Question 27
Environmental Ethics refers to: (UGC NET Management Jun 2009)
  • A.Unfair Trade Practices.
  • B.Pollution.
  • C.Product price.
  • D.Quality of the product
Correct Answer: Pollution.

The correct answer is option (B) Pollution.

 

Environmental Ethics refers to the ethical considerations and principles related to the interactions between human activities and the natural environment. It involves the moral responsibility of individuals, organizations, and societies towards the environment. The key focus of Environmental Ethics is on sustainable practices, conservation, and minimizing harm to the ecosystem.

 

Therefore, the most relevant aspect related to Environmental Ethics among the given options is (B) Pollution.

Question 28
________is the Manager’s dilemma when he has to decide on the commercial proposal submitted by his son. (UGC NET Management Dec 2011)
  • A.Favouritism
  • B.Moral Dilemma
  • C.Conflict of Interest
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Conflict of Interest

The correct answer is option (C) - Conflict of Interest.

 

When a manager is faced with the decision on a commercial proposal submitted by his son, the situation involves a "Conflict of Interest." A conflict of interest arises when an individual, such as a manager, has competing interests that could compromise their ability to act impartially or make objective decisions.

Question 29
Match the following: (UGC NET MANAGEMENT SEP 2013)List – I(a) Value(b) Unethical behavior(c) Indian ethos(d) Environmental responsibilityList - II(i) Aham Brahmasmi(ii) Recycling Waste(iii) Bribery(iv) TrustworthinessCodes:
  • A.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(iv), d-(i)
  • D.a-(i). b-(iii), c-(iv), d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)

Option B is the correct answer.

 

a) Value – Trustworthiness is a moral value considered to be a virtue. A trustworthy person is someone in whom we can place our trust and be sure that the trust will not be betrayed.

b) Unethical behavior – Bribery is one of the archetypal examples of a corporation engaged in unethical behavior.

c) Indian ethos – Aham Brahmasmi is a term that is used in Hindu and yoga philosophy to describe the unity of the atman (individual self or soul) with Brahman (the Absolute). It is typically translated as “I am Brahman” or less literally as “I am divine.”

d) Environmental Responsibility – Recycling is processing used materials (waste) into new, useful products. This is done to reduce the use of raw materials that would have been used. Recycling also uses less energy and great way of controlling air, water and land pollution.

Question 30
Match the items of List-II with those of List-I; and choose the correct code of combination:List-I(a) Procedural Justice(b) Restorative Justice(c) Retributive Justice(d) Distributive JusticeList-II(i) Works on the principle of punishment.(ii) Treat equal people equally and unequal people unequally.(iii) Its simplest form is an apology.(iv) Actions performed complying with the law.Code:
  • A.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(ii), d-(i)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Procedural Justice (c) - (iv):

Procedural justice focuses on the fairness of the processes used to make decisions. It emphasizes that actions performed should comply with established laws and procedures. The emphasis is on the fairness of the procedures followed in decision-making.

 

Restorative Justice (b) - (iii):

Restorative justice is a system of criminal justice that focuses on rehabilitation and reconciliation between offenders and victims. Its simplest form often involves an apology or some form of restitution. The goal is to repair the harm caused by the offense.

 

Retributive Justice (a) - (i):

Retributive justice is based on the principle of punishment. It is a theory of justice that holds that the punishment inflicted should be proportionate to the offense committed. It focuses on punishment as a means of societal revenge or moral balancing.

 

Distributive Justice (d) - (ii):

Distributive justice concerns the fair distribution of resources and opportunities in society. It is often associated with the idea of treating equal people equally and unequal people unequally, based on relevant criteria such as need, effort, or contribution.

Question 31
Match the following. (UGC NET Management JUN 2014)List-I (Types of Qualities)a. Physicalb. Ethicalc. Sociald. MentalList-II (Features)i. Sharp memoryii. Coordinatoriii. Personalityiv. CharacterSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.Codes
  • A.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
  • C.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The correct matching is option (B) - a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i.

 

Physical Qualities (a) are matched with Personality (iii).

Ethical Qualities (b) are matched with Character (iv).

Social Qualities (c) are matched with Coordinator (ii).

Mental Qualities (d) are matched with Sharp memory (i).

Question 32
Match the items of List-I with the items of List-II regarding evaluation of project application andEthics refer to the principles of conduct governing an individual or a group; specifically, the standard one uses to decide what one’s conduct should be.Making ethical decisions always involves normative judgements. Ethical decisions always involve questions of morality which is society’s highest accepted standards of behavior.  Moral standards guide behaviors of the most serious consequence to society’swellbeing.  Authoritative bodies like legislatures cannot change what morality means.  Moral judgements also trigger strong emotions.  Violating moral standards may therefore make someone feel ashamed or remorseful.  Asking ‘Is what I am doing legal?’ would not necessarily reveal if it is ethical.  Firing a 39-year-old employee with 20 years’ tenure without cause may be legal but some would view it as unethical.  Ethics means making decisions that represent what you stand for, not just what the laws are.Which among the following is not a characteristic of ethical decision? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2018)
  • A.It can be change by legislatures.
  • B.It should lead to most serious consequences to make society’s wellbeing.
  • C.It should involve question of morality.
  • D.It evokes strong emotions.
Correct Answer: It can be change by legislatures.

Source Based Answer. From the line “Authoritative bodies like legislatures cannot change what morality means”, it is clear that ethical decisions cannot be changed by legislatures.

Question 33
Ethics refer to the principles of conduct governing an individual or a group; specifically, the standard one uses to decide what one’s conduct should be. Making ethical decisions always involves normative judgements. Ethical decisions always involve questions of morality which is society’s highest accepted standards of behavior.  Moral standards guide behaviors of the most serious consequence to society’s wellbeing.  Authoritative bodies like legislatures cannot change what morality means.  Moral judgements also trigger strong emotions.  Violating moral standards may therefore make someone feel ashamed or remorseful.  Asking ‘Is what I am doing legal?’ would not necessarily reveal if it is ethical.  Firing a 39-year-old employee with 20 years’ tenure without cause may be legal but some would view it as unethical.  Ethics means making decisions that represent what you stand for, not just what the laws are.Which among the following cannot be a parameter of being called ethical? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2018)
  • A.Decisions involving normative judgements
  • B.Standard one uses to decide what one’s conduct should be
  • C.Conduct governing an individual or group
  • D.Decisions involving authoritative judgements
Correct Answer: Decisions involving authoritative judgements

Source Based Answer. From the line “Authoritative bodies like legislatures cannot change what morality means”, it is clear that decisions involving authoritative judgements cannot be a parameter of being ethical.

 

Rest of the three options are stated as ethical in the starting of the paragraph itself “Ethics refer to the principles of conduct governing an individual or a group; specifically, the standard one uses to decide what one’s conduct should be. Making ethical decisions always involves normative judgements.”

Question 34
Ethics refer to the principles of conduct governing an individual or a group; specifically, the standard one uses to decide what one’s conduct should be. Making ethical decisions always involves normative judgements. Ethical decisions always involve questions of morality which is society’s highest accepted standards of behavior.  Moral standards guide behaviors of the most serious consequence to society’s wellbeing.  Authoritative bodies like legislatures cannot change what morality means.  Moral judgementsalso trigger strong emotions.  Violating moral standards may therefore make someone feel ashamed or remorseful.  Asking ‘Is what I am doing legal?’ would not necessarily reveal if it is ethical.  Firing a 39-year-old employee with 20 years’ tenure withoutcause may be legal but some would view it as unethical.  Ethics means making decisions that represent what you stand for, not just what the laws are.Among the following statements, which one is not true? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2018)
  • A.A decision may be legal but may not be ethical.
  • B.Ethical decisions represent what one stands for.
  • C.Ethical decisions are always legal.
  • D.Ethical decisions involve questions of morality.
Correct Answer: Ethical decisions are always legal.

Ethical decisions are not always legal. Ethical decision involves moral standards which are generally principles governing conduct of a society in which we are living however they are not binding on any member of the society. A person is not simply be punished under law or there is no legal implication if he is not behaving ethically in some grave situations.

 

For example, taking a child away from an abusive parent when you are nowhere related to the child. OR Talking over the phone with your friend while driving to your friend’s house who is having a panic attack.
